"summary": {"eng": "WASHINGTON, June 12 (Reuters) - U.S. President Joe Biden departed for Italy on Wednesday to meet with Group of Seven leaders in an effort to increase pressure on Russia over its war against Ukraine and on China for its support of Moscow and excess industrial capacity.\n\nThe G7 leaders arrive at the summit confronting myriad woes at home even as they seek solutions for many of the world's most pressing problems.\n\nBiden, 81, spent Tuesday evening at his home in Wilmington, Delaware, after a 12-membe"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Apulia"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Italy"}}}, "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 14}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Economic", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Economic", "wgt": 13}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare and Conflict", "wgt": 14}, {"uri": "news/Politics", "label": "news/Politics", "wgt": 93}], "articleCounts": {"eng": 349}, "sentiment": 0.2705882352941176, "breakingScore": 0.3556708451739712}
{"uri": "8174968173", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "21:38:48", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T21:38:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T21:37:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://wsvn.com/news/politics/biden-and-zelenskyy-will-sign-a-security-deal-as-g7-leaders-agree-to-use-russian-cash-to-help-kyiv/", "title": "Biden and Zelenskyy will sign a security deal, as G7 leaders agree to use Russian cash to help Kyiv - WSVN 7News | Miami News, Weather, Sports | Fort Lauderdale", "body": "BRINDISI, Italy (AP) -- President Joe Biden and President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will sign a bilateral security agreement between the U.S. and Ukraine on Thursday when they meet on the sidelines of the Group of Seven summit in Italy, as negotiators for the group have reached an agreement on how to provide Ukraine with up to $50 billion backed by frozen Russian assets.\n\nThe international group of wealthy democracies has been discussing ways of using the more than $260 billion in Russian assets frozen outside the country after the Feb. 24, 2022 invasion of Ukraine to help Kyiv.\n\nEuropean officials have resisted confiscating the assets, citing legal and financial stability concerns -- most of the frozen assets are located in Europe -- but the plan would use the interest earned on the assets to help Ukraine's war effort. An official with the French presidency confirmed the agreement Wednesday, saying most of the money would be flowing to Ukraine in the form of a loan from the U.S. government backed by the proceeds of the frozen Russian assets in the European Union. Two other people familiar with the matter confirmed the arrangement.\n\nFinal technical negotiations were underway ahead of the summit to finalize the legal terms of the deal.\n\nThe announcement of the agreement comes as Biden landed in Italy to attend the summit of the world's leading democracies with an urgency to get big things done, including turning frozen Russian assets into billions of dollars to help Ukraine fight Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\nThe security arrangement was aimed to send a signal to Russia of American resolve in supporting Kyiv, the White House said as Biden was headed to Europe.\n\nNational security adviser Jake Sullivan said the security agreement would not commit U.S. troops directly to Ukraine's defense against Russia's invasion -- a red line drawn by Biden, who's fearful of being pulled into direct conflict between the nuclear-armed powers.\n\n\"We want to demonstrate that the U.S. supports the people of Ukraine, that we stand with them and that we'll continue to help address their security needs,\" Sullivan said, adding \"this agreement will show our resolve.\"\n\nSullivan said aboard Air Force One that the goal of the financing plan was to have a loan that would \"pull forward the windfall profits from the seized assets\" of Russia, giving Ukraine a \"substantial source of funding\" to meet its immediate needs.\n\nThe national security adviser said he had a specific sum of money in mind, but declined to say if that figure was $50 billion. He stressed the urgency of getting Ukraine financial resources as soon as possible and that multiple countries would back the agreement.\n\n\"It's to provide the necessary resources to Ukraine now for its economic energy and other needs, so that it's capable of having the resilience necessary to withstand Russia's continuing aggression,\" Sullivan said.\n\nThis year's meeting comes three years after Biden declared at his first such gathering that America was back as a global leader following the disruptions to Western alliances that occurred when Donald Trump was president. Now, there's a chance this gathering could be the final G7 for Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of elections this year.\n\nBiden and his counterparts from Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related to artificial intelligence, migration, the Russian military's resurgence and China's economic might, among other topics. Pope Francis, Zelenskyy and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan are joining the gathering at the Borgo Egnazia resort in the Puglia region of southern Italy.\n\nThe summit, opening Thursday, will play out after far-right parties across the continent racked up gains of surprising scale in just-concluded European Union elections. Those victories -- coupled with upcoming elections in the United Kingdom, France and the United States -- have rattled the global political establishment and added weightiness to this year's summit.\n\n\"You hear this a lot when you talk to U.S. and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether it's on China, whether it's on the assets, we may not have another chance,\" said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Council's GeoEconomics Center, an international affairs think tank. \"We don't know what the world will look like three months, six months, nine months from now.\"\n\nThe G7 is an informal bloc of industrialized democracies that meets annually to discuss shared issues and concerns. Biden will arrive in Italy on Wednesday night, his second trip outside the U.S. in as many weeks. The Democratic president was in France last week for a state visit in Paris and ceremonies in Normandy marking the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings in World War II.\n\nWhile last week's visit had a celebratory feel, this one will be dominated by pressing global issues, including how to keep financial support flowing to Ukraine as it fights Russia's invasion. Biden's trip comes a day after his son Hunter was convicted on federal gun charges, a blow sure to weigh heavily on the president's mind.\n\nDespite pressing global challenges, White House national security spokesman John Kirby said there's still a sense of relief among world leaders in 2024 that \"America was back,\" referencing Biden's 2021 speech at the G7 in England.\n\n\"Biden's message then was that democracies need to step up and show they can deliver for their people,\" Kirby said. \"That's true now more than ever.\"\n\nKirby said the U.S. was prepared to work with democratically elected officials in the EU no matter who they are, though some of those being elevated have expressed far less support for Ukraine than current leaders.\n\n\"We have every confidence that regardless of who fills the seats in the European Parliament, we're going to continue to work closely with our EU partners on all the issues relative to our shared interests across the European continent,\" Kirby said. \"That includes supporting Ukraine.\"\n\nBiden and Zelenskyy, who met last week in Paris, will meet again to discuss continued support for the Eastern European nation, which is trying to fend off an intense Russian offensive in eastern areas of the country. They're expected to hold a joint news conference. Biden is also expected to meet with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, the pope and other leaders.\n\nBiden, who's been adamant \"we will not walk away\" from Ukraine, last week publicly apologized to Zelenskyy for a monthslong delay by Congress in authorizing additional American military assistance. The delay allowed Russia to make gains on the battlefield.\n\nSullivan called the security agreement a \"bridge\" to when Ukraine is invited to join the NATO alliance -- a long-term priority of Zelenskyy's that the allies have said will first require an end to the Russia-Ukraine war and that Putin has steadfastly opposed.\n\nBiden's back-to-back trips to France and Italy amount to a rare doubleheader of diplomacy in the midst of the presidential election. The president will skip a Ukraine peace conference in Switzerland this weekend to jet to Los Angeles for a campaign fundraiser with big names from Hollywood. Vice President Kamala Harris will represent the U.S. at the conference.\n\nDespite the delays in military aid, the Biden administration on Tuesday announced it would send Ukraine another Patriot missile system to help fend off Russian strikes, two U.S. officials told The Associated Press. Biden approved the move, the officials told the AP, as Kyiv has desperately called for more air defenses in its battle against an intense Russian assault on the northeastern Kharkiv region.\n\nEarlier Wednesday, the U.S. announced fresh sanctions targeting Chinese companies that help Russia pursue its war in Ukraine, as well as Russia's financial infrastructure. Sullivan said, \"These actions will ratchet up the risk that foreign financial institutions take by dealing with Russia's war economy.\"\n\nBiden is also expected to discuss economic concerns brought on by Chinese manufacturing overcapacity, how to use artificial intelligence in a way that maximizes benefits but still manages national security risks, and global migration.\n\nThe U.S. and other G7 nations are struggling to manage large influxes of migrants arriving for complicated reasons that include war, climate change and drought. Migration, and how nations cope with the growing numbers at their borders, has been a factor driving the far-right rise in some of Europe.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.\n\nJoin our Newsletter for the latest news right to your inbox Email address Submit", "source": {"uri": "wsvn.com", "https://wsvn.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2023/09/230921-Zelenskyy-and-the-Bidens.png", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9644722", "eventUri": "eng-9644722", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Brindisi"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Italy"}}}, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.5137254901960784, "wgt": 208, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-06-387686960", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "22:27:49", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T22:27:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T22:04:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.newsmax.com/politics/Biden-G7-Italy-Ukraine-Russian-assets/2024/06/12/id/1168530/", "title": "Biden, Zelenskyy Will Sign Security Deal; G7 Leaders Agree to Use Russian Cash to Aid Kyiv", "body": "President Joe Biden and President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will sign a bilateral security agreement between the U.S. and Ukraine on Thursday when they meet on the sidelines of the Group of Seven summit in Italy.\n\nNegotiators for the group have also reached an agreement on how to provide Ukraine with up to $50 billion backed by frozen Russian assets.\n\nThe international group of wealthy democracies has been discussing ways of using the more than $260 billion in frozen Russian assets, most of which are outside the country, to help Ukraine fight Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\nEuropean officials have resisted confiscating the assets, citing legal and financial stability concerns, but the plan would use the interest earned on the assets to help Ukraine's war effort. An official with the French presidency confirmed the agreement Wednesday, saying most of the money would be flowing to Ukraine in the form of a loan from the U.S. government backed by the proceeds of the frozen Russian assets in the European Union. Two other people familiar with the matter confirmed the arrangement.\n\nFinal technical negotiations were underway ahead of the summit to finalize the legal terms of the deal.\n\nThe announcement of the agreement comes as Biden landed in Italy with an urgency to get big things done. Thursday's security arrangement was aimed to send a signal to Russia of American resolve in supporting Kyiv, the White House said.\n\nNational security adviser Jake Sullivan said the security agreement would not commit U.S. troops directly to Ukraine's defense against Russia's invasion -- a red line drawn by Biden, who's fearful of being pulled into direct conflict between the nuclear-armed powers.\n\n\"We want to demonstrate that the U.S. supports the people of Ukraine, that we stand with them and that we'll continue to help address their security needs,\" Sullivan said, adding \"this agreement will show our resolve.\"\n\nSullivan said aboard Air Force One that the goal of the financing plan was to have a loan that would \"pull forward the windfall profits from the seized assets\" of Russia, giving Ukraine a \"substantial source of funding\" to meet its immediate needs.\n\nThe national security adviser said he had a specific sum of money in mind, but declined to say if that figure was $50 billion. He stressed the urgency of getting Ukraine financial resources as soon as possible and that multiple countries would back the agreement.\n\n\"It's to provide the necessary resources to Ukraine now for its economic energy and other needs, so that it's capable of having the resilience necessary to withstand Russia's continuing aggression,\" Sullivan said.\n\nThis year's meeting comes three years after Biden declared at his first such gathering that America was back as a global leader following the disruptions to Western alliances that occurred when Donald Trump was president. Now, there's a chance this gathering could be the final summit for Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of elections this year.\n\nBiden and his counterparts from Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related to artificial intelligence, migration, the Russian military's resurgence and China's economic might, among other topics. Pope Francis, Zelenskyy and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan are joining the gathering at the Borgo Egnazia resort in the Puglia region of southern Italy.\n\nThe summit, which opened Thursday, will play out after far-right parties across the continent racked up gains of surprising scale in just-concluded European Union elections. Those victories -- coupled with upcoming elections in the United Kingdom, France and the United States -- have rattled the global political establishment and added weightiness to this year's summit.\n\n\"You hear this a lot when you talk to U.S. and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether it's on China, whether it's on the assets, we may not have another chance,\" said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Council's GeoEconomics Center, an international affairs think tank. \"We don't know what the world will look like three months, six months, nine months from now.\"\n\nThe G7 is an informal bloc of industrialized democracies that meets annually to discuss shared issues and concerns. This is Biden's second trip outside the U.S. in as many weeks; the Democratic president was in France last week for a state visit in Paris and ceremonies in Normandy marking the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings in World War II.\n\nWhile last week's visit had a celebratory feel, this one will be dominated by pressing global issues, including how to keep financial support flowing to Ukraine as it fights Russia's invasion. Biden's trip comes days after his son Hunter was convicted on federal gun charges, a blow sure to weigh heavily on the president's mind.\n\nDespite pressing global challenges, White House national security spokesman John Kirby said there's still a sense of relief among world leaders in 2024 that \"America was back,\" referencing Biden's 2021 speech at the G7 in England.\n\n\"Biden's message then was that democracies need to step up and show they can deliver for their people,\" Kirby said. \"That's true now more than ever.\"\n\nKirby said the U.S. was prepared to work with democratically elected officials in the EU no matter who they are, though some of those being elevated have expressed far less support for Ukraine than current leaders.\n\n\"We have every confidence that regardless of who fills the seats in the European Parliament, we're going to continue to work closely with our EU partners on all the issues relative to our shared interests across the European continent,\" Kirby said. \"That includes supporting Ukraine.\"\n\nBiden and Zelenskyy, who met last week in Paris, are expected to hold a joint news conference while meeting at the G7 summit. Biden is also expected to meet with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, the pope and other leaders.\n\nBiden, who's been adamant \"we will not walk away\" from Ukraine, last week publicly apologized to Zelenskyy for a monthslong delay by Congress in authorizing additional American military assistance. The delay allowed Russia to make gains on the battlefield.\n\nSullivan called the security agreement a \"bridge\" to when Ukraine is invited to join the NATO alliance -- a long-term priority of Zelenskyy's that the allies have said will first require an end to the Russia-Ukraine war and that Putin has steadfastly opposed.\n\nBiden's back-to-back trips to France and Italy amount to a rare doubleheader of diplomacy in the midst of the presidential election. The president, however, will skip a Ukraine peace conference in Switzerland this weekend to jet to Los Angeles for a campaign fundraiser with big names from Hollywood. Vice President Kamala Harris will represent the U.S. at the conference.\n\nDespite the delays in military aid, the Biden administration on Tuesday announced it would send Ukraine another Patriot missile system to help fend off Russian strikes, two U.S. officials told The Associated Press.\n\nEarlier Wednesday, the U.S. also announced fresh sanctions targeting Chinese companies that help Russia pursue its war in Ukraine, as well as Russia's financial infrastructure. Sullivan said, \"These actions will ratchet up the risk that foreign financial institutions take by dealing with Russia's war economy.\"\n\nBiden is also expected to discuss economic concerns brought on by Chinese manufacturing overcapacity, how to use artificial intelligence in a way that maximizes benefits but still manages national security risks, and global migration.\n\nThe U.S. and other G7 nations are struggling to manage large influxes of migrants arriving for complicated reasons that include war, climate change and drought. Migration, and how nations cope with the growing numbers at their borders, has been a factor driving the far-right rise in some of Europe.", "source": {"uri": "newsmax.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8175059824", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "23:26:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T23:26:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T23:25:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.chicagotribune.com/2024/06/12/biden-and-zelenskyy-security-deal/", "title": "Biden and Zelenskyy will sign a security deal, as G7 leaders agree to use Russian cash to help Kyiv", "body": "BRINDISI, Italy -- President Joe Biden and President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will sign a bilateral security agreement between the U.S. and Ukraine on Thursday when they meet on the sidelines of the Group of Seven summit in Italy.\n\nNegotiators for the group have also reached an agreement on how to provide Ukraine with up to $50 billion backed by frozen Russian assets.\n\nThe international group of wealthy democracies has been discussing ways of using the more than $260 billion in frozen Russian assets, most of which are outside the country, to help Ukraine fight Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\nEuropean officials have resisted confiscating the assets, citing legal and financial stability concerns, but the plan would use the interest earned on the assets to help Ukraine's war effort. An official with the French presidency confirmed the agreement Wednesday, saying most of the money would be flowing to Ukraine in the form of a loan from the U.S. government backed by the proceeds of the frozen Russian assets in the European Union. Two other people familiar with the matter confirmed the arrangement.\n\nFinal technical negotiations were underway ahead of the summit to finalize the legal terms of the deal.\n\nThe announcement of the agreement comes as Biden landed in Italy with an urgency to get big things done. Thursday's security arrangement was aimed to send a signal to Russia of American resolve in supporting Kyiv, the White House said.\n\nNational security adviser Jake Sullivan said the security agreement would not commit U.S. troops directly to Ukraine's defense against Russia's invasion -- a red line drawn by Biden, who's fearful of being pulled into direct conflict between the nuclear-armed powers.\n\n\"We want to demonstrate that the U.S. supports the people of Ukraine, that we stand with them and that we'll continue to help address their security needs,\" Sullivan said, adding \"this agreement will show our resolve.\"\n\nSullivan said aboard Air Force One that the goal of the financing plan was to have a loan that would \"pull forward the windfall profits from the seized assets\" of Russia, giving Ukraine a \"substantial source of funding\" to meet its immediate needs.\n\nThe national security adviser said he had a specific sum of money in mind, but declined to say if that figure was $50 billion. He stressed the urgency of getting Ukraine financial resources as soon as possible and that multiple countries would back the agreement.\n\n\"It's to provide the necessary resources to Ukraine now for its economic energy and other needs, so that it's capable of having the resilience necessary to withstand Russia's continuing aggression,\" Sullivan said.\n\nThis year's meeting comes three years after Biden declared at his first such gathering that America was back as a global leader following the disruptions to Western alliances that occurred when Donald Trump was president. Now, there's a chance this gathering could be the final summit for Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of elections this year.\n\nBiden and his counterparts from Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related to artificial intelligence, migration, the Russian military's resurgence and China's economic might, among other topics. Pope Francis, Zelenskyy and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan are joining the gathering at the Borgo Egnazia resort in the Puglia region of southern Italy.\n\nThe summit, which opened Thursday, will play out after far-right parties across the continent racked up gains of surprising scale in just-concluded European Union elections. Those victories -- coupled with upcoming elections in the United Kingdom, Franceand the United States -- have rattled the global political establishment and added weightiness to this year's summit.\n\n\"You hear this a lot when you talk to U.S. and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether it's on China, whether it's on the assets, we may not have another chance,\" said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Council's GeoEconomics Center, an international affairs think tank. \"We don't know what the world will look like three months, six months, nine months from now.\"\n\nThe G7 is an informal bloc of industrialized democracies that meets annually to discuss shared issues and concerns. This is Biden's second trip outside the U.S. in as many weeks; the Democratic president was in France last week for a state visit in Paris and ceremonies in Normandy marking the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings in World War II.\n\nWhile last week's visit had a celebratory feel, this one will be dominated by pressing global issues, including how to keep financial support flowing to Ukraine as it fights Russia's invasion. Biden's trip comes days after his son Hunter was convicted on federal gun charges, a blow sure to weigh heavily on the president's mind.\n\nDespite pressing global challenges, White House national security spokesman John Kirby said there's still a sense of relief among world leaders in 2024 that \"America was back,\"referencing Biden's 2021 speech at the G7 in England.\n\n\"Biden's message then was that democracies need to step up and show they can deliver for their people,\" Kirby said. \"That's true now more than ever.\"\n\nKirby said the U.S. was prepared to work with democratically elected officials in the EU no matter who they are, though some of those being elevated have expressed far less support for Ukraine than current leaders.\n\n\"We have every confidence that regardless of who fills the seats in the European Parliament, we're going to continue to work closely with our EU partners on all the issues relative to our shared interests across the European continent,\" Kirby said. \"That includes supporting Ukraine.\"\n\nBiden and Zelenskyy, who met last week in Paris, are expected to hold a joint news conference while meeting at the G7 summit. Biden is also expected to meet with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, the pope and other leaders.\n\nBiden, who's been adamant \"we will not walk away\" from Ukraine, last week publicly apologized to Zelenskyy for a monthslong delay by Congress in authorizing additional American military assistance. The delay allowed Russia to make gains on the battlefield.\n\nSullivan called the security agreement a \"bridge\" to when Ukraine is invited to join the NATO alliance -- a long-term priority of Zelenskyy's that the allies have said will first require an end to the Russia-Ukraine war and that Putin has steadfastly opposed.\n\nBiden's back-to-back trips to France and Italy amount to a rare doubleheader of diplomacy in the midst of the presidential election. The president, however, will skip a Ukraine peace conference in Switzerland this weekend to jet to Los Angeles for a campaign fundraiser with big names from Hollywood. Vice President Kamala Harris will represent the U.S. at the conference.\n\nDespite the delays in military aid, the Biden administration on Tuesday announced it would send Ukraine another Patriot missile system to help fend off Russian strikes, two U.S. officials told The Associated Press.\n\nEarlier Wednesday, the U.S. also announced fresh sanctionstargeting Chinese companies that help Russia pursue its war in Ukraine, as well as Russia's financial infrastructure. Sullivan said, \"These actions will ratchet up the risk that foreign financial institutions take by dealing with Russia's war economy.\"\n\nBiden is also expected to discuss economic concerns brought on by Chinese manufacturing overcapacity, how to use artificial intelligence in a way that maximizes benefits but still manages national security risks, and global migration.\n\nThe U.S. and other G7 nations are struggling to manage large influxes of migrants arriving for complicated reasons that include war, climate change and drought. Migration, and how nations cope with the growing numbers at their borders, has been a factor driving the far-right rise in some of Europe.", "source": {"uri": "chicagotribune.com", "dataType": "news", "https://www.chicagotribune.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Italy_G7_Biden_56201.jpg?w=640", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9644722", "eventUri": "eng-9644722", "location": {"type": "place", {"uri": "8175038304", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "22:58:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T22:58:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T22:57:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.opb.org/article/2024/06/12/biden-zelenskyy-sign-security-deal-as-g7-leaders-agree-to-use-russian-cash-help-kyiv/", "title": "Biden and Zelenskyy will sign a security deal as G7 leaders agree to use Russian cash to help Kyiv", "body": "By DARLENE SUPERVILLE, COLLEEN LONG, ZEKE MILLER and AAMER MADHANI (Associated Press)\n\nPresident Joe Biden and President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will sign a bilateral security agreement between the U.S. and Ukraine on Thursday when they meet on the sidelines of the Group of Seven summit in Italy, as negotiators for the group have reached an agreement on how to provide Ukraine with up to $50 billion backed by frozen Russian assets.\n\nThe international group of wealthy democracies has been discussing ways of using the more than $260 billion in Russian assets frozen outside the country after the Feb. 24, 2022 invasion of Ukraine to help Kyiv.\n\nEuropean officials have resisted confiscating the assets, citing legal and financial stability concerns -- most of the frozen assets are located in Europe -- but the plan would use the interest earned on the assets to help Ukraine's war effort. An official with the French presidency confirmed the agreement Wednesday, saying most of the money would be flowing to Ukraine in the form of a loan from the U.S. government backed by the proceeds of the frozen Russian assets in the European Union. Two other people familiar with the matter confirmed the arrangement.\n\nFinal technical negotiations were underway ahead of the summit to finalize the legal terms of the deal.\n\nThe announcement of the agreement comes as Biden landed in Italy to attend the summit of the world's leading democracies with an urgency to get big things done, including turning frozen Russian assets into billions of dollars to help Ukraine fight Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\nThe security arrangement was aimed to send a signal to Russia of American resolve in supporting Kyiv, the White House said as Biden was headed to Europe.\n\nNational security adviser Jake Sullivan said the security agreement would not commit U.S. troops directly to Ukraine's defense against Russia's invasion -- a red line drawn by Biden, who's fearful of being pulled into direct conflict between the nuclear-armed powers.\n\n\"We want to demonstrate that the U.S. supports the people of Ukraine, that we stand with them and that we'll continue to help address their security needs,\" Sullivan said, adding \"this agreement will show our resolve.\"\n\nSullivan said aboard Air Force One that the goal of the financing plan was to have a loan that would \"pull forward the windfall profits from the seized assets\" of Russia, giving Ukraine a \"substantial source of funding\" to meet its immediate needs.\n\nThe national security adviser said he had a specific sum of money in mind, but declined to say if that figure was $50 billion. He stressed the urgency of getting Ukraine financial resources as soon as possible and that multiple countries would back the agreement.\n\n\"It's to provide the necessary resources to Ukraine now for its economic energy and other needs, so that it's capable of having the resilience necessary to withstand Russia's continuing aggression,\" Sullivan said.\n\nThis year's meeting comes three years after Biden declared at his first such gathering that America was back as a global leader following the disruptions to Western alliances that occurred when Donald Trump was president. Now, there's a chance this gathering could be the final G7 for Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of elections this year.\n\nBiden and his counterparts from Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related to artificial intelligence, migration, the Russian military's resurgence and China's economic might, among other topics. Pope Francis, Zelenskyy and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan are joining the gathering at the Borgo Egnazia resort in the Puglia region of southern Italy.\n\nThe summit, opening Thursday, will play out after far-right parties across the continent racked up gains of surprising scale in just-concluded European Union elections. Those victories -- coupled with upcoming elections in the United Kingdom, France and the United States -- have rattled the global political establishment and added weightiness to this year's summit.\n\n\"You hear this a lot when you talk to U.S. and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether it's on China, whether it's on the assets, we may not have another chance,\" said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Council's GeoEconomics Center, an international affairs think tank. \"We don't know what the world will look like three months, six months, nine months from now.\"\n\nThe G7 is an informal bloc of industrialized democracies that meets annually to discuss shared issues and concerns. Biden will arrive in Italy on Wednesday night, his second trip outside the U.S. in as many weeks. The Democratic president was in France last week for a state visit in Paris and ceremonies in Normandy marking the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings in World War II.\n\nWhile last week's visit had a celebratory feel, this one will be dominated by pressing global issues, including how to keep financial support flowing to Ukraine as it fights Russia's invasion. Biden's trip comes a day after his son Hunter was convicted on federal gun charges, a blow sure to weigh heavily on the president's mind.\n\nDespite pressing global challenges, White House national security spokesman John Kirby said there's still a sense of relief among world leaders in 2024 that \"America was back,\" referencing Biden's 2021 speech at the G7 in England.\n\n\"Biden's message then was that democracies need to step up and show they can deliver for their people,\" Kirby said. \"That's true now more than ever.\"\n\nKirby said the U.S. was prepared to work with democratically elected officials in the EU no matter who they are, though some of those being elevated have expressed far less support for Ukraine than current leaders.\n\n\"We have every confidence that regardless of who fills the seats in the European Parliament, we're going to continue to work closely with our EU partners on all the issues relative to our shared interests across the European continent,\" Kirby said. \"That includes supporting Ukraine.\"\n\nBiden and Zelenskyy, who met last week in Paris, will meet again to discuss continued support for the Eastern European nation, which is trying to fend off an intense Russian offensive in eastern areas of the country. They're expected to hold a joint news conference. Biden is also expected to meet with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, the pope and other leaders.\n\nBiden, who's been adamant \"we will not walk away\" from Ukraine, last week publicly apologized to Zelenskyy for a monthslong delay by Congress in authorizing additional American military assistance. The delay allowed Russia to make gains on the battlefield.\n\nSullivan called the security agreement a \"bridge\" to when Ukraine is invited to join the NATO alliance -- a long-term priority of Zelenskyy's that the allies have said will first require an end to the Russia-Ukraine war and that Putin has steadfastly opposed.\n\nBiden's back-to-back trips to France and Italy amount to a rare doubleheader of diplomacy in the midst of the presidential election. The president will skip a Ukraine peace conference in Switzerland this weekend to jet to Los Angeles for a campaign fundraiser with big names from Hollywood. Vice President Kamala Harris will represent the U.S. at the conference.\n\nDespite the delays in military aid, the Biden administration on Tuesday announced it would send Ukraine another Patriot missile system to help fend off Russian strikes, two U.S. officials told The Associated Press. Biden approved the move, the officials told the AP, as Kyiv has desperately called for more air defenses in its battle against an intense Russian assault on the northeastern Kharkiv region.\n\nEarlier Wednesday, the U.S. announced fresh sanctions targeting Chinese companies that help Russia pursue its war in Ukraine, as well as Russia's financial infrastructure. Sullivan said, \"These actions will ratchet up the risk that foreign financial institutions take by dealing with Russia's war economy.\"\n\nBiden is also expected to discuss economic concerns brought on by Chinese manufacturing overcapacity, how to use artificial intelligence in a way that maximizes benefits but still manages national security risks, and global migration.\n\nThe U.S. and other G7 nations are struggling to manage large influxes of migrants arriving for complicated reasons that include war, climate change and drought. Migration, and how nations cope with the growing numbers at their borders, has been a factor driving the far-right rise in some of Europe.\n\n___\n\nSuperville reported from Bari, Italy. Miller and Madhani reported from Washington. Sylvie Corbet in Paris and Fatima Hussein and Josh Boak in Washington contributed.", "source": {"uri": "opb.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "opb"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-387653133", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "21:26:04", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T21:26:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T21:07:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/biden-and-zelenskyy-will-sign-a-security-deal-as-g7-leaders-agree-to-use-russian/article_07fb4b72-bc5f-54d9-a65e-ffb962685b42.html", "title": "Biden and Zelenskyy will sign a security deal, as G7 leaders agree to use Russian cash to help Kyiv", "body": "BRINDISI, Italy (AP) -- President Joe Biden and President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will sign a bilateral security agreement between the U.S. and Ukraine on Thursday when they meet on the sidelines of the Group of Seven summit in Italy, as negotiators for the group have reached an agreement on how to provide Ukraine with up to $50 billion backed by frozen Russian assets, two people familiar with the matter said Wednesday.\n\nThe international group of wealthy democracies has been discussing ways of using the more than $260 billion in Russian assets frozen outside the country after the Feb. 24, 2022 invasion of Ukraine to help Kyiv.\n\nEuropean officials have resisted confiscating the assets, citing legal and financial stability concerns -- most of the frozen assets are located in Europe -- but the plan would use the interest earned on the assets to help Ukraine's war effort. The two people spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss the agreement before it was formally announced.\n\nAn official with the French presidency confirmed the announcement Wednesday.\n\nThe announcement of the agreement comes as Biden heads to the summit of the world's leading democracies with an urgency to get big things done, including turning frozen Russian assets into billions of dollars to help Ukraine fight Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\nThe security arrangement was aimed to send a signal to Russia of American resolve in supporting Kyiv, the White House said as Biden was headed to Europe.\n\nNational security adviser Jake Sullivan said the security agreement would not commit U.S. troops directly to Ukraine's defense against Russia's invasion -- a red line drawn by Biden, who's fearful of being pulled into direct conflict between the nuclear-armed powers.\n\n\"We want to demonstrate that the U.S. supports the people of Ukraine, that we stand with them and that we'll continue to help address their security needs,\" Sullivan said, adding \"this agreement will show our resolve.\"\n\nThis year's meeting comes three years after Biden declared at his first such gathering that America was back as a global leader following the disruptions to Western alliances that occurred when Donald Trump was president. Now, there's a chance this gathering could be the final G7 for Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of elections this year.\n\nBiden and his counterparts from Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related to artificial intelligence, migration, the Russian military's resurgence and China's economic might, among other topics. Pope Francis, Zelenskyy and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan are joining the gathering at the Borgo Egnazia resort in the Puglia region of southern Italy.\n\nThe summit, opening Thursday, will play out after far-right parties across the continent racked up gains of surprising scale in just-concluded European Union elections. Those victories, coupled with upcoming elections in the United Kingdom, France and the United States, have rattled the global political establishment and added weightiness to this year's summit.\n\n\"You hear this a lot when you talk to U.S. and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether it's on China, whether it's on the assets, we may not have another chance,\" said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Council's GeoEconomics Center, an international affairs think tank. \"We don't know what the world will look like three months, six months, nine months from now.\"\n\nThe G7 is an informal bloc of industrialized democracies that meets annually to discuss shared issues and concerns. Biden will arrive in Italy on Wednesday night, his second trip outside the U.S. in as many weeks. The Democratic president was in France last week for a state visit in Paris and ceremonies in Normandy marking the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings in World War II.\n\nWhile last week's visit had a celebratory feel, this one will be dominated by pressing global issues, including how to keep financial support flowing to Ukraine as it fights Russia's invasion. Biden's trip comes a day after his son Hunter was convicted on federal gun charges, a blow sure to weigh heavily on the president's mind.\n\nDespite pressing global challenges, White House national security spokesman John Kirby said there's still a sense of relief among world leaders in 2024 that \"America was back,\" referencing Biden's 2021 speech at the G7 in England.\n\n\"Biden's message then was that democracies need to step up and show they can deliver for their people,\" Kirby said. \"That's true now more than ever.\"\n\nKirby said the U.S. was prepared to work with democratically elected officials in the EU no matter who they are, though some of those being elevated have expressed far less support for Ukraine than current leaders.\n\n\"We have every confidence that regardless of who fills the seats in the European Parliament, we're going to continue to work closely with our EU partners on all the issues relative to our shared interests across the European continent,\" Kirby said. \"That includes supporting Ukraine.\"\n\nBiden and Zelenskyy, who met last week in Paris, will meet again to discuss continued support for the Eastern European nation, which is trying to fend off an intense Russian offensive in eastern areas of the country. They're expected to hold a joint news conference. Biden is also expected to meet with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, the pope and other leaders.\n\nBiden, who's been adamant \"we will not walk away\" from Ukraine, last week publicly apologized to Zelenskyy for a monthslong delay by Congress in authorizing additional American military assistance. The delay allowed Russia to make gains on the battlefield.\n\nSullivan called the security agreement a \"bridge\" to when Ukraine is invited to join the NATO alliance -- a long-term priority of Zelenskyy's that the allies have said will first require an end to the Russia-Ukraine war and that Putin has steadfastly opposed.\n\nBiden's back-to-back trips to France and Italy amount to a rare doubleheader of diplomacy in the midst of the presidential election. The president will skip a Ukraine peace conference in Switzerland this weekend to jet to Los Angeles for a campaign fundraiser with big names from Hollywood. Vice President Kamala Harris will represent the U.S. at the conference.\n\nDespite the delays in military aid, the Biden administration on Tuesday announced it would send Ukraine another Patriot missile system to help fend off Russian strikes, two U.S. officials told The Associated Press. Biden approved the move, the officials told the AP, as Kyiv has desperately called for more air defenses in its battle against an intense Russian assault on the northeastern Kharkiv region.\n\nEarlier Wednesday, the U.S. announced fresh sanctions targeting Chinese companies that help Russia pursue its war in Ukraine, as well as Russia's financial infrastructure. Sullivan said, \"These actions will ratchet up the risk that foreign financial institutions take by dealing with Russia's war economy.\"\n\nA European plan to specifically use the interest on the Russian funds would provide only a trickle of money every year -- about $2.5 billion to $3 billion at current interest rates, which would barely meet a month's financing needs for the Ukrainian government.\n\nWhite House national security adviser Jake Sullivan said aboard Air Force One that the goal of the financing plan was to have a loan that would \"pull forward the windfall profits from the seized assets\" of Russia, giving Ukraine a \"substantial source of funding\" to meet its immediate needs.\n\nSullivan said he had a specific sum of money in mind, but declined to say if that figure was $50 billion. He stressed the urgency of getting Ukraine financial resources as soon as possible and that multiple countries would back the agreement.\n\n\"It's to provide the necessary resources to Ukraine now for its economic energy and other needs, so that it's capable of having the resilience necessary to withstand Russia's continuing aggression,\" Sullivan said.\n\nTreasury Secretary Janet Yellen said recently that G7 finance ministers have been discussing the possibility of extending a loan to Ukraine and using the windfall profits of assets seized in Europe to pay it off.\n\nKirby said the U.S. was optimistic the group could agree on the matter.\n\nBiden is also expected to discuss economic concerns brought on by Chinese manufacturing overcapacity, how to use artificial intelligence in a way that maximizes benefits but still manages national security risks, and global migration.\n\nThe U.S. and other G7 nations are struggling to manage large influxes of migrants arriving for complicated reasons that include war, climate change and drought. Migration, and how nations cope with the growing numbers at their borders, has been a factor driving the far-right rise in some of Europe.\n\nSuperville reported from Bari, Italy. Miller and Madhani reported from Washington. Angela Charlton in Paris and Fatima Hussein and Josh Boak in Washington contributed.", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Beckley Register-Herald"}, "authors": {"uri": "8174969746", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "21:42:23", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T21:42:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T21:39:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/biden-and-zelenskyy-will-sign-a-security-deal-as-g7-leaders-agree-to-use-russian/article_b052be6b-ecb0-55df-a4e5-1c18dbf91417.html", "title": "Biden and Zelenskyy will sign a security deal, as G7 leaders agree to use Russian cash to help Kyiv", "body": "President Joe Biden is escorted by Air Force Col. Angela Ochoa, Commander, 89th Airlift Wing, as he arrives at Andrews Air Force Base, Md., Wednesday, June 12, 2024. Biden is headed to Italy for the G7 summit. Biden's granddaughter, Finnegan Biden, walks left.\n\nBRINDISI, Italy (AP) -- President Joe Biden and President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will sign a bilateral security agreement between the U.S. and Ukraine on Thursday when they meet on the sidelines of the Group of Seven summit in Italy, as negotiators for the group have reached an agreement on how to provide Ukraine with up to $50 billion backed by frozen Russian assets, two people familiar with the matter said Wednesday.\n\nThe international group of wealthy democracies has been discussing ways of using the more than $260 billion in Russian assets frozen outside the country after the Feb. 24, 2022 invasion of Ukraine to help Kyiv.\n\nEuropean officials have resisted confiscating the assets, citing legal and financial stability concerns -- most of the frozen assets are located in Europe -- but the plan would use the interest earned on the assets to help Ukraine's war effort. The two people spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss the agreement before it was formally announced.\n\nAn official with the French presidency confirmed the announcement Wednesday.\n\nThe announcement of the agreement comes as Biden heads to the summit of the world's leading democracies with an urgency to get big things done, including turning frozen Russian assets into billions of dollars to help Ukraine fight Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\nThe security arrangement was aimed to send a signal to Russia of American resolve in supporting Kyiv, the White House said as Biden was headed to Europe.\n\nNational security adviser Jake Sullivan said the security agreement would not commit U.S. troops directly to Ukraine's defense against Russia's invasion -- a red line drawn by Biden, who's fearful of being pulled into direct conflict between the nuclear-armed powers.\n\n\"We want to demonstrate that the U.S. supports the people of Ukraine, that we stand with them and that we'll continue to help address their security needs,\" Sullivan said, adding \"this agreement will show our resolve.\"\n\nThis year's meeting comes three years after Biden declared at his first such gathering that America was back as a global leader following the disruptions to Western alliances that occurred when Donald Trump was president. Now, there's a chance this gathering could be the final G7 for Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of elections this year.\n\nBiden and his counterparts from Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related to artificial intelligence, migration, the Russian military's resurgence and China's economic might, among other topics. Pope Francis, Zelenskyy and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan are joining the gathering at the Borgo Egnazia resort in the Puglia region of southern Italy.\n\nThe summit, opening Thursday, will play out after far-right parties across the continent racked up gains of surprising scale in just-concluded European Union elections. Those victories, coupled with upcoming elections in the United Kingdom, France and the United States, have rattled the global political establishment and added weightiness to this year's summit.\n\n\"You hear this a lot when you talk to U.S. and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether it's on China, whether it's on the assets, we may not have another chance,\" said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Council's GeoEconomics Center, an international affairs think tank. \"We don't know what the world will look like three months, six months, nine months from now.\"\n\nThe G7 is an informal bloc of industrialized democracies that meets annually to discuss shared issues and concerns. Biden will arrive in Italy on Wednesday night, his second trip outside the U.S. in as many weeks. The Democratic president was in France last week for a state visit in Paris and ceremonies in Normandy marking the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings in World War II.\n\nWhile last week's visit had a celebratory feel, this one will be dominated by pressing global issues, including how to keep financial support flowing to Ukraine as it fights Russia's invasion. Biden's trip comes a day after his son Hunter was convicted on federal gun charges, a blow sure to weigh heavily on the president's mind.\n\nDespite pressing global challenges, White House national security spokesman John Kirby said there's still a sense of relief among world leaders in 2024 that \"America was back,\" referencing Biden's 2021 speech at the G7 in England.\n\n\"Biden's message then was that democracies need to step up and show they can deliver for their people,\" Kirby said. \"That's true now more than ever.\"\n\nKirby said the U.S. was prepared to work with democratically elected officials in the EU no matter who they are, though some of those being elevated have expressed far less support for Ukraine than current leaders.\n\n\"We have every confidence that regardless of who fills the seats in the European Parliament, we're going to continue to work closely with our EU partners on all the issues relative to our shared interests across the European continent,\" Kirby said. \"That includes supporting Ukraine.\"\n\nBiden and Zelenskyy, who met last week in Paris, will meet again to discuss continued support for the Eastern European nation, which is trying to fend off an intense Russian offensive in eastern areas of the country. They're expected to hold a joint news conference. Biden is also expected to meet with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, the pope and other leaders.\n\nBiden, who's been adamant \"we will not walk away\" from Ukraine, last week publicly apologized to Zelenskyy for a monthslong delay by Congress in authorizing additional American military assistance. The delay allowed Russia to make gains on the battlefield.\n\nSullivan called the security agreement a \"bridge\" to when Ukraine is invited to join the NATO alliance -- a long-term priority of Zelenskyy's that the allies have said will first require an end to the Russia-Ukraine war and that Putin has steadfastly opposed.\n\nBiden's back-to-back trips to France and Italy amount to a rare doubleheader of diplomacy in the midst of the presidential election. The president will skip a Ukraine peace conference in Switzerland this weekend to jet to Los Angeles for a campaign fundraiser with big names from Hollywood. Vice President Kamala Harris will represent the U.S. at the conference.\n\nDespite the delays in military aid, the Biden administration on Tuesday announced it would send Ukraine another Patriot missile system to help fend off Russian strikes, two U.S. officials told The Associated Press. Biden approved the move, the officials told the AP, as Kyiv has desperately called for more air defenses in its battle against an intense Russian assault on the northeastern Kharkiv region.\n\nEarlier Wednesday, the U.S. announced fresh sanctions targeting Chinese companies that help Russia pursue its war in Ukraine, as well as Russia's financial infrastructure. Sullivan said, \"These actions will ratchet up the risk that foreign financial institutions take by dealing with Russia's war economy.\"\n\nA European plan to specifically use the interest on the Russian funds would provide only a trickle of money every year -- about $2.5 billion to $3 billion at current interest rates, which would barely meet a month's financing needs for the Ukrainian government.\n\nWhite House national security adviser Jake Sullivan said aboard Air Force One that the goal of the financing plan was to have a loan that would \"pull forward the windfall profits from the seized assets\" of Russia, giving Ukraine a \"substantial source of funding\" to meet its immediate needs.\n\nSullivan said he had a specific sum of money in mind, but declined to say if that figure was $50 billion. He stressed the urgency of getting Ukraine financial resources as soon as possible and that multiple countries would back the agreement.\n\n\"It's to provide the necessary resources to Ukraine now for its economic energy and other needs, so that it's capable of having the resilience necessary to withstand Russia's continuing aggression,\" Sullivan said.\n\nTreasury Secretary Janet Yellen said recently that G7 finance ministers have been discussing the possibility of extending a loan to Ukraine and using the windfall profits of assets seized in Europe to pay it off.\n\nKirby said the U.S. was optimistic the group could agree on the matter.\n\nBiden is also expected to discuss economic concerns brought on by Chinese manufacturing overcapacity, how to use artificial intelligence in a way that maximizes benefits but still manages national security risks, and global migration.\n\nThe U.S. and other G7 nations are struggling to manage large influxes of migrants arriving for complicated reasons that include war, climate change and drought. Migration, and how nations cope with the growing numbers at their borders, has been a factor driving the far-right rise in some of Europe.\n\nSuperville reported from Bari, Italy. Miller and Madhani reported from Washington. {"uri": "8175302190", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "04:23:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T04:23:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T04:18:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/politics/2742006/", "title": "Biden, Zelensky to sign security deal, as G7 leaders agree to use Russian money to help kyiv - ExBulletin", "body": "WASHINGTON President Joe Biden and President Volodymyr Zelensky will sign a bilateral security agreement between the United States and Ukraine on Thursday when they meet on the sidelines of the Group of Seven summit in Italy, as the group's negotiators reached an agreement on how to provide Ukraine with up to $50 billion backed by frozen Russian assets.\n\nThe international group of wealthy democracies discusses ways to use the more than $260 billion in Russian assets frozen outside the country after the invasion of February 24, 2022 from Ukraine to help Kyiv.\n\nEuropean officials have resisted asset confiscation, citing legal and financial stability concerns. Most of the frozen assets are located in Europe, but the plan would use interest earned on the assets to help Ukraine's war effort. A French presidency official confirmed the deal on Wednesday, saying most of the money would flow to Ukraine in the form of a US government loan backed by proceeds from frozen Russian assets in the bloc. European. Two other people familiar with the matter confirmed the deal.\n\nFinal technical negotiations were underway before the summit to finalize the legal terms of the agreement.\n\nDeal announcement comes as Biden lands in Italy to attend the summit of the world's main democracies with the urgency to accomplish great things, in particular to transform Russian assets frozen in billions of dollars to help Ukraine fight Russian President Vladimir Putin war machine.\n\nThe security deal was aimed at sending Russia a signal of US determination to support kyiv, the White House said as Biden headed to Europe.\n\nNational security adviser Jake Sullivan said the security deal would not commit U.S. troops directly to defending Ukraine against Russian invasion, a red line drawn by Biden, who fears be drawn into direct conflict between nuclear powers.\n\nWe want to demonstrate that the United States supports the Ukrainian people, that we stand with them and continue to help meet their security needs, Sullivan said, adding that \"this agreement will show our resolve.\"\n\nSullivan said aboard Air Force One that the goal of the financing plan was to secure a loan that would recoup windfall profits from assets seized by Russia, giving Ukraine a substantial source of financing to meet their immediate needs.\n\nThe national security adviser said he had a specific amount of money in mind, but declined to say whether that figure was $50 billion. He stressed the urgency of obtaining financial resources for Ukraine as quickly as possible and that several countries would support the agreement.\n\nThis is about providing Ukraine with the resources needed now for its economic energy and other needs, so that it is able to have the resilience to resist Russia's continued aggression, Sullivan said .\n\nThis year's meeting comes three years after Biden declared in his first such meeting that America was back as a world leader following disruptions to Western alliances that occurred when Donald Trump was president. It is now possible that this gathering could be the last G7 for Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of this year's elections.\n\nBiden and his counterparts from Canada, the United Kingdom, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related to artificial intelligence, migration, the resurgence of the Russian army and the economic power of China, among other subjects. Pope Francis, Zelensky and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan join the gathering at the seaside resort of Borgo Egnazia in southern Italy's Puglia region.\n\nThe summit, which opens on Thursday, will come after far-right parties across the continent racked up gains of surprising magnitude at the just-concluded summit. European Union elections. These victories, coupled with the upcoming elections to United Kingdom, France and the UNITED STATES have shaken the global political establishment and added weight to this year's summit.\n\nYou hear this a lot when talking to U.S. and European officials: If we can't get it done now, whether on China or on assets, we may not get another chance, said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Councils GeoEconomics Center, an international affairs think tank. We don't know what the world will look like in three months, six months, nine months. \"\n\nThe G7 is an informal bloc of industrialized democracies that meets annually to discuss common issues and concerns. Biden will arrive in Italy on Wednesday evening, his second trip outside the United States in as many weeks. The Democratic president was in France last week to a state visit in Paris and marking ceremonies in Normandy the 80th anniversary of the Landing during WWII.\n\nAlthough last week's visit was celebratory, it will be dominated by pressing global issues, including how to maintain financial support for Ukraine as it struggles. Invasion of Russia. Biden's trip comes a day after his son Hunter's departure convicted of federal gun chargesa hard blow that will certainly weigh heavily on the president's mind.\n\nDespite pressing global challenges, White House national security spokesman John Kirby said there is still a sense of relief among world leaders in 2024 because \"America was back\" SEO Biden's speech in 2021 at the G7 in England.\n\nBiden's message then was that democracies must step up and show they can meet the expectations of their people, Kirby said. This is more true than ever.\n\nKirby said the United States is willing to work with democratically elected officials in the EU, whoever they may be, even if some of those who have been promoted have expressed far less support for Ukraine than current leaders.\n\n\"We are confident that, whoever takes the seats in the European Parliament, we will continue to work closely with our EU partners on all issues relating to our common interests across the European continent,\" said Kirby. \"This includes support for Ukraine.\n\nBiden and Zelenskyy, who met last week in Pariswill meet again to discuss continued support for the Eastern European nation as it attempts to fend off an intense crisis. Russian offensive in the eastern regions of the country. They are expected to hold a joint press conference. Biden is also expected to meet Giorgia Meloni, Italian Prime Ministerthe pope and other leaders.\n\nBiden, who insisted we would not leave Ukraine, last week publicly apologized to Zelensky of Congress' months-long delay in authorizing additional U.S. military aid. This delay allowed Russia to battlefield gains.\n\nSullivan called the security deal a bridge to when Ukraine will be invited to join the NATO alliance, a long-term priority of Zelensky's that allies say will first require ending the Russian-Ukrainian war and that Putin strongly opposed.\n\nBiden's back-to-back trips to France and Italy constitute a rare diplomatic double bill in the middle of the presidential election. The president will jump a Ukraine Peace Conference in Switzerland this weekend to fly to Los Angeles for a fundraising campaign with big names from Hollywood. Vice President Kamala Harris will represent the United States at the conference.\n\nDespite delays in providing military aid, the Biden administration announced Tuesday that it would do so. send Ukraine another Patriot missile system to help repel Russian strikes, two U.S. officials told The Associated Press. Biden approved the move, the officials told the AP, as kyiv has desperately called for more air defenses in its fight against an intense Russian attack on the northeastern Kharkiv region.\n\nEarlier Wednesday, the U.S. announced new sanctions targeting Chinese companies that are helping Russia continue its war in Ukraine, as well as Russian financial infrastructure. Sullivan said: \"These actions will increase the risk foreign financial institutions take in dealing with the Russian war economy.\n\nBiden is also expected to discuss economic concerns caused by Chinese manufacturing overcapacity, how to use artificial intelligence in ways that maximize profits while managing national security risks, and global migration.\n\nThe United States and other G7 countries are struggling to manage massive influxes of migrants arriving for complex reasons such as war, climate change and drought. Migration and how countries deal with the growing number of people at their borders has been a factor in the rise of the far right in certain regions of Europe.\n\n___\n\nSuperville reported from Bari, Italy. Miller and Madhani reported from Washington. {"uri": "2024-06-387810890", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "03:00:27", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T03:00:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T02:48:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.republicworld.com/india/biden-and-zelenskyy-will-sign-a-security-deal-as-g7-leaders-agree-to-use-russian-cash-to-help-kyiv", "title": "Biden and Zelenskyy Will Sign a Security Deal, as G7 Leaders Agree to Use Russian Cash to Help Kyiv", "body": "Brindisi: President Joe Biden and President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will sign a bilateral security agreement between the US and Ukraine on Thursday when they meet on the sidelines of the Group of Seven summit in Italy, as negotiators for the group have reached an agreement on how to provide Ukraine with up to USD 50 billion backed by frozen Russian assets, two people familiar with the matter said Wednesday.\n\nThe international group of wealthy democracies has been discussing ways of using the more than USD 260 billion in Russian assets frozen outside the country after the February 24, 2022 invasion of Ukraine to help Kyiv.\n\nEuropean officials have resisted confiscating the assets, citing legal and financial stability concerns -- most of the frozen assets are located in Europe -- but the plan would use the interest earned on the assets to help Ukraine's war effort. The two people spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss the agreement before it was formally announced.\n\nAn official with the French presidency confirmed the announcement Wednesday.\n\nThe announcement of the agreement comes as Biden heads to the summit of the world's leading democracies with an urgency to get big things done, including turning frozen Russian assets into billions of dollars to help Ukraine fight Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\nThe security arrangement was aimed to send a signal to Russia of American resolve in supporting Kyiv, the White House said as Biden was headed to Europe.\n\nNational security adviser Jake Sullivan said the security agreement would not commit US troops directly to Ukraine's defense against Russia's invasion -- a red line drawn by Biden, who's fearful of being pulled into direct conflict between the nuclear-armed powers.\n\n\"We want to demonstrate that the US supports the people of Ukraine, that we stand with them and that we'll continue to help address their security needs,\" Sullivan said, adding \"this agreement will show our resolve.\" This year's meeting comes three years after Biden declared at his first such gathering that America was back as a global leader following the disruptions to Western alliances that occurred when Donald Trump was president. Now, there's a chance this gathering could be the final G7 for Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of elections this year.\n\nBiden and his counterparts from Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related to artificial intelligence, migration, the Russian military's resurgence and China's economic might, among other topics. Pope Francis, Zelenskyy and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan are joining the gathering at the Borgo Egnazia resort in the Puglia region of southern Italy.\n\nThe summit, opening Thursday, will play out after far-right parties across the continent racked up gains of surprising scale in just-concluded European Union elections. Those victories, coupled with upcoming elections in the United Kingdom, France and the United States, have rattled the global political establishment and added weightiness to this year's summit.\n\n\"You hear this a lot when you talk to US and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether it's on China, whether it's on the assets, we may not have another chance,\" said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Council's GeoEconomics Center, an international affairs think tank. \"We don't know what the world will look like three months, six months, nine months from now.\" The G7 is an informal bloc of industrialized democracies that meets annually to discuss shared issues and concerns. Biden will arrive in Italy on Wednesday night, his second trip outside the U.S. in as many weeks. The Democratic president was in France last week for a state visit in Paris and ceremonies in Normandy marking the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings in World War II.\n\nWhile last week's visit had a celebratory feel, this one will be dominated by pressing global issues, including how to keep financial support flowing to Ukraine as it fights Russia's invasion. Biden's trip comes a day after his son Hunter was convicted on federal gun charges, a blow sure to weigh heavily on the president's mind.\n\nDespite pressing global challenges, White House national security spokesman John Kirby said there's still a sense of relief among world leaders in 2024 that \"America was back,\" referencing Biden's 2021 speech at the G7 in England.\n\n\"Biden's message then was that democracies need to step up and show they can deliver for their people,\" Kirby said. \"That's true now more than ever.\" Kirby said the U.S. was prepared to work with democratically elected officials in the EU no matter who they are, though some of those being elevated have expressed far less support for Ukraine than current leaders.\n\n\"We have every confidence that regardless of who fills the seats in the European Parliament, we're going to continue to work closely with our EU partners on all the issues relative to our shared interests across the European continent,\" Kirby said. \"That includes supporting Ukraine.\" Biden and Zelenskyy, who met last week in Paris, will meet again to discuss continued support for the Eastern European nation, which is trying to fend off an intense Russian offensive in eastern areas of the country. They're expected to hold a joint news conference. Biden is also expected to meet with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, the pope and other leaders.\n\nBiden, who's been adamant \"we will not walk away\" from Ukraine, last week publicly apologized to Zelenskyy for a month-long delay by Congress in authorizing additional American military assistance. The delay allowed Russia to make gains on the battlefield.\n\nSullivan called the security agreement a \"bridge\" to when Ukraine is invited to join the NATO alliance -- a long-term priority of Zelenskyy's that the allies have said will first require an end to the Russia-Ukraine war and that Putin has steadfastly opposed.\n\nBiden's back-to-back trips to France and Italy amount to a rare doubleheader of diplomacy in the midst of the presidential election. The president will skip a Ukraine peace conference in Switzerland this weekend to jet to Los Angeles for a campaign fundraiser with big names from Hollywood. Vice President Kamala Harris will represent the US at the conference.\n\nDespite the delays in military aid, the Biden administration on Tuesday announced it would send Ukraine another Patriot missile system to help fend off Russian strikes, two US officials told The Associated Press. Biden approved the move, the officials told the AP, as Kyiv has desperately called for more air defences in its battle against an intense Russian assault on the northeastern Kharkiv region.\n\nEarlier Wednesday, the US announced fresh sanctions targeting Chinese companies that help Russia pursue its war in Ukraine, as well as Russia's financial infrastructure. Sullivan said, \"These actions will ratchet up the risk that foreign financial institutions take by dealing with Russia's war economy.\" A European plan to specifically use the interest on the Russian funds would provide only a trickle of money every year -- about USD 2.5 billion to USD 3 billion at current interest rates, which would barely meet a month's financing needs for the Ukrainian government.\n\nWhite House national security adviser Jake Sullivan said aboard Air Force One that the goal of the financing plan was to have a loan that would \"pull forward the windfall profits from the seized assets\" of Russia, giving Ukraine a \"substantial source of funding\" to meet its immediate needs.\n\nSullivan said he had a specific sum of money in mind, but declined to say if that figure was USD 50 billion. He stressed the urgency of getting Ukraine financial resources as soon as possible and that multiple countries would back the agreement.\n\n\"It's to provide the necessary resources to Ukraine now for its economic energy and other needs, so that it's capable of having the resilience necessary to withstand Russia's continuing aggression,\" Sullivan said.\n\nTreasury Secretary Janet Yellen said recently that G7 finance ministers have been discussing the possibility of extending a loan to Ukraine and using the windfall profits of assets seized in Europe to pay it off.\n\nKirby said the USD was optimistic the group could agree on the matter.\n\nBiden is also expected to discuss economic concerns brought on by Chinese manufacturing overcapacity, how to use artificial intelligence in a way that maximizes benefits but still manages national security risks, and global migration.\n\nThe U.S. and other G7 nations are struggling to manage large influxes of migrants arriving for complicated reasons that include war, climate change and drought. Migration, and how nations cope with the growing numbers at their borders, has been a factor driving the far-right rise in some of Europe.", "source": {"uri": "republicworld.com", "dataType": "news",
