{"uri": "8175070901", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "23:43:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T23:43:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T23:41:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/politics/2741743/", "title": "Biden, Zelensky to sign security deal, as G7 leaders agree to use Russian money to help kyiv - WSVN 7News | Miami News, Weather, Sports - ExBulletin", "body": "BRINDISI, Italy (AP) President Joe Biden and President Volodymyr Zelensky will sign a bilateral security agreement between the United States and Ukraine on Thursday when they meet on the sidelines of the Group of Seven summit in Italy, as the The group's negotiators reached an agreement. on how to provide Ukraine with up to $50 billion backed by frozen Russian assets.\n\nThe international group of wealthy democracies is discussing ways to use the more than $260 billion in Russian assets frozen outside the country after the Feb. 24, 2022, invasion of Ukraine to help Kyiv.\n\nEuropean officials have resisted asset confiscation, citing legal and financial stability concerns. Most of the frozen assets are located in Europe, but the plan would use interest earned on the assets to help Ukraine's war effort. A French presidency official confirmed the deal on Wednesday, saying most of the money would flow to Ukraine in the form of a US government loan backed by proceeds from frozen Russian assets in the bloc. European. Two other people familiar with the matter confirmed the deal.\n\nFinal technical negotiations were underway before the summit to finalize the legal terms of the agreement.\n\nThe announcement of the deal comes as Biden lands in Italy to attend the summit of the world's leading democracies with an urgency to do big things, including turning frozen Russian assets into billions of dollars to help Ukraine fight Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\nThe security deal was aimed at sending Russia a signal of US determination to support kyiv, the White House said as Biden headed to Europe.\n\nNational security adviser Jake Sullivan said the security deal would not commit U.S. troops directly to defending Ukraine against Russian invasion, a red line drawn by Biden, who fears be drawn into direct conflict between nuclear powers.\n\nWe want to demonstrate that the United States supports the Ukrainian people, that we stand with them and that we continue to help meet their security needs, Sullivan said, adding that this agreement would show our resolve.\n\nSullivan said aboard Air Force One that the goal of the financing plan was to secure a loan that would recoup windfall profits from assets seized by Russia, giving Ukraine a substantial source of financing to meet their immediate needs.\n\nThe national security adviser said he had a specific amount of money in mind, but declined to say whether that figure was $50 billion. He stressed the urgency of obtaining financial resources for Ukraine as quickly as possible and that several countries would support the agreement.\n\nThis is about providing Ukraine with the resources needed now for its economic energy and other needs, so that it is able to have the resilience to resist Russia's continued aggression, Sullivan said .\n\nThis year's meeting comes three years after Biden declared in his first such meeting that America was back as a world leader following the disruptions to Western alliances that occurred when Donald Trump was president. It is now possible that this gathering could be the last G7 for Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of this year's elections.\n\nBiden and his counterparts from Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related to artificial intelligence, migration, resurgence of the military Russian and the economic power of China, among other subjects. Pope Francis, Zelensky and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan join the gathering at the seaside resort of Borgo Egnazia in southern Italy's Puglia region.\n\nThe summit, which opens on Thursday, comes after the continent's far-right parties racked up surprisingly large gains in just-concluded European elections. These victories, coupled with upcoming elections in the United Kingdom, France and the United States, have shaken the global political establishment and added weight to this year's summit.\n\nYou hear this a lot when you talk to U.S. and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether on China or on assets, we may not get another chance, Josh Lipsky said , senior director of the Atlantic Councils. GeoEconomics Center, an international affairs think tank. We don't know what the world will look like in three months, six months, nine months.\n\nThe G7 is an informal bloc of industrialized democracies that meets annually to discuss common issues and concerns. Biden will arrive in Italy on Wednesday evening, his second trip outside the United States in as many weeks. The Democratic president was in France last week for a state visit to Paris and ceremonies in Normandy marking the 80th anniversary of the World War II landings.\n\nWhile last week's visit had a celebratory character, this one will be dominated by pressing global issues, including how to maintain financial support for Ukraine as it fights the Russian invasion. Biden's trip comes a day after his son Hunter was convicted of federal gun-related charges, a blow that is sure to weigh heavily on the president's mind.\n\nDespite pressing global challenges, White House national security spokesman John Kirby said there is still a sense of relief among world leaders in 2024 that America is back, referring to at Biden's 2021 G7 speech in England.\n\nBiden's message then was that democracies must step up and show they can meet the expectations of their people, Kirby said. This is more true than ever.\n\nKirby said the United States is willing to work with democratically elected officials in the EU, whoever they may be, even if some of those who have been promoted have expressed far less support for Ukraine than current leaders.\n\nWe are confident that whoever takes the seats in the European Parliament, we will continue to work closely with our EU partners on all issues relating to our common interests across the European continent, Kirby said. This includes support for Ukraine.\n\nBiden and Zelensky, who met last week in Paris, will meet again to discuss continued support for the Eastern European nation, which is trying to repel an intense Russian offensive in the country's eastern regions. They are expected to hold a joint press conference. Biden is also expected to meet with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, the pope and other leaders.\n\nBiden, who insisted we would not leave Ukraine, last week publicly apologized to Zelensky for Congress' months-long delay in authorizing additional U.S. military aid. This delay allowed Russia to make gains on the battlefield.\n\nSullivan called the security deal a bridge to when Ukraine will be invited to join the NATO alliance, a long-term priority of Zelenskyy's that allies say will first require ending the Russian-Ukrainian war and which Putin strongly opposed.\n\nBiden's back-to-back trips to France and Italy constitute a rare diplomatic double bill in the midst of a presidential election. The president will skip a Ukraine peace conference in Switzerland this weekend and will fly to Los Angeles for a fundraising campaign with big Hollywood names. Vice President Kamala Harris will represent the United States at the conference.\n\nDespite delays in military aid, the Biden administration announced Tuesday that it will send Ukraine another Patriot missile system to help it repel Russian strikes, two U.S. officials told The Associated Press . Biden approved the move, the officials told the AP, as kyiv has desperately called for more air defenses in its fight against an intense Russian attack on the northeastern Kharkiv region.\n\nEarlier on Wednesday, the United States announced new sanctions targeting Chinese companies that help Russia pursue its war in Ukraine, as well as Russian financial infrastructure. Sullivan said: \"These actions will increase the risk foreign financial institutions take in dealing with the Russian war economy.\n\nBiden is also expected to discuss economic concerns caused by Chinese manufacturing overcapacity, how to use artificial intelligence in ways that maximize profits while managing national security risks, and global migration.\n\nThe United States and other G7 countries are struggling to manage massive influxes of migrants arriving for complex reasons such as war, climate change and drought. {"uri": "8175362324", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "05:17:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T05:17:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T05:16:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://english.metrovaartha.com/news/international/biden-and-zelenskyy-will-sign-a-security-deal-as-g7-leaders-agree-to-use-russian-cash-to-help-kyiv", "title": "Biden and Zelenskyy will sign a security deal, as G7 leaders agree to use Russian cash to help Kyiv", "body": "Brindisi (Italy) | President Joe Biden and President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will sign a bilateral security agreement between the US and Ukraine on Thursday when they meet on the sidelines of the Group of Seven summit in Italy.\n\nNegotiators for the group have also reached an agreement on how to provide Ukraine with up to $50 billion backed by frozen Russian assets.\n\nThe international group of wealthy democracies has been discussing ways of using the more than $260 billion in frozen Russian assets, most of which are outside the country, to help Ukraine fight Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\nEuropean officials have resisted confiscating the assets, citing legal and financial stability concerns, but the plan would use the interest earned on the assets to help Ukraine's war effort. An official with the French presidency confirmed the agreement Wednesday, saying most of the money would be flowing to Ukraine in the form of a loan from the U.S. government backed by the proceeds of the frozen Russian assets in the European Union. Two other people familiar with the matter confirmed the arrangement.\n\nFinal technical negotiations were underway ahead of the summit to finalize the legal terms of the deal.\n\nThe announcement of the agreement comes as Biden landed in Italy with an urgency to get big things done. Thursday's security arrangement was aimed to send a signal to Russia of American resolve in supporting Kyiv, the White House said.\n\nNational security adviser Jake Sullivan said the security agreement would not commit U.S. troops directly to Ukraine's defense against Russia's invasion - a red line drawn by Biden, who's fearful of being pulled into direct conflict between the nuclear-armed powers.\n\n\"We want to demonstrate that the U.S. supports the people of Ukraine, that we stand with them and that we'll continue to help address their security needs,\" Sullivan said, adding \"this agreement will show our resolve.\" Sullivan said aboard Air Force One that the goal of the financing plan was to have a loan that would \"pull forward the windfall profits from the seized assets\" of Russia, giving Ukraine a \"substantial source of funding\" to meet its immediate needs.\n\nThe national security adviser said he had a specific sum of money in mind, but declined to say if that figure was $50 billion. He stressed the urgency of getting Ukraine financial resources as soon as possible and that multiple countries would back the agreement.\n\n\"It's to provide the necessary resources to Ukraine now for its economic energy and other needs, so that it's capable of having the resilience necessary to withstand Russia's continuing aggression,\" Sullivan said.\n\nThis year's meeting comes three years after Biden declared at his first such gathering that America was back as a global leader following the disruptions to Western alliances that occurred when Donald Trump was president. Now, there's a chance this gathering could be the final summit for Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of elections this year.\n\nBiden and his counterparts from Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related to artificial intelligence, migration, the Russian military's resurgence and China's economic might, among other topics. Pope Francis, Zelenskyy and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan are joining the gathering at the Borgo Egnazia resort in the Puglia region of southern Italy.\n\nThe summit, which opened Thursday, will play out after far-right parties across the continent racked up gains of surprising scale in just-concluded European Union elections. Those victories - coupled with upcoming elections in the United Kingdom, France and the United States - have rattled the global political establishment and added weightiness to this year's summit.\n\n\"You hear this a lot when you talk to U.S. and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether it's on China, whether it's on the assets, we may not have another chance,\" said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Council's GeoEconomics Center, an international affairs think tank. \"We don't know what the world will look like three months, six months, nine months from now.\" The G7 is an informal bloc of industrialized democracies that meets annually to discuss shared issues and concerns. This is Biden's second trip outside the U.S. in as many weeks; the Democratic president was in France last week for a state visit in Paris and ceremonies in Normandy marking the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings in World War II.\n\nWhile last week's visit had a celebratory feel, this one will be dominated by pressing global issues, including how to keep financial support flowing to Ukraine as it fights Russia's invasion. Biden's trip comes days after his son Hunter was convicted on federal gun charges, a blow sure to weigh heavily on the president's mind.\n\nDespite pressing global challenges, White House national security spokesman John Kirby said there's still a sense of relief among world leaders in 2024 that \"America was back,\" referencing Biden's 2021 speech at the G7 in England.\n\n\"Biden's message then was that democracies need to step up and show they can deliver for their people,\" Kirby said. \"That's true now more than ever.\" Kirby said the U.S. was prepared to work with democratically elected officials in the EU no matter who they are, though some of those being elevated have expressed far less support for Ukraine than current leaders.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-387679269", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "22:12:07", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T22:12:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T22:05:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://indianexpress.com/article/world/biden-and-zelenskyy-will-sign-a-security-deal-as-g7-leaders-agree-to-use-russian-cash-to-help-kyiv-9389111/", "title": "Biden and Zelenskyy will sign a security deal, as G7 leaders agree to use Russian cash to help Kyiv | World News - The Indian Express", "body": "The security arrangement was aimed to send a signal to Russia of American resolve in supporting Kyiv, the White House said as Biden was headed to Europe.\n\nPresident Joe Biden and President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will sign a bilateral security agreement between the US and Ukraine on Thursday when they meet on the sidelines of the Group of Seven summit in Italy, as negotiators for the group have reached an agreement on how to provide Ukraine with up to $50 billion backed by frozen Russian assets, two people familiar with the matter said Wednesday.\n\nThe international group of wealthy democracies has been discussing ways of using the more than $260 billion in Russian assets frozen outside the country after the February. 24, 2022 invasion of Ukraine to help Kyiv.\n\nEuropean officials have resisted confiscating the assets, citing legal and financial stability concerns most of the frozen assets are located in Europe but the plan would use the interest earned on the assets to help Ukraine's war effort.\n\nThe two people spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss the agreement before it was formally announced. An official with the French presidency confirmed the announcement Wednesday.\n\nThe announcement of the agreement comes as Biden heads to the summit of the world's leading democracies with an urgency to get big things done, including turning frozen Russian assets into billions of dollars to help Ukraine fight Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\nThe security arrangement was aimed to send a signal to Russia of American resolve in supporting Kyiv, the White House said as Biden was headed to Europe.\n\nNational security adviser Jake Sullivan said the security agreement would not commit US troops directly to Ukraine's defense against Russia's invasion a red line drawn by Biden, who's fearful of being pulled into direct conflict between the nuclear-armed powers.\n\n\"We want to demonstrate that the US supports the people of Ukraine, that we stand with them and that we'll continue to help address their security needs,\" Sullivan said, adding \"this agreement will show our resolve.\"\n\nThis year's meeting comes three years after Biden declared at his first such gathering that America was back as a global leader following the disruptions to Western alliances that occurred when Donald Trump was president.\n\nNow, there's a chance this gathering could be the final G7 for Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of elections this year.\n\nBiden and his counterparts from Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related to artificial intelligence, migration, the Russian military's resurgence and China's economic might, among other topics.\n\nPope Francis, Zelenskyy and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan are joining the gathering at the Borgo Egnazia resort in the Puglia region of southern Italy.\n\nThe summit, opening Thursday, will play out after far-right parties across the continent racked up gains of surprising scale in just-concluded European Union elections.\n\nThose victories, coupled with upcoming elections in the United Kingdom, France and the United States, have rattled the global political establishment and added weightiness to this year's summit.\n\n\"You hear this a lot when you talk to US and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether it's on China, whether it's on the assets, we may not have another chance,\" said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Council's Geo Economics Center, an international affairs think tank. \"We don't know what the world will look like three months, six months, nine months from now.\n\n\"The G7 is an informal bloc of industrialized democracies that meets annually to discuss shared issues and concerns. Biden will arrive in Italy on Wednesday night, his second trip outside the US in as many weeks.\n\nThe Democratic president was in France last week for a state visit in Paris and ceremonies in Normandy marking the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings in World War II.\n\nWhile last week's visit had a celebratory feel, this one will be dominated by pressing global issues, including how to keep financial support flowing to Ukraine as it fights Russia's invasion.\n\nBiden's trip comes a day after his son Hunter was convicted on federal gun charges, a blow sure to weigh heavily on the president's mind.\n\nDespite pressing global challenges, White House national security spokesman John Kirby said there's still a sense of relief among world leaders in 2024 that \"America was back,\" referencing Biden's 2021 speech at the G7 in England.\n\n\"Biden's message then was that democracies need to step up and show they can deliver for their people,\" Kirby said. \"That's true now more than ever.\"\n\nKirby said the US was prepared to work with democratically elected officials in the EU no matter who they are, though some of those being elevated have expressed far less support for Ukraine than current leaders.\n\n\"We have every confidence that regardless of who fills the seats in the European Parliament, we're going to continue to work closely with our EU partners on all the issues relative to our shared interests across the European continent,\" Kirby said.\n\n\"That includes supporting Ukraine.\" Biden and Zelenskyy, who met last week in Paris, will meet again to discuss continued support for the Eastern European nation, which is trying to fend off an intense Russian offensive in eastern areas of the country.\n\nThey're expected to hold a joint news conference. Biden is also expected to meet with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, the pope and other leaders.\n\nBiden, who's been adamant \"we will not walk away\" from Ukraine, last week publicly apologised to Zelenskyy for a monthslong delay by Congress in authorizing additional American military assistance.\n\nThe delay allowed Russia to make gains on the battlefield. Sullivan called the security agreement a \"bridge\" to when Ukraine is invited to join the NATO alliance a long-term priority of Zelenskyy's that the allies have said will first require an end to the Russia-Ukraine war and that Putin has steadfastly opposed.\n\nBiden's back-to-back trips to France and Italy amount to a rare doubleheader of diplomacy in the midst of the presidential election.\n\nThe president will skip a Ukraine peace conference in Switzerland this weekend to jet to Los Angeles for a campaign fundraiser with big names from Hollywood. Vice President Kamala Harris will represent the US at the conference.\n\nDespite the delays in military aid, the Biden administration on Tuesday announced it would send Ukraine another Patriot missile system to help fend off Russian strikes, two US officials told The Associated Press.\n\nBiden approved the move, the officials told the AP, as Kyiv has desperately called for more air defenses in its battle against an intense Russian assault on the northeastern Kharkiv region.\n\nEarlier Wednesday, the US announced fresh sanctions targeting Chinese companies that help Russia pursue its war in Ukraine, as well as Russia's financial infrastructure. Sullivan said, \"These actions will ratchet up the risk that foreign financial institutions take by dealing with Russia's war economy.\"\n\nA European plan to specifically use the interest on the Russian funds would provide only a trickle of money every year about $2.5 billion to $3 billion at current interest rates, which would barely meet a month's financing needs for the Ukrainian government.\n\nWhite House national security adviser Jake Sullivan said aboard Air Force One that the goal of the financing plan was to have a loan that would \"pull forward the windfall profits from the seized assets\" of Russia, giving Ukraine a \"substantial source of funding\" to meet its immediate needs.\n\nSullivan said he had a specific sum of money in mind, but declined to say if that figure was $50 billion. He stressed the urgency of getting Ukraine financial resources as soon as possible and that multiple countries would back the agreement.\n\n\"It's to provide the necessary resources to Ukraine now for its economic energy and other needs, so that it's capable of having the resilience necessary to withstand Russia's continuing aggression,\" Sullivan said.\n\nTreasury Secretary Janet Yellen said recently that G7 finance ministers have been discussing the possibility of extending a loan to Ukraine and using the windfall profits of assets seized in Europe to pay it off. Kirby said the US was optimistic the group could agree on the matter.\n\nBiden is also expected to discuss economic concerns brought on by Chinese manufacturing overcapacity, how to use artificial intelligence in a way that maximizes benefits but still manages national security risks, and global migration.\n\nThe US and other G7 nations are struggling to manage large influxes of migrants arriving for complicated reasons that include war, climate change and drought. Migration, and how nations cope with the growing numbers at their borders, has been a factor driving the far-right rise in some of Europe.", "source": {"uri": "indianexpress.com", "dataType": "news", "https://images.indianexpress.com/2024/06/Helo-22.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9644722", "eventUri": "eng-9644722", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": {"uri": "2024-06-387224629", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "13:23:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T13:23:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T09:09:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2024-06-12/fresh-off-france-trip-biden-heads-back-to-europe-for-g7-summit-to-talk-ukraine-support-migration", "title": "Fresh off France Trip, Biden Heads Back to Europe for G7 Summit to Talk Ukraine Support, Migration", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- President Joe Biden heads to Italy on Wednesday for a summit of the world's leading democracies with an urgency to get big things done, including turning frozen Russian assets into billions of dollars to help Ukraine as it fights off Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\nThis year's Group of Seven summit comes three years after Biden declared at his first such gathering that America was back as a global leader following the disruptions to Western alliances that occurred under President Donald Trump. Now, there's a chance this gathering could be the final G7 for Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of elections this year.\n\nBiden and his counterparts from Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related to the spread of artificial intelligence, migration, the Russian military's resurgence and China's economic might, among other topics. Pope Francis, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan are joining the gathering at the Borgo Egnazia resort in the Puglia, a region of southern Italy.\n\nThe summit, which opens Thursday, will play out after far-right parties across the continent racked up gains of surprising scale in just-concluded European Union elections. Those victories -- coupled with upcoming elections in the United Kingdom, France and the United States -- have rattled the global political establishment and added weightiness to this year's summit.\n\n\"You hear this a lot when you talk to U.S. and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether it's on China, whether it's on the assets, we may not have another chance,\" said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Council's GeoEconomics Center, an international affairs think tank. \"We don't know what the world will look like three months, six months, nine months from now.\"\n\nThe G7 is an informal bloc of industrialized democracies that meets annually to discuss shared issues and concerns. Biden is set to arrive in Italy on Wednesday night, his second trip outside the U.S. in as many weeks. The Democratic president was in France last week for a state visit in Paris and ceremonies in Normandy marking the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings in World War II.\n\nWhile last week's visit had a celebratory feel, this one will be dominated by pressing global issues, including how to keep financial support flowing to Ukraine as it fights Russia's invasion. Biden's trip also comes one day after his son Hunter was convicted on federal gun charges, a blow sure to weigh heavily on the president's mind.\n\nDespite pressing global challenges, White House national security spokesman John Kirby said there is still a sense of relief among world leaders in 2024 that \"America was back,\" referencing Biden's 2021 speech at the G7 in Cornwall, England.\n\n\"Biden's message then was that democracies need to step up and show they can deliver for their people,\" Kirby said. \"That's true now more than ever.\"\n\nKirby said the U.S. was prepared to work with democratically elected officials in the EU no matter who they are, though some of those being elevated have expressed far less support for Ukraine than current leaders.\n\n\"We have every confidence that regardless of who fills the seats in the European Parliament, we're going to continue to work closely with our EU partners on all the issues relative to our shared interests across the European continent,\" Kirby said. \"That includes supporting Ukraine.\"\n\nBiden and Zelenskyy, who met last week in Paris, will meet again Thursday on the sidelines of the summit to discuss continued support for the Eastern European nation, which is trying to fend off an intense Russian offensive in eastern areas of the country. They are expected to hold a joint news conference. Biden is also expected to meet one-on-one with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, the pope and other leaders.\n\nBiden, who has been adamant that \"we will not walk away\" from Ukraine, last week publicly apologized to Zelenskyy for a monthslong delay by Congress in authorizing additional American military assistance. The delay allowed Russia to make gains on the battlefield.\n\nBiden's back-to-back trips to France and Italy amount to a rare doubleheader of international diplomacy in the midst of the presidential election. The president will skip a Ukraine peace conference in Switzerland this weekend to jet to Los Angeles for a campaign fundraiser with big names from Hollywood. Vice President Kamala Harris will represent the U.S. at the Swiss conference.\n\nDespite the delays in military aid, the Biden administration on Tuesday announced it would send Ukraine another Patriot missile system to help fend off Russian strikes, two U.S. officials told The Associated Press. Biden approved the move, the officials told the AP, as Kyiv has desperately called for more air defenses in its battle against an intense Russian assault on the northeastern Kharkiv region.\n\nKirby said the U.S. would use the G7 summit to announce fresh sanctions and export control actions targeting those who have helped Russia procure what it needs for the war. He said the new measures would make it harder for financiers to support Russia's defense mechanism.\n\nUkraine and many of its supporters have called for the confiscation of $260 billion in Russian assets frozen outside the country after the Feb. 24, 2022, invasion. But European officials have resisted, citing legal and financial stability concerns. Most of the frozen assets are located in Europe.\n\nA European plan to just use the interest on the Russian funds would provide only a trickle of money every year -- about $2.5 billion to $3 billion at current interest rates, which would barely meet a month's financing needs for the Ukrainian government.\n\nTreasury Secretary Janet Yellen said recently that G7 finance ministers have been discussing the possibility of extending a loan to Ukraine and using the windfall profits of assets seized in Europe to pay it off.\n\nKirby said the U.S. was optimistic the group could agree on the matter.\n\nBiden is also expected to discuss economic concerns brought on by Chinese manufacturing overcapacity, how to use artificial intelligence in a way that maximizes benefits but still manages national security risks, and global migration.\n\nThe U.S. and other G7 nations are struggling to manage large influxes of migrants arriving for complicated reasons that include war, climate change and drought. Migration, and how nations cope with the growing numbers at their borders, has been a factor driving the far-right rise in some of Europe.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.", "source": {"uri": "usnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "U.S. News & World Report"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8174561605", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "15:53:32", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T15:53:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T15:52:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://mynorthwest.com/3962419/biden-and-zelenskyy-will-sign-security-agreement-between-us-and-ukraine-when-they-meet-at-g7/", "title": "Biden and Zelenskyy will sign security agreement between US and Ukraine when they meet at G7", "body": "ABOARD AIR FORCE ONE (AP) -- President Joe Biden and President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will sign a bilateral security agreement between the U.S. and Ukraine on Thursday when they meet on the sidelines of the Group of Seven summit, aiming to send signal to Russia of American resolve to supporting Kyiv, the White House said as Biden was headed to Italy.\n\nNational security adviser Jake Sullivan told reporters that the agreement would not commit U.S. troops directly to Ukraine's defense against Russia's invasion -- a red line drawn by Biden, who is fearful of being drawn into direct conflict between the nuclear-armed powers.\n\n\"We want to demonstrate that the U.S. supports the people of Ukraine, that we stand with them and that we'll continue to help address their security needs,\" Sullivan said, adding \"this agreement will show our resolve.\"\n\nSullivan called the agreement a \"bridge\" to when Ukraine is invited to join the NATO alliance -- a long-term priority of Zelenskyy's that the allies have said will first require an end to the Russia-Ukraine war.\n\nBiden heads to frozen Russian assets into billions of dollars to help Ukraine as it fights off Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\nThis year's Donald Trump was president. Now, there's a chance this gathering could be the final G7 for Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of elections this year.\n\nBiden and his counterparts from Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related to the spread of artificial intelligence, migration, the Russian military's resurgence and China's economic might, among other topics. Pope Francis, Zelenskyy and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan are joining the gathering at the Borgo Egnazia resort in the Puglia region of southern Italy.\n\nThe summit, which opens Thursday, will play out after far-right parties across the continent racked up gains of surprising scale in just-concluded European Union elections. Those victories, coupled with upcoming elections in the United Kingdom, France and the United States, have rattled the global political establishment and added weightiness to this year's summit.\n\n\"You hear this a lot when you talk to U.S. and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether it's on China, whether it's on the assets, we may not have another chance,\" said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Council's GeoEconomics Center, an international affairs think tank. \"We don't know what the world will look like three months, six months, nine months from now.\"\n\nThe G7 is an informal bloc of industrialized democracies that meets annually to discuss shared issues and concerns. Biden is set to arrive in Italy on Wednesday night, his second trip outside the U.S. in as many weeks. The Democratic president was in France last week for a state visit in Paris and ceremonies in Normandy marking the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings in World War II.\n\nWhile last week's visit had a celebratory feel, this one will be dominated by pressing global issues, including how to keep financial support flowing to Ukraine as it fights Russia's invasion. Biden's trip also comes one day after his son Hunter was convicted on federal gun charges, a blow sure to weigh heavily on the president's mind.\n\nDespite pressing global challenges, White House national security spokesman John Kirby said there is still a sense of relief among world leaders in 2024 that \"America was back,\" referencing Biden's 2021 speech at the G7 in Cornwall, England.\n\n\"Biden's message then was that democracies need to step up and show they can deliver for their people,\" Kirby said. \"That's true now more than ever.\"\n\nKirby said the U.S. was prepared to work with democratically elected officials in the EU no matter who they are, though some of those being elevated have expressed far less support for Ukraine than current leaders.\n\n\"We have every confidence that regardless of who fills the seats in the European Parliament, we're going to continue to work closely with our EU partners on all the issues relative to our shared interests across the European continent,\" Kirby said. \"That includes supporting Ukraine.\"\n\nBiden and Zelenskyy, who met last week in Paris, will meet again Thursday on the sidelines of the summit to discuss continued support for the Eastern European nation, which is trying to fend off an intense Russian offensive in eastern areas of the country. They are expected to hold a joint news conference. Biden is also expected to meet with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, the pope and other leaders.\n\nBiden, who has been adamant that \"we will not walk away\" from Ukraine, last week publicly apologized to Zelenskyy for a monthslong delay by Congress in authorizing additional American military assistance. The delay allowed Russia to make gains on the battlefield.\n\nBiden's back-to-back trips to France and Italy amount to a rare doubleheader of diplomacy in the midst of the presidential election. The president will skip a Ukraine peace conference in Switzerland this weekend to jet to Los Angeles for a campaign fundraiser with big names from Hollywood. Vice President Kamala Harris will represent the U.S. at the conference.\n\nDespite the delays in military aid, the Biden administration on Tuesday announced it would send Ukraine another Patriot missile system to help fend off Russian strikes, two U.S. officials told The Associated Press. Biden approved the move, the officials told the AP, as Kyiv has desperately called for more air defenses in its battle against an intense Russian assault on the northeastern Kharkiv region.\n\nKirby said the U.S. would use the G7 summit to announce fresh sanctions and export control actions targeting those who have helped Russia procure what it needs for the war. He said the new measures would make it harder for financiers to support Russia's defense mechanism.\n\nUkraine and many of its supporters have called for the confiscation of $260 billion in Russian assets frozen outside the country after the Feb. 24, 2022, invasion. But European officials have resisted, citing legal and financial stability concerns. Most of the frozen assets are located in Europe.\n\nA European plan to just use the interest on the Russian funds would provide only a trickle of money every year -- about $2.5 billion to $3 billion at current interest rates, which would barely meet a month's financing needs for the Ukrainian government.\n\nTreasury Secretary Janet Yellen said recently that G7 finance ministers have been discussing the possibility of extending a loan to Ukraine and using the windfall profits of assets seized in Europe to pay it off.\n\nKirby said the U.S. was optimistic the group could agree on the matter.\n\nBiden is also expected to discuss economic concerns brought on by Chinese manufacturing overcapacity, how to use artificial intelligence in a way that maximizes benefits but still manages national security risks, and global migration.\n\nThe U.S. and other G7 nations are struggling to manage large influxes of migrants arriving for complicated reasons that include war, climate change and drought. Migration, and how nations cope with the growing numbers at their borders, has been a factor driving the far-right rise in some of Europe.", "source": {"uri": "mynorthwest.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8174573247", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "16:00:08", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T16:00:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T15:59:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://chatnewstoday.ca/2024/06/12/biden-and-zelenskyy-will-sign-security-agreement-between-us-and-ukraine-when-they-meet-at-g7/", "title": "Biden and Zelenskyy will sign security agreement between US and Ukraine when they meet at G7", "body": "Sullivan called the agreement a \"bridge\" to when Ukraine is invited to join the NATO alliance -- a long-term priority of Zelenskyy's that the allies have said will first require an end to the Russia-Ukraine war.\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- President Joe Biden headed to Italy on Wednesday for a summit of the world's leading democracies with an urgency to get big things done, including turning frozen Russian assets into billions of dollars to help Ukraine as it fights off Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\nThis year's Group of Seven summit comes three years after Biden declared at his first such gathering that America was back as a global leader following the disruptions to Western alliances that occurred when Donald Trump was president. Now, there's a chance this gathering could be the final G7 for Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of elections this year.\n\nBiden and his counterparts from Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related to the spread of artificial intelligence, migration, the Russian military's resurgence and China's economic might, among other topics. Pope Francis, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan are joining the gathering at the Borgo Egnazia resort in the Puglia region of southern Italy.\n\nThe summit, which opens Thursday, will play out after far-right parties across the continent racked up gains of surprising scale in just-concluded European Union elections. Those victories, coupled with upcoming elections in the United Kingdom, France and the United States, have rattled the global political establishment and added weightiness to this year's summit.\n\n\"You hear this a lot when you talk to U.S. and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether it's on China, whether it's on the assets, we may not have another chance,\" said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Council's GeoEconomics Center, an international affairs think tank. \"We don't know what the world will look like three months, six months, nine months from now.\"\n\nThe G7 is an informal bloc of industrialized democracies that meets annually to discuss shared issues and concerns. Biden is set to arrive in Italy on Wednesday night, his second trip outside the U.S. in as many weeks. The Democratic president was in France last week for a state visit in Paris and ceremonies in Normandy marking the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings in World War II.\n\nWhile last week's visit had a celebratory feel, this one will be dominated by pressing global issues, including how to keep financial support flowing to Ukraine as it fights Russia's invasion. Biden's trip also comes one day after his son Hunter was convicted on federal gun charges, a blow sure to weigh heavily on the president's mind.\n\nDespite pressing global challenges, White House national security spokesman John Kirby said there is still a sense of relief among world leaders in 2024 that \"America was back,\" referencing Biden's 2021 speech at the G7 in Cornwall, England.\n\n\"Biden's message then was that democracies need to step up and show they can deliver for their people,\" Kirby said. \"That's true now more than ever.\"\n\nKirby said the U.S. was prepared to work with democratically elected officials in the EU no matter who they are, though some of those being elevated have expressed far less support for Ukraine than current leaders.\n\n\"We have every confidence that regardless of who fills the seats in the European Parliament, we're going to continue to work closely with our EU partners on all the issues relative to our shared interests across the European continent,\" Kirby said. \"That includes supporting Ukraine.\"\n\nBiden and Zelenskyy, who met last week in Paris, will meet again Thursday on the sidelines of the summit to discuss continued support for the Eastern European nation, which is trying to fend off an intense Russian offensive in eastern areas of the country. They are expected to hold a joint news conference. Biden is also expected to meet with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, the pope and other leaders.\n\nBiden, who has been adamant that \"we will not walk away\" from Ukraine, last week publicly apologized to Zelenskyy for a monthslong delay by Congress in authorizing additional American military assistance. The delay allowed Russia to make gains on the battlefield.\n\nBiden's back-to-back trips to France and Italy amount to a rare doubleheader of diplomacy in the midst of the presidential election. The president will skip a Ukraine peace conference in Switzerland this weekend to jet to Los Angeles for a campaign fundraiser with big names from Hollywood. Vice President Kamala Harris will represent the U.S. at the conference.\n\nDespite the delays in military aid, the Biden administration on Tuesday announced it would send Ukraine another Patriot missile system to help fend off Russian strikes, two U.S. officials told The Associated Press. Biden approved the move, the officials told the AP, as Kyiv has desperately called for more air defenses in its battle against an intense Russian assault on the northeastern Kharkiv region.\n\nKirby said the U.S. would use the G7 summit to announce fresh sanctions and export control actions targeting those who have helped Russia procure what it needs for the war. He said the new measures would make it harder for financiers to support Russia's defense mechanism.\n\nUkraine and many of its supporters have called for the confiscation of $260 billion in Russian assets frozen outside the country after the Feb. 24, 2022, invasion. But European officials have resisted, citing legal and financial stability concerns. Most of the frozen assets are located in Europe.\n\nA European plan to just use the interest on the Russian funds would provide only a trickle of money every year -- about $2.5 billion to $3 billion at current interest rates, which would barely meet a month's financing needs for the Ukrainian government.\n\nTreasury Secretary Janet Yellen said recently that G7 finance ministers have been discussing the possibility of extending a loan to Ukraine and using the windfall profits of assets seized in Europe to pay it off.\n\nKirby said the U.S. was optimistic the group could agree on the matter.\n\nBiden is also expected to discuss economic concerns brought on by Chinese manufacturing overcapacity, how to use artificial intelligence in a way that maximizes benefits but still manages national security risks, and global migration.\n\nThe U.S. and other G7 nations are struggling to manage large influxes of migrants arriving for complicated reasons that include war, climate change and drought. Migration, and how nations cope with the growing numbers at their borders, has been a factor driving the far-right rise in some of Europe.\n\nDarlene Superville And Colleen Long, The Associated "eng-9644722", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.07450980392156858, "wgt": 196, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-06-387430714", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "16:35:23", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T16:35:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T16:25:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/biden-and-zelenskyy-will-sign-a-security-agreement-between-the-us-and-ukraine-when-they/article_4225dbd7-8db5-5795-be1b-380a79eaee74.html", "title": "Biden and Zelenskyy will sign a security agreement between the US and Ukraine when they meet at G7", "body": "ABOARD AIR FORCE ONE (AP) -- President Joe Biden and President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will sign a bilateral security agreement between the U.S. and Ukraine on Thursday when they meet on the sidelines of the Group of Seven summit in Italy, aiming to send a signal to Russia of American resolve in supporting Kyiv, the White House said as Biden was headed to Europe.\n\nNational security adviser Jake Sullivan said the agreement would not commit U.S. troops directly to Ukraine's defense against Russia's invasion -- a red line drawn by Biden, who's fearful of being pulled into direct conflict between the nuclear-armed powers. Announcement of the agreement comes as Biden heads to the summit of the world's leading democracies with an urgency to get big things done, including turning frozen Russian assets into billions of dollars to help Ukraine fight Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\n\"We want to demonstrate that the U.S. supports the people of Ukraine, that we stand with them and that we'll continue to help address their security needs,\" Sullivan said, adding \"this agreement will show our resolve.\"\n\nThis year's meeting comes three years after Biden declared at his first such gathering that America was back as a global leader following the disruptions to Western alliances that occurred when Donald Trump was president. Now, there's a chance this gathering could be the final G7 for Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of elections this year.\n\nBiden and his counterparts from Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related artificial intelligence, migration, the Russian military's resurgence and China's economic might, among other topics. Pope Francis, Zelenskyy and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan are joining the gathering at the Borgo Egnazia resort in the Puglia region of southern Italy.\n\nThe summit, opening Thursday, will play out after far-right parties across the continent racked up gains of surprising scale in just-concluded European Union elections. Those victories, coupled with upcoming elections in the United Kingdom, France and the United States, have rattled the global political establishment and added weightiness to this year's summit.\n\n\"You hear this a lot when you talk to U.S. and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether it's on China, whether it's on the assets, we may not have another chance,\" said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Council's GeoEconomics Center, an international affairs think tank. \"We don't know what the world will look like three months, six months, nine months from now.\"\n\nThe G7 is an informal bloc of industrialized democracies that meets annually to discuss shared issues and concerns. Biden will arrive in Italy on Wednesday night, his second trip outside the U.S. in as many weeks. The Democratic president was in France last week for a state visit in Paris and ceremonies in Normandy marking the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings in World War II.\n\nWhile last week's visit had a celebratory feel, this one will be dominated by pressing global issues, including how to keep financial support flowing to Ukraine as it fights Russia's invasion. Biden's trip comes a day after his son Hunter was convicted on federal gun charges, a blow sure to weigh heavily on the president's mind.\n\nDespite pressing global challenges, White House national security spokesman John Kirby said there's still a sense of relief among world leaders in 2024 that \"America was back,\" referencing Biden's 2021 speech at the G7 in England.\n\n\"Biden's message then was that democracies need to step up and show they can deliver for their people,\" Kirby said. \"That's true now more than ever.\"\n\nKirby said the U.S. was prepared to work with democratically elected officials in the EU no matter who they are, though some of those being elevated have expressed far less support for Ukraine than current leaders.\n\n\"We have every confidence that regardless of who fills the seats in the European Parliament, we're going to continue to work closely with our EU partners on all the issues relative to our shared interests across the European continent,\" Kirby said. \"That includes supporting Ukraine.\"\n\nBiden and Zelenskyy, who met last week in Paris, will meet again discuss continued support for the Eastern European nation, which is trying to fend off an intense Russian offensive in eastern areas of the country. They're expected to hold a joint news conference. Biden is also expected to meet with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, the pope and other leaders.\n\nBiden, who's been adamant \"we will not walk away\" from Ukraine, last week publicly apologized to Zelenskyy for a monthslong delay by Congress in authorizing additional American military assistance. The delay allowed Russia to make gains on the battlefield.\n\nSullivan called the security agreement a \"bridge\" to when Ukraine is invited to join the NATO alliance -- a long-term priority of Zelenskyy's that the allies have said will first require an end to the Russia-Ukraine war and that Putin has steadfastly opposed.\n\nBiden's back-to-back trips to France and Italy amount to a rare doubleheader of diplomacy in the midst of the presidential election. The president will skip a Ukraine peace conference in Switzerland this weekend to jet to Los Angeles for a campaign fundraiser with big names from Hollywood. Vice President Kamala Harris will represent the U.S. at the conference.\n\nDespite the delays in military aid, the Biden administration on Tuesday announced it would send Ukraine another Patriot missile system to help fend off Russian strikes, two U.S. officials told The Associated Press. Biden approved the move, the officials told the AP, as Kyiv has desperately called for more air defenses in its battle against an intense Russian assault on the northeastern Kharkiv region.\n\nKirby said the U.S. would use the G7 summit to announce fresh sanctions and export control actions targeting those who have helped Russia procure what it needs for the war. He said the new measures would make it harder for financiers to support Russia's defense mechanism.\n\nUkraine and many of its supporters have called for the confiscation of $260 billion in Russian assets frozen outside the country after the Feb. 24, 2022, invasion. But European officials have resisted, citing legal and financial stability concerns. Most of the frozen assets are located in Europe.\n\nA European plan to just use the interest on the Russian funds would provide only a trickle of money every year -- about $2.5 billion to $3 billion at current interest rates, which would barely meet a month's financing needs for the Ukrainian government.\n\nTreasury Secretary Janet Yellen said recently that G7 finance ministers have been discussing the possibility of extending a loan to Ukraine and using the windfall profits of assets seized in Europe to pay it off.\n\nKirby said the U.S. was optimistic the group could agree on the matter.\n\nBiden is also expected to discuss economic concerns brought on by Chinese manufacturing overcapacity, how to use artificial intelligence in a way that maximizes benefits but still manages national security risks, and global migration.\n\nThe U.S. and other G7 nations are struggling to manage large influxes of migrants arriving for complicated reasons that include war, climate change and drought. Migration, and how nations cope with the growing numbers at their borders, has been a factor driving the far-right rise in some of Europe.\n\nSuperville reported from Bari, Italy.\n\nMore from this section\n\nRepublican challenger to Tester leans into his outsider status in Montana US Senate debate\n\nKiosk Machine Industry June 2024: Self Service Kiosk Machine - InfoComm Preview and Acrelec {"uri": "8174955017", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "21:23:33", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T21:23:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T21:22:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.thepeterboroughexaminer.com/news/world/united-states/biden-and-zelenskyy-will-sign-a-security-deal-as-g7-leaders-agree-to-use-russian/article_4fc6bbd0-514f-516c-ad3b-c74f36c31e78.html", "title": "Biden and Zelenskyy will sign a security deal, as G7 leaders agree to use Russian cash to help Kyiv", "body": "BRINDISI, Italy (AP) -- President Joe Biden and President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will sign a bilateral security agreement between the U.S. and Ukraine on Thursday when they meet on the sidelines of the Group of Seven summit in Italy, as negotiators for the group have reached an agreement on how to provide Ukraine with up to $50 billion backed by frozen Russian assets, two people familiar with the matter said Wednesday.\n\nThe international group of wealthy democracies has been discussing ways of using the more than $260 billion in Russian assets frozen outside the country after the Feb. 24, 2022 invasion of Ukraine to help Kyiv.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nEuropean officials have resisted confiscating the assets, citing legal and financial stability concerns -- most of the frozen assets are located in Europe -- but the plan would use the interest earned on the assets to help Ukraine's war effort. The two people spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss the agreement before it was formally announced.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nAn official with the French presidency confirmed the announcement Wednesday.\n\nThe announcement of the agreement comes as Biden heads to the summit of the world's leading democracies with an urgency to get big things done, including turning frozen Russian assets into billions of dollars to help Ukraine fight Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\nThe security arrangement was aimed to send a signal to Russia of American resolve in supporting Kyiv, the White House said as Biden was headed to Europe.\n\nNational security adviser Jake Sullivan said the security agreement would not commit U.S. troops directly to Ukraine's defense against Russia's invasion -- a red line drawn by Biden, who's fearful of being pulled into direct conflict between the nuclear-armed powers.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"We want to demonstrate that the U.S. supports the people of Ukraine, that we stand with them and that we'll continue to help address their security needs,\" Sullivan said, adding \"this agreement will show our resolve.\"\n\nYou might be interested in Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThis year's meeting comes three years after Biden declared at his first such gathering that America was back as a global leader following the disruptions to Western alliances that occurred when Donald Trump was president. Now, there's a chance this gathering could be the final G7 for Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of elections this year.\n\nBiden and his counterparts from Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related to artificial intelligence, migration, the Russian military's resurgence and China's economic might, among other topics. Pope Francis, Zelenskyy and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan are joining the gathering at the Borgo Egnazia resort in the Puglia region of southern Italy.\n\nThe summit, opening Thursday, will play out after far-right parties across the continent racked up gains of surprising scale in just-concluded European Union elections. Those victories, coupled with upcoming elections in the United Kingdom, France and the United States, have rattled the global political establishment and added weightiness to this year's summit.\n\n\"You hear this a lot when you talk to U.S. and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether it's on China, whether it's on the assets, we may not have another chance,\" said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Council's GeoEconomics Center, an international affairs think tank. \"We don't know what the world will look like three months, six months, nine months from now.\"\n\nThe G7 is an informal bloc of industrialized democracies that meets annually to discuss shared issues and concerns. Biden will arrive in Italy on Wednesday night, his second trip outside the U.S. in as many weeks. The Democratic president was in France last week for a state visit in Paris and ceremonies in Normandy marking the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings in World War II.\n\nWhile last week's visit had a celebratory feel, this one will be dominated by pressing global issues, including how to keep financial support flowing to Ukraine as it fights Russia's invasion. Biden's trip comes a day after his son Hunter was convicted on federal gun charges, a blow sure to weigh heavily on the president's mind.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nDespite pressing global challenges, White House national security spokesman John Kirby said there's still a sense of relief among world leaders in 2024 that \"America was back,\" referencing Biden's 2021 speech at the G7 in England.\n\n\"Biden's message then was that democracies need to step up and show they can deliver for their people,\" Kirby said. \"That's true now more than ever.\"\n\nKirby said the U.S. was prepared to work with democratically elected officials in the EU no matter who they are, though some of those being elevated have expressed far less support for Ukraine than current leaders.\n\n\"We have every confidence that regardless of who fills the seats in the European Parliament, we're going to continue to work closely with our EU partners on all the issues relative to our shared interests across the European continent,\" Kirby said. \"That includes supporting Ukraine.\"\n\nBiden and Zelenskyy, who met last week in Paris, will meet again to discuss continued support for the Eastern European nation, which is trying to fend off an intense Russian offensive in eastern areas of the country. They're expected to hold a joint news conference. Biden is also expected to meet with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, the pope and other leaders.\n\nBiden, who's been adamant \"we will not walk away\" from Ukraine, last week publicly apologized to Zelenskyy for a monthslong delay by Congress in authorizing additional American military assistance. The delay allowed Russia to make gains on the battlefield.\n\nSullivan called the security agreement a \"bridge\" to when Ukraine is invited to join the NATO alliance -- a long-term priority of Zelenskyy's that the allies have said will first require an end to the Russia-Ukraine war and that Putin has steadfastly opposed.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nBiden's back-to-back trips to France and Italy amount to a rare doubleheader of diplomacy in the midst of the presidential election. The president will skip a Ukraine peace conference in Switzerland this weekend to jet to Los Angeles for a campaign fundraiser with big names from Hollywood. Vice President Kamala Harris will represent the U.S. at the conference.\n\nDespite the delays in military aid, the Biden administration on Tuesday announced it would send Ukraine another Patriot missile system to help fend off Russian strikes, two U.S. officials told The Associated Press. Biden approved the move, the officials told the AP, as Kyiv has desperately called for more air defenses in its battle against an intense Russian assault on the northeastern Kharkiv region.\n\nEarlier Wednesday, the U.S. announced fresh sanctions targeting Chinese companies that help Russia pursue its war in Ukraine, as well as Russia's financial infrastructure. Sullivan said, \"These actions will ratchet up the risk that foreign financial institutions take by dealing with Russia's war economy.\"\n\nA European plan to specifically use the interest on the Russian funds would provide only a trickle of money every year -- about $2.5 billion to $3 billion at current interest rates, which would barely meet a month's financing needs for the Ukrainian government.\n\nWhite House national security adviser Jake Sullivan said aboard Air Force One that the goal of the financing plan was to have a loan that would \"pull forward the windfall profits from the seized assets\" of Russia, giving Ukraine a \"substantial source of funding\" to meet its immediate needs.\n\nSullivan said he had a specific sum of money in mind, but declined to say if that figure was $50 billion. He stressed the urgency of getting Ukraine financial resources as soon as possible and that multiple countries would back the agreement.\n\n\"It's to provide the necessary resources to Ukraine now for its economic energy and other needs, so that it's capable of having the resilience necessary to withstand Russia's continuing aggression,\" Sullivan said.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nTreasury Secretary Janet Yellen said recently that G7 finance ministers have been discussing the possibility of extending a loan to Ukraine and using the windfall profits of assets seized in Europe to pay it off.\n\nKirby said the U.S. was optimistic the group could agree on the matter.\n\nBiden is also expected to discuss economic concerns brought on by Chinese manufacturing overcapacity, how to use artificial intelligence in a way that maximizes benefits but still manages national security risks, and global migration.\n\nThe U.S. and other G7 nations are struggling to manage large influxes of migrants arriving for complicated reasons that include war, climate change and drought. Migration, and how nations cope with the growing numbers at their borders, has been a factor driving the far-right rise in some of Europe.\n\n___\n\nSuperville reported from Bari, Italy. Miller and Madhani reported from Washington. Angela Charlton in Paris and Fatima Hussein and Josh Boak in Washington contributed.", "source": {"uri": "thepeterboroughexaminer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "thepeterboroughexaminer.com"}, {"uri": "2024-06-387656266", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "21:31:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T21:31:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T21:31:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.newsandstar.co.uk/news/national/24383994.biden-zelensky-sign-security-agreement-us-ukraine-summit/", "title": "Biden and Zelensky to sign security agreement between US and Ukraine at summit", "body": "President Joe Biden and President Volodymyr Zelensky will sign a bilateral security agreement between the US and Ukraine on Thursday when they meet on the sidelines of the G7 summit.\n\nThe announcement came as negotiators for the group reached an agreement on how to provide Ukraine with up to 50 billion dollars backed by frozen Russian assets, according to two people familiar with the matter.\n\nThe international group of wealthy democracies has been discussing ways of using the more than 260 billion dollars in Russian assets frozen outside the country after the February 2022 invasion of Ukraine to help Kyiv.\n\nEuropean officials have resisted confiscating the assets, citing legal and financial stability concerns - most of the frozen assets are located in Europe - but the plan would use the interest earned on the assets to help Ukraine's war effort.\n\nAn official with the French presidency confirmed the announcement on Wednesday.\n\nThe announcement of the agreement comes as Mr Biden heads to the G7 summit with an urgency to get big things done, including turning frozen Russian assets into billions of dollars to help Ukraine fight Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\nThe security arrangement was aimed at sending a signal to Russia of American resolve in supporting Kyiv, the White House said as Mr Biden was headed to Europe.\n\nNational security adviser Jake Sullivan told reporters that the agreement would not commit US troops directly to Ukraine's defence against Russia's invasion - a red line drawn by Mr Biden, who is fearful of being drawn into direct conflict between the nuclear-armed powers.\n\n\"We want to demonstrate that the US supports the people of Ukraine, that we stand with them and that we'll continue to help address their security needs,\" Mr Sullivan said, adding \"this agreement will show our resolve\".\n\nMr Sullivan called the agreement a \"bridge\" to when Ukraine is invited to join the Nato alliance - a long-term priority of Mr Zelensky's that the allies have said will first require an end to the Russia-Ukraine war.\n\nMr Biden heads to the summit of the world's leading democracies with an urgency to get big things done, including turning frozen Russian assets into billions of dollars to help Ukraine as it fights off Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\nThis year's G7 summit comes three years after Mr Biden declared at his first such gathering that America was back as a global leader following the disruptions to western alliances that occurred when Donald Trump was president.\n\nNow, there is a chance this gathering could be the final G7 for Mr Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of elections this year.\n\nMr Biden and his counterparts from Canada, the UK, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related to the spread of artificial intelligence, migration, the Russian military's resurgence and China's economic might, among other topics.\n\nPope Francis, Mr Zelensky and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan are joining the gathering at the Borgo Egnazia resort in the Puglia region of southern Italy.\n\nThe summit, which opens on Thursday, will play out after far-right parties across the continent secured gains of surprising scale in just-concluded European Union elections.\n\nThose victories, coupled with upcoming elections in the UK, France and the US, have rattled the global political establishment and added weightiness to this year's summit.\n\n\"You hear this a lot when you talk to US and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether it's on China, whether it's on the assets, we may not have another chance,\" said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Council's GeoEconomics Centre, an international affairs think tank.\n\n\"We don't know what the world will look like three months, six months, nine months from now.\"", "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.wandsworthguardian.co.uk/news/national/24383994.biden-zelensky-sign-security-agreement-us-ukraine-summit/", "title": "Biden and Zelensky to sign security agreement between US and Ukraine at summit", "body": "President Joe Biden and President Volodymyr Zelensky will sign a bilateral security agreement between the US and Ukraine on Thursday when they meet on the sidelines of the G7 summit.\n\nThe announcement came as negotiators for the group reached an agreement on how to provide Ukraine with up to 50 billion dollars backed by frozen Russian assets, according to two people familiar with the matter.\n\nThe international group of wealthy democracies has been discussing ways of using the more than 260 billion dollars in Russian assets frozen outside the country after the February 2022 invasion of Ukraine to help Kyiv.\n\nEuropean officials have resisted confiscating the assets, citing legal and financial stability concerns - most of the frozen assets are located in Europe - but the plan would use the interest earned on the assets to help Ukraine's war effort.\n\nAn official with the French presidency confirmed the announcement on Wednesday.\n\nThe announcement of the agreement comes as Mr Biden heads to the G7 summit with an urgency to get big things done, including turning frozen Russian assets into billions of dollars to help Ukraine fight Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\nThe security arrangement was aimed at sending a signal to Russia of American resolve in supporting Kyiv, the White House said as Mr Biden was headed to Europe.\n\nNational security adviser Jake Sullivan told reporters that the agreement would not commit US troops directly to Ukraine's defence against Russia's invasion - a red line drawn by Mr Biden, who is fearful of being drawn into direct conflict between the nuclear-armed powers.\n\n\"We want to demonstrate that the US supports the people of Ukraine, that we stand with them and that we'll continue to help address their security needs,\" Mr Sullivan said, adding \"this agreement will show our resolve\".\n\nMr Sullivan called the agreement a \"bridge\" to when Ukraine is invited to join the Nato alliance - a long-term priority of Mr Zelensky's that the allies have said will first require an end to the Russia-Ukraine war.\n\nMr Biden heads to the summit of the world's leading democracies with an urgency to get big things done, including turning frozen Russian assets into billions of dollars to help Ukraine as it fights off Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\nThis year's G7 summit comes three years after Mr Biden declared at his first such gathering that America was back as a global leader following the disruptions to western alliances that occurred when Donald Trump was president.\n\nNow, there is a chance this gathering could be the final G7 for Mr Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of elections this year.\n\nMr Biden and his counterparts from Canada, the UK, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related to the spread of artificial intelligence, migration, the Russian military's resurgence and China's economic might, among other topics.\n\nPope Francis, Mr Zelensky and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan are joining the gathering at the Borgo Egnazia resort in the Puglia region of southern Italy.\n\nThe summit, which opens on Thursday, will play out after far-right parties across the continent secured gains of surprising scale in just-concluded European Union elections.\n\nThose victories, coupled with upcoming elections in the UK, France and the US, have rattled the global political establishment and added weightiness to this year's summit.\n\n\"You hear this a lot when you talk to US and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether it's on China, whether it's on the assets, we may not have another chance,\" said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Council's GeoEconomics Centre, an international affairs think tank.\n\n\"We don't know what the world will look like three months, six months, nine months from now.\"",
