{"uri": "8174565826", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "15:56:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T15:56:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T15:54:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/news/national/biden-and-zelenskyy-will-sign-security-agreement-between-us-and-ukraine-when-they-meet-at/article_cebd0e5c-159c-5bea-bb1e-30d49bbe936c.html", "title": "Biden and Zelenskyy will sign security agreement between US and Ukraine when they meet at G7", "body": "President Joe Biden is escorted by Air Force Col. Angela Ochoa, Commander, 89th Airlift Wing, as he arrives at Andrews Air Force Base, Md., Wednesday, June 12, 2024. Biden is headed to Italy for the G7 summit. Biden's granddaughter, Finnegan Biden, walks right.\n\nABOARD AIR FORCE ONE (AP) -- President Joe Biden and President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will sign a bilateral security agreement between the U.S. and Ukraine on Thursday when they meet on the sidelines of the Group of Seven summit, aiming to send signal to Russia of American resolve to supporting Kyiv, the White House said as Biden was headed to Italy.\n\nNational security adviser Jake Sullivan told reporters that the agreement would not commit U.S. troops directly to Ukraine's defense against Russia's invasion -- a red line drawn by Biden, who is fearful of being drawn into direct conflict between the nuclear-armed powers.\n\n\"We want to demonstrate that the U.S. supports the people of Ukraine, that we stand with them and that we'll continue to help address their security needs,\" Sullivan said, adding \"this agreement will show our resolve.\"\n\nSullivan called the agreement a \"bridge\" to when Ukraine is invited to join the NATO alliance -- a long-term priority of Zelenskyy's that the allies have said will first require an end to the Russia-Ukraine war.\n\nBiden heads to the summit of the world's leading democracies with an urgency to get big things done, including turning frozen Russian assets into billions of dollars to help Ukraine as it fights off Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\nThis year's Group of Seven summit comes three years after Biden declared at his first such gathering that America was back as a global leader following the disruptions to Western alliances that occurred when Donald Trump was president. Now, there's a chance this gathering could be the final G7 for Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of elections this year.\n\nBiden and his counterparts from Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related to the spread of artificial intelligence, migration, the Russian military's resurgence and China's economic might, among other topics. Pope Francis, Zelenskyy and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan are joining the gathering at the Borgo Egnazia resort in the Puglia region of southern Italy.\n\nThe summit, which opens Thursday, will play out after far-right parties across the continent racked up gains of surprising scale in just-concluded European Union elections. Those victories, coupled with upcoming elections in the United Kingdom, France and the United States, have rattled the global political establishment and added weightiness to this year's summit.\n\n\"You hear this a lot when you talk to U.S. and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether it's on China, whether it's on the assets, we may not have another chance,\" said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Council's GeoEconomics Center, an international affairs think tank. \"We don't know what the world will look like three months, six months, nine months from now.\"\n\nThe G7 is an informal bloc of industrialized democracies that meets annually to discuss shared issues and concerns. Biden is set to arrive in Italy on Wednesday night, his second trip outside the U.S. in as many weeks. The Democratic president was in France last week for a state visit in Paris and ceremonies in Normandy marking the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings in World War II.\n\nWhile last week's visit had a celebratory feel, this one will be dominated by pressing global issues, including how to keep financial support flowing to Ukraine as it fights Russia's invasion. Biden's trip also comes one day after his son Hunter was convicted on federal gun charges, a blow sure to weigh heavily on the president's mind.\n\nDespite pressing global challenges, White House national security spokesman John Kirby said there is still a sense of relief among world leaders in 2024 that \"America was back,\" referencing Biden's 2021 speech at the G7 in Cornwall, England.\n\n\"Biden's message then was that democracies need to step up and show they can deliver for their people,\" Kirby said. \"That's true now more than ever.\"\n\nKirby said the U.S. was prepared to work with democratically elected officials in the EU no matter who they are, though some of those being elevated have expressed far less support for Ukraine than current leaders.\n\n\"We have every confidence that regardless of who fills the seats in the European Parliament, we're going to continue to work closely with our EU partners on all the issues relative to our shared interests across the European continent,\" Kirby said. \"That includes supporting Ukraine.\"\n\nBiden and Zelenskyy, who met last week in Paris, will meet again Thursday on the sidelines of the summit to discuss continued support for the Eastern European nation, which is trying to fend off an intense Russian offensive in eastern areas of the country. They are expected to hold a joint news conference. Biden is also expected to meet with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, the pope and other leaders.\n\nBiden, who has been adamant that \"we will not walk away\" from Ukraine, last week publicly apologized to Zelenskyy for a monthslong delay by Congress in authorizing additional American military assistance. The delay allowed Russia to make gains on the battlefield.\n\nBiden's back-to-back trips to France and Italy amount to a rare doubleheader of diplomacy in the midst of the presidential election. The president will skip a Ukraine peace conference in Switzerland this weekend to jet to Los Angeles for a campaign fundraiser with big names from Hollywood. Vice President Kamala Harris will represent the U.S. at the conference.\n\nDespite the delays in military aid, the Biden administration on Tuesday announced it would send Ukraine another Patriot missile system to help fend off Russian strikes, two U.S. officials told The Associated Press. Biden approved the move, the officials told the AP, as Kyiv has desperately called for more air defenses in its battle against an intense Russian assault on the northeastern Kharkiv region.\n\nKirby said the U.S. would use the G7 summit to announce fresh sanctions and export control actions targeting those who have helped Russia procure what it needs for the war. He said the new measures would make it harder for financiers to support Russia's defense mechanism.\n\nUkraine and many of its supporters have called for the confiscation of $260 billion in Russian assets frozen outside the country after the Feb. 24, 2022, invasion. But European officials have resisted, citing legal and financial stability concerns. Most of the frozen assets are located in Europe.\n\nA European plan to just use the interest on the Russian funds would provide only a trickle of money every year -- about $2.5 billion to $3 billion at current interest rates, which would barely meet a month's financing needs for the Ukrainian government.\n\nTreasury Secretary Janet Yellen said recently that G7 finance ministers have been discussing the possibility of extending a loan to Ukraine and using the windfall profits of assets seized in Europe to pay it off.\n\nKirby said the U.S. was optimistic the group could agree on the matter.\n\nBiden is also expected to discuss economic concerns brought on by Chinese manufacturing overcapacity, how to use artificial intelligence in a way that maximizes benefits but still manages national security risks, and global migration.\n\nThe U.S. and other G7 nations are struggling to manage large influxes of migrants arriving for complicated reasons that include war, climate change and drought. Migration, and how nations cope with the growing numbers at their borders, has been a factor driving the far-right rise in some of Europe.\n\nSuperville reported from Bari, Italy.", "source": {"uri": "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9644722", "eventUri": "eng-9644722", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2012-06-", "textStart": 151, "textEnd": 158}], "sentiment": {"uri": "8174630194", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "16:40:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T16:40:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T16:39:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.yakimaherald.com/news/nation_and_world/nation/biden-and-zelenskyy-will-sign-a-security-agreement-between-the-us-and-ukraine-when-they/article_dd508b6c-12a0-59ec-83f5-6882de006788.html", "title": "Biden and Zelenskyy will sign a security agreement between the US and Ukraine when they meet at G7", "body": "President Joe Biden is escorted by Air Force Col. Angela Ochoa, Commander, 89th Airlift Wing, as he arrives at Andrews Air Force Base, Md., Wednesday, June 12, 2024. Biden is headed to Italy for the G7 summit. Biden's granddaughter, Finnegan Biden, walks left.\n\nABOARD AIR FORCE ONE (AP) -- President Joe Biden and President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will sign a bilateral security agreement between the U.S. and Ukraine on Thursday when they meet on the sidelines of the Group of Seven summit in Italy, aiming to send a signal to Russia of American resolve in supporting Kyiv, the White House said as Biden was headed to Europe.\n\nNational security adviser Jake Sullivan said the agreement would not commit U.S. troops directly to Ukraine's defense against Russia's invasion -- a red line drawn by Biden, who's fearful of being pulled into direct conflict between the nuclear-armed powers. Announcement of the agreement comes as Biden heads to the summit of the world's leading democracies with an urgency to get big things done, including turning frozen Russian assets into billions of dollars to help Ukraine fight Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\n\"We want to demonstrate that the U.S. supports the people of Ukraine, that we stand with them and that we'll continue to help address their security needs,\" Sullivan said, adding \"this agreement will show our resolve.\"\n\nThis year's meeting comes three years after Biden declared at his first such gathering that America was back as a global leader following the disruptions to Western alliances that occurred when Donald Trump was president. Now, there's a chance this gathering could be the final G7 for Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of elections this year.\n\nBiden and his counterparts from Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related artificial intelligence, migration, the Russian military's resurgence and China's economic might, among other topics. Pope Francis, Zelenskyy and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan are joining the gathering at the Borgo Egnazia resort in the Puglia region of southern Italy.\n\nThe summit, opening Thursday, will play out after far-right parties across the continent racked up gains of surprising scale in just-concluded European Union elections. Those victories, coupled with upcoming elections in the United Kingdom, France and the United States, have rattled the global political establishment and added weightiness to this year's summit.\n\n\"You hear this a lot when you talk to U.S. and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether it's on China, whether it's on the assets, we may not have another chance,\" said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Council's GeoEconomics Center, an international affairs think tank. \"We don't know what the world will look like three months, six months, nine months from now.\"\n\nThe G7 is an informal bloc of industrialized democracies that meets annually to discuss shared issues and concerns. Biden will arrive in Italy on Wednesday night, his second trip outside the U.S. in as many weeks. The Democratic president was in France last week for a state visit in Paris and ceremonies in Normandy marking the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings in World War II.\n\nWhile last week's visit had a celebratory feel, this one will be dominated by pressing global issues, including how to keep financial support flowing to Ukraine as it fights Russia's invasion. Biden's trip comes a day after his son Hunter was convicted on federal gun charges, a blow sure to weigh heavily on the president's mind.\n\nDespite pressing global challenges, White House national security spokesman John Kirby said there's still a sense of relief among world leaders in 2024 that \"America was back,\" referencing Biden's 2021 speech at the G7 in England.\n\n\"Biden's message then was that democracies need to step up and show they can deliver for their people,\" Kirby said. \"That's true now more than ever.\"\n\nKirby said the U.S. was prepared to work with democratically elected officials in the EU no matter who they are, though some of those being elevated have expressed far less support for Ukraine than current leaders.\n\n\"We have every confidence that regardless of who fills the seats in the European Parliament, we're going to continue to work closely with our EU partners on all the issues relative to our shared interests across the European continent,\" Kirby said. \"That includes supporting Ukraine.\"\n\nBiden and Zelenskyy, who met last week in Paris, will meet again discuss continued support for the Eastern European nation, which is trying to fend off an intense Russian offensive in eastern areas of the country. They're expected to hold a joint news conference. Biden is also expected to meet with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, the pope and other leaders.\n\nBiden, who's been adamant \"we will not walk away\" from Ukraine, last week publicly apologized to Zelenskyy for a monthslong delay by Congress in authorizing additional American military assistance. The delay allowed Russia to make gains on the battlefield.\n\nSullivan called the security agreement a \"bridge\" to when Ukraine is invited to join the NATO alliance -- a long-term priority of Zelenskyy's that the allies have said will first require an end to the Russia-Ukraine war and that Putin has steadfastly opposed.\n\nBiden's back-to-back trips to France and Italy amount to a rare doubleheader of diplomacy in the midst of the presidential election. The president will skip a Ukraine peace conference in Switzerland this weekend to jet to Los Angeles for a campaign fundraiser with big names from Hollywood. Vice President Kamala Harris will represent the U.S. at the conference.\n\nDespite the delays in military aid, the Biden administration on Tuesday announced it would send Ukraine another Patriot missile system to help fend off Russian strikes, two U.S. officials told The Associated Press. Biden approved the move, the officials told the AP, as Kyiv has desperately called for more air defenses in its battle against an intense Russian assault on the northeastern Kharkiv region.\n\nKirby said the U.S. would use the G7 summit to announce fresh sanctions and export control actions targeting those who have helped Russia procure what it needs for the war. He said the new measures would make it harder for financiers to support Russia's defense mechanism.\n\nUkraine and many of its supporters have called for the confiscation of $260 billion in Russian assets frozen outside the country after the Feb. 24, 2022, invasion. But European officials have resisted, citing legal and financial stability concerns. Most of the frozen assets are located in Europe.\n\nA European plan to just use the interest on the Russian funds would provide only a trickle of money every year -- about $2.5 billion to $3 billion at current interest rates, which would barely meet a month's financing needs for the Ukrainian government.\n\nTreasury Secretary Janet Yellen said recently that G7 finance ministers have been discussing the possibility of extending a loan to Ukraine and using the windfall profits of assets seized in Europe to pay it off.\n\nKirby said the U.S. was optimistic the group could agree on the matter.\n\nBiden is also expected to discuss economic concerns brought on by Chinese manufacturing overcapacity, how to use artificial intelligence in a way that maximizes benefits but still manages national security risks, and global migration.\n\nThe U.S. and other G7 nations are struggling to manage large influxes of migrants arriving for complicated reasons that include war, climate change and drought. Migration, and how nations cope with the growing numbers at their borders, has been a factor driving the far-right rise in some of Europe.\n\nSuperville reported from Bari, Italy.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8174553645", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "15:47:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T15:47:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T15:46:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.brandonsun.com/world/2024/06/12/biden-and-zelenskyy-will-sign-security-agreement-between-us-and-ukraine-when-they-meet-at-g7", "title": "Biden and Zelenskyy will sign security agreement between US and Ukraine when they meet at G7", "body": "I agree to the Terms and Conditions, Cookie and Privacy Policies, and CASL agreement.\n\nABOARD AIR FORCE ONE (AP) -- President Joe Biden and President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will sign a bilateral security agreement between the U.S. and Ukraine on Thursday when they meet on the sidelines of the Group of Seven summit, aiming to send signal to Russia of American resolve to supporting Kyiv, the White House said.\n\nNational Security Adviser Jake Sullivan told reporters that the agreement would not commit U.S. troops directly to Ukraine's defense against Russia's invasion -- a red line drawn by Biden, who is fearful of being drawn into direct conflict between the nuclear-armed powers.\n\n\"We want to demonstrate that the U.S. supports the people of Ukraine, that we stand with them and that we'll continue to help address their security needs,\" Sullivan said, adding \"this agreement will show our resolve.\"\n\nSullivan called the agreement a \"bridge\" to when Ukraine is invited to join the NATO alliance -- a long-term priority of Zelenskyy's that the allies have said will first require an end to the Russia-Ukraine war.\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- President Joe Biden headed to Italy on Wednesday for a summit of the world's leading democracies with an urgency to get big things done, including turning frozen Russian assets into billions of dollars to help Ukraine as it fights off Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\nThis year's Group of Seven summit comes three years after Biden declared at his first such gathering that America was back as a global leader following the disruptions to Western alliances that occurred when Donald Trump was president. Now, there's a chance this gathering could be the final G7 for Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of elections this year.\n\nBiden and his counterparts from Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related to the spread of artificial intelligence, migration, the Russian military's resurgence and China's economic might, among other topics. Pope Francis, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan are joining the gathering at the Borgo Egnazia resort in the Puglia region of southern Italy.\n\nThe summit, which opens Thursday, will play out after far-right parties across the continent racked up gains of surprising scale in just-concluded European Union elections. Those victories, coupled with upcoming elections in the United Kingdom, France and the United States, have rattled the global political establishment and added weightiness to this year's summit.\n\n\"You hear this a lot when you talk to U.S. and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether it's on China, whether it's on the assets, we may not have another chance,\" said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Council's GeoEconomics Center, an international affairs think tank. \"We don't know what the world will look like three months, six months, nine months from now.\"\n\nThe G7 is an informal bloc of industrialized democracies that meets annually to discuss shared issues and concerns. Biden is set to arrive in Italy on Wednesday night, his second trip outside the U.S. in as many weeks. The Democratic president was in France last week for a state visit in Paris and ceremonies in Normandy marking the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings in World War II.\n\nWhile last week's visit had a celebratory feel, this one will be dominated by pressing global issues, including how to keep financial support flowing to Ukraine as it fights Russia's invasion. Biden's trip also comes one day after his son Hunter was convicted on federal gun charges, a blow sure to weigh heavily on the president's mind.\n\nDespite pressing global challenges, White House national security spokesman John Kirby said there is still a sense of relief among world leaders in 2024 that \"America was back,\" referencing Biden's 2021 speech at the G7 in Cornwall, England.\n\n\"Biden's message then was that democracies need to step up and show they can deliver for their people,\" Kirby said. \"That's true now more than ever.\"\n\nKirby said the U.S. was prepared to work with democratically elected officials in the EU no matter who they are, though some of those being elevated have expressed far less support for Ukraine than current leaders.\n\n\"We have every confidence that regardless of who fills the seats in the European Parliament, we're going to continue to work closely with our EU partners on all the issues relative to our shared interests across the European continent,\" Kirby said. \"That includes supporting Ukraine.\"\n\nBiden and Zelenskyy, who met last week in Paris, will meet again Thursday on the sidelines of the summit to discuss continued support for the Eastern European nation, which is trying to fend off an intense Russian offensive in eastern areas of the country. They are expected to hold a joint news conference. Biden is also expected to meet with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, the pope and other leaders.\n\nBiden, who has been adamant that \"we will not walk away\" from Ukraine, last week publicly apologized to Zelenskyy for a monthslong delay by Congress in authorizing additional American military assistance. The delay allowed Russia to make gains on the battlefield.\n\nBiden's back-to-back trips to France and Italy amount to a rare doubleheader of diplomacy in the midst of the presidential election. The president will skip a Ukraine peace conference in Switzerland this weekend to jet to Los Angeles for a campaign fundraiser with big names from Hollywood. Vice President Kamala Harris will represent the U.S. at the conference.\n\nDespite the delays in military aid, the Biden administration on Tuesday announced it would send Ukraine another Patriot missile system to help fend off Russian strikes, two U.S. officials told The Associated Press. Biden approved the move, the officials told the AP, as Kyiv has desperately called for more air defenses in its battle against an intense Russian assault on the northeastern Kharkiv region.\n\nKirby said the U.S. would use the G7 summit to announce fresh sanctions and export control actions targeting those who have helped Russia procure what it needs for the war. He said the new measures would make it harder for financiers to support Russia's defense mechanism.\n\nUkraine and many of its supporters have called for the confiscation of $260 billion in Russian assets frozen outside the country after the Feb. 24, 2022, invasion. But European officials have resisted, citing legal and financial stability concerns. Most of the frozen assets are located in Europe.\n\nA European plan to just use the interest on the Russian funds would provide only a trickle of money every year -- about $2.5 billion to $3 billion at current interest rates, which would barely meet a month's financing needs for the Ukrainian government.\n\nTreasury Secretary Janet Yellen said recently that G7 finance ministers have been discussing the possibility of extending a loan to Ukraine and using the windfall profits of assets seized in Europe to pay it off.\n\nKirby said the U.S. was optimistic the group could agree on the matter.\n\nBiden is also expected to discuss economic concerns brought on by Chinese manufacturing overcapacity, how to use artificial intelligence in a way that maximizes benefits but still manages national security risks, and global migration.\n\nThe U.S. and other G7 nations are struggling to manage large influxes of migrants arriving for complicated reasons that include war, climate change and drought. Migration, and how nations cope with the growing numbers at their borders, has been a factor driving the far-right rise in some of Europe.", "source": {"uri": "brandonsun.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "2024-06-387430202", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "16:34:40", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T16:34:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T16:33:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.wapt.com/article/ukraine-us-security-agreement-g7/61085598", "title": "Biden and Zelenskyy will sign security agreement between US and Ukraine when they meet at G7", "body": "President Joe Biden and President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will sign a bilateral security agreement between the U.S. and Ukraine on Thursday when they meet on the sidelines of the Group of Seven summit, aiming to send signal to Russia of American resolve to supporting Kyiv, the White House said as Biden was headed to Italy.Related video above: President Biden makes first state visit to France, reaffirms commitment to UkraineNational security adviser Jake Sullivan told reporters that the agreement would not commit U.S. troops directly to Ukraine's defense against Russia's invasion - a red line drawn by Biden, who is fearful of being drawn into direct conflict between the nuclear-armed powers.\"We want to demonstrate that the U.S. supports the people of Ukraine, that we stand with them and that we'll continue to help address their security needs,\" Sullivan said, adding \"This agreement will show our resolve.\"Sullivan called the agreement a \"bridge\" to when Ukraine is invited to join the NATO alliance - a long-term priority of Zelenskyy's that the allies have said will first require an end to the Russia-Ukraine war.Biden heads to the summit of the world's leading democracies with an urgency to get big things done, including turning frozen Russian assets into billions of dollars to help Ukraine as it fights off Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.This year's Group of Seven summit comes three years after Biden declared at his first such gathering that America was back as a global leader following the disruptions to Western alliances that occurred when Donald Trump was president. Now, there's a chance this gathering could be the final G7 for Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of elections this year.Biden and his counterparts from Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related to the spread of artificial intelligence, migration, the Russian military's resurgence and China's economic might, among other topics. Pope Francis, Zelenskyy and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan are joining the gathering at the Borgo Egnazia resort in the Puglia region of southern Italy.The summit, which opens Thursday, will play out after far-right parties across the continent racked up gains of surprising scale in just-concluded European Union elections. Those victories, coupled with upcoming elections in the United Kingdom, France and the United States, have rattled the global political establishment and added weightiness to this year's summit.\"You hear this a lot when you talk to U.S. and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether it's on China, whether it's on the assets, we may not have another chance,\" said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Council's GeoEconomics Center, an international affairs think tank. \"We don't know what the world will look like three months, six months, nine months from now.\"The G7 is an informal bloc of industrialized democracies that meets annually to discuss shared issues and concerns. Biden is set to arrive in Italy on Wednesday night, his second trip outside the U.S. in as many weeks. The Democratic president was in France last week for a state visit in Paris and ceremonies in Normandy marking the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings in World War II.While last week's visit had a celebratory feel, this one will be dominated by pressing global issues, including how to keep financial support flowing to Ukraine as it fights Russia's invasion. Biden's trip also comes one day after his son Hunter was convicted on federal gun charges, a blow sure to weigh heavily on the president's mind.Video above: Ukrainian doctor finds peace through musicDespite pressing global challenges, White House national security spokesman John Kirby said there is still a sense of relief among world leaders in 2024 that \"America was back,\" referencing Biden's 2021 speech at the G7 in Cornwall, England.\"Biden's message then was that democracies need to step up and show they can deliver for their people,\" Kirby said. \"That's true now more than ever.\"Kirby said the U.S. was prepared to work with democratically elected officials in the EU no matter who they are, though some of those being elevated have expressed far less support for Ukraine than current leaders.\"We have every confidence that regardless of who fills the seats in the European Parliament, we're going to continue to work closely with our EU partners on all the issues relative to our shared interests across the European continent,\" Kirby said. \"That includes supporting Ukraine.\"Biden and Zelenskyy, who met last week in Paris, will meet again Thursday on the sidelines of the summit to discuss continued support for the Eastern European nation, which is trying to fend off an intense Russian offensive in eastern areas of the country. They are expected to hold a joint news conference. Biden is also expected to meet with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, the pope and other leaders.Biden, who has been adamant that \"we will not walk away\" from Ukraine, last week publicly apologized to Zelenskyy for a monthslong delay by Congress in authorizing additional American military assistance. The delay allowed Russia to make gains on the battlefield.Biden's back-to-back trips to France and Italy amount to a rare doubleheader of diplomacy in the midst of the presidential election. The president will skip a Ukraine peace conference in Switzerland this weekend to jet to Los Angeles for a campaign fundraiser with big names from Hollywood. Vice President Kamala Harris will represent the U.S. at the conference.Despite the delays in military aid, the Biden administration on Tuesday announced it would send Ukraine another Patriot missile system to help fend off Russian strikes, two U.S. officials told The Associated Press. Biden approved the move, the officials told the AP, as Kyiv has desperately called for more air defenses in its battle against an intense Russian assault on the northeastern Kharkiv region.Kirby said the U.S. would use the G7 summit to announce fresh sanctions and export control actions targeting those who have helped Russia procure what it needs for the war. He said the new measures would make it harder for financiers to support Russia's defense mechanism.Ukraine and many of its supporters have called for the confiscation of $260 billion in Russian assets frozen outside the country after the Feb. 24, 2022, invasion. But European officials have resisted, citing legal and financial stability concerns. Most of the frozen assets are located in Europe.A European plan to just use the interest on the Russian funds would provide only a trickle of money every year -- about $2.5 billion to $3 billion at current interest rates, which would barely meet a month's financing needs for the Ukrainian government.Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said recently that G7 finance ministers have been discussing the possibility of extending a loan to Ukraine and using the windfall profits of assets seized in Europe to pay it off.Video above: Why are war crimes hard to prosecute?Kirby said the U.S. was optimistic the group could agree on the matter.Biden is also expected to discuss economic concerns brought on by Chinese manufacturing overcapacity, how to use artificial intelligence in a way that maximizes benefits but still manages national security risks, and global migration.The U.S. and other G7 nations are struggling to manage large influxes of migrants arriving for complicated reasons that include war, climate change and drought. Migration, and how nations cope with the growing numbers at their borders, has been a factor driving the far-right rise in some of Europe.___Superville reported from Bari, Italy.\n\nPresident Joe Biden and President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will sign a bilateral security agreement between the U.S. and Ukraine on Thursday when they meet on the sidelines of the Group of Seven summit, aiming to send signal to Russia of American resolve to supporting Kyiv, the White House said as Biden was headed to Italy.\n\nRelated video above: President Biden makes first state visit to France, reaffirms commitment to Ukraine\n\nNational security adviser Jake Sullivan told reporters that the agreement would not commit U.S. troops directly to Ukraine's defense against Russia's invasion - a red line drawn by Biden, who is fearful of being drawn into direct conflict between the nuclear-armed powers.\n\n\"We want to demonstrate that the U.S. supports the people of Ukraine, that we stand with them and that we'll continue to help address their security needs,\" Sullivan said, adding \"This agreement will show our resolve.\"\n\nSullivan called the agreement a \"bridge\" to when Ukraine is invited to join the NATO alliance - a long-term priority of Zelenskyy's that the allies have said will first require an end to the Russia-Ukraine war.\n\nBiden heads to the summit of the world's leading democracies with an urgency to get big things done, including turning frozen Russian assets into billions of dollars to help Ukraine as it fights off Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\nThis year's Group of Seven summit comes three years after Biden declared at his first such gathering that America was back as a global leader following the disruptions to Western alliances that occurred when Donald Trump was president. Now, there's a chance this gathering could be the final G7 for Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of elections this year.\n\nBiden and his counterparts from Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related to the spread of artificial intelligence, migration, the Russian military's resurgence and China's economic might, among other topics. Pope Francis, Zelenskyy and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan are joining the gathering at the Borgo Egnazia resort in the Puglia region of southern Italy.\n\nThe summit, which opens Thursday, will play out after far-right parties across the continent racked up gains of surprising scale in just-concluded European Union elections. Those victories, coupled with upcoming elections in the United Kingdom, France and the United States, have rattled the global political establishment and added weightiness to this year's summit.\n\n\"You hear this a lot when you talk to U.S. and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether it's on China, whether it's on the assets, we may not have another chance,\" said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Council's GeoEconomics Center, an international affairs think tank. \"We don't know what the world will look like three months, six months, nine months from now.\"\n\nThe G7 is an informal bloc of industrialized democracies that meets annually to discuss shared issues and concerns. Biden is set to arrive in Italy on Wednesday night, his second trip outside the U.S. in as many weeks. The Democratic president was in France last week for a state visit in Paris and ceremonies in Normandy marking the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings in World War II.\n\nWhile last week's visit had a celebratory feel, this one will be dominated by pressing global issues, including how to keep financial support flowing to Ukraine as it fights Russia's invasion. Biden's trip also comes one day after his son Hunter was convicted on federal gun charges, a blow sure to weigh heavily on the president's mind.\n\nVideo above: Ukrainian doctor finds peace through music\n\nDespite pressing global challenges, White House national security spokesman John Kirby said there is still a sense of relief among world leaders in 2024 that \"America was back,\" referencing Biden's 2021 speech at the G7 in Cornwall, England.\n\n\"Biden's message then was that democracies need to step up and show they can deliver for their people,\" Kirby said. \"That's true now more than ever.\"\n\nKirby said the U.S. was prepared to work with democratically elected officials in the EU no matter who they are, though some of those being elevated have expressed far less support for Ukraine than current leaders.\n\n\"We have every confidence that regardless of who fills the seats in the European Parliament, we're going to continue to work closely with our EU partners on all the issues relative to our shared interests across the European continent,\" Kirby said. \"That includes supporting Ukraine.\"\n\nBiden and Zelenskyy, who met last week in Paris, will meet again Thursday on the sidelines of the summit to discuss continued support for the Eastern European nation, which is trying to fend off an intense Russian offensive in eastern areas of the country. They are expected to hold a joint news conference. Biden is also expected to meet with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, the pope and other leaders.\n\nBiden, who has been adamant that \"we will not walk away\" from Ukraine, last week publicly apologized to Zelenskyy for a monthslong delay by Congress in authorizing additional American military assistance. The delay allowed Russia to make gains on the battlefield.\n\nBiden's back-to-back trips to France and Italy amount to a rare doubleheader of diplomacy in the midst of the presidential election. The president will skip a Ukraine peace conference in Switzerland this weekend to jet to Los Angeles for a campaign fundraiser with big names from Hollywood. Vice President Kamala Harris will represent the U.S. at the conference.\n\nDespite the delays in military aid, the Biden administration on Tuesday announced it would send Ukraine another Patriot missile system to help fend off Russian strikes, two U.S. officials told The Associated Press. Biden approved the move, the officials told the AP, as Kyiv has desperately called for more air defenses in its battle against an intense Russian assault on the northeastern Kharkiv region.\n\nKirby said the U.S. would use the G7 summit to announce fresh sanctions and export control actions targeting those who have helped Russia procure what it needs for the war. He said the new measures would make it harder for financiers to support Russia's defense mechanism.\n\nUkraine and many of its supporters have called for the confiscation of $260 billion in Russian assets frozen outside the country after the Feb. 24, 2022, invasion. But European officials have resisted, citing legal and financial stability concerns. Most of the frozen assets are located in Europe.\n\nA European plan to just use the interest on the Russian funds would provide only a trickle of money every year -- about $2.5 billion to $3 billion at current interest rates, which would barely meet a month's financing needs for the Ukrainian government.\n\nTreasury Secretary Janet Yellen said recently that G7 finance ministers have been discussing the possibility of extending a loan to Ukraine and using the windfall profits of assets seized in Europe to pay it off.\n\nVideo above: Why are war crimes hard to prosecute?\n\nKirby said the U.S. was optimistic the group could agree on the matter.\n\nBiden is also expected to discuss economic concerns brought on by Chinese manufacturing overcapacity, how to use artificial intelligence in a way that maximizes benefits but still manages national security risks, and global migration.\n\nThe U.S. and other G7 nations are struggling to manage large influxes of migrants arriving for complicated reasons that include war, climate change and drought. Migration, and how nations cope with the growing numbers at their borders, has been a factor driving the far-right rise in some of Europe.", "source": {"uri": "wapt.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8174326036", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "13:19:34", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T13:19:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T13:18:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13522203/Fresh-France-trip-Biden-heads-Europe-G7-summit-talk-Ukraine-support-migration.html", "title": "Fresh off France trip, Biden heads back to Europe for G7 summit to...", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) - President Joe Biden heads to Italy on Wednesday for a summit of the world's leading democracies with an urgency to get big things done, including turning frozen Russian assets into billions of dollars to help Ukraine as it fights off Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\nThis year's Group of Seven summit comes three years after Biden declared at his first such gathering that America was back as a global leader following the disruptions to Western alliances that occurred under President Donald Trump. Now, there's a chance this gathering could be the final G7 for Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of elections this year.\n\nBiden and his counterparts from Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related to the spread of artificial intelligence, migration, the Russian military\u00b4s resurgence and China's economic might, among other topics. Pope Francis, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan are joining the gathering at the Borgo Egnazia resort in the Puglia, a region of southern Italy.\n\nThe summit, which opens Thursday, will play out after far-right parties across the continent racked up gains of surprising scale in just-concluded European Union elections. Those victories - coupled with upcoming elections in the United Kingdom, France and the United States - have rattled the global political establishment and added weightiness to this year's summit.\n\n\"You hear this a lot when you talk to U.S. and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether it's on China, whether it's on the assets, we may not have another chance,\" said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Council\u00b4s GeoEconomics Center, an international affairs think tank. \"We don\u00b4t know what the world will look like three months, six months, nine months from now.\"\n\nThe G7 is an informal bloc of industrialized democracies that meets annually to discuss shared issues and concerns. Biden is set to arrive in Italy on Wednesday night, his second trip outside the U.S. in as many weeks. The Democratic president was in France last week for a state visit in Paris and ceremonies in Normandy marking the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings in World War II.\n\nPresident Joe Biden is escorted by Air Force Col. Angela Ochoa, Commander, 89th Airlift Wing, as he arrives at Andrews Air Force Base, Md., Wednesday, June 12, 2024. Biden is headed to Italy for the G7 summit. Biden's granddaughter, Finnegan Biden, walks left. (AP Photo/Alex Brandon)\n\nWhile last week\u00b4s visit had a celebratory feel, this one will be dominated by pressing global issues, including how to keep financial support flowing to Ukraine as it fights Russia\u00b4s invasion. Biden's trip also comes one day after his son Hunter was convicted on federal gun charges, a blow sure to weigh heavily on the president's mind.\n\nDespite pressing global challenges, White House national security spokesman John Kirby said there is still a sense of relief among world leaders in 2024 that \"America was back,\" referencing Biden's 2021 speech at the G7 in Cornwall, England.\n\n\"Biden\u00b4s message then was that democracies need to step up and show they can deliver for their people,\" Kirby said. \"That's true now more than ever.\"\n\nKirby said the U.S. was prepared to work with democratically elected officials in the EU no matter who they are, though some of those being elevated have expressed far less support for Ukraine than current leaders.\n\n\"We have every confidence that regardless of who fills the seats in the European Parliament, we\u00b4re going to continue to work closely with our EU partners on all the issues relative to our shared interests across the European continent,\" Kirby said. \"That includes supporting Ukraine.\"\n\nBiden and Zelenskyy, who met last week in Paris, will meet again Thursday on the sidelines of the summit to discuss continued support for the Eastern European nation, which is trying to fend off an intense Russian offensive in eastern areas of the country. They are expected to hold a joint news conference. Biden is also expected to meet one-on-one with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, the pope and other leaders.\n\nBiden, who has been adamant that \"we will not walk away\" from Ukraine, last week publicly apologized to Zelenskyy for a monthslong delay by Congress in authorizing additional American military assistance. The delay allowed Russia to make gains on the battlefield.\n\nBiden\u00b4s back-to-back trips to France and Italy amount to a rare doubleheader of international diplomacy in the midst of the presidential election. The president will skip a Ukraine peace conference in Switzerland this weekend to jet to Los Angeles for a campaign fundraiser with big names from Hollywood. Vice President Kamala Harris will represent the U.S. at the Swiss conference.\n\nDespite the delays in military aid, the Biden administration on Tuesday announced it would send Ukraine another Patriot missile system to help fend off Russian strikes, two U.S. officials told The Associated Press. Biden approved the move, the officials told the AP, as Kyiv has desperately called for more air defenses in its battle against an intense Russian assault on the northeastern Kharkiv region.\n\nKirby said the U.S. would use the G7 summit to announce fresh sanctions and export control actions targeting those who have helped Russia procure what it needs for the war. He said the new measures would make it harder for financiers to support Russia's defense mechanism.\n\nUkraine and many of its supporters have called for the confiscation of $260 billion in Russian assets frozen outside the country after the Feb. 24, 2022, invasion. But European officials have resisted, citing legal and financial stability concerns. Most of the frozen assets are located in Europe.\n\nA European plan to just use the interest on the Russian funds would provide only a trickle of money every year - about $2.5 billion to $3 billion at current interest rates, which would barely meet a month\u00b4s financing needs for the Ukrainian government.\n\nTreasury Secretary Janet Yellen said recently that G7 finance ministers have been discussing the possibility of extending a loan to Ukraine and using the windfall profits of assets seized in Europe to pay it off.\n\nKirby said the U.S. was optimistic the group could agree on the matter.\n\nBiden is also expected to discuss economic concerns brought on by Chinese manufacturing overcapacity, how to use artificial intelligence in a way that maximizes benefits but still manages national security risks, and global migration.\n\nThe U.S. and other G7 nations are struggling to manage large influxes of migrants arriving for complicated reasons that include war, climate change and drought. Migration, and how nations cope with the growing numbers at their borders, has been a factor driving the far-right rise in some of Europe.\n\nSuperville reported from Bari, Italy.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8175130509", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "01:02:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T01:02:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T01:00:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/politics/2741808/", "title": "Biden returns to Europe for G7 summit to discuss support for Ukraine, migration - ExBulletin", "body": "WASHINGTON- President Joe Biden is traveling to Italy on Wednesday for a summit of the world's main democracies with the urgency of accomplishing great things, in particular transforming Russian assets frozen in billions of dollars to help Ukraine fight against Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\nThis year Group of Seven Summit comes three years after Biden declared at his first such rally that America was back as a world leader following the disruptions to Western alliances that occurred under President Donald Trump. It is now possible that this gathering could be the last G7 for Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of this year's elections.\n\nBiden and his counterparts from Canada, the United Kingdom, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related to the diffusion of artificial intelligence, migration, the resurgence of the Russian military and China's economic power, among other topics. Pope Francis, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan join the gathering at the resort town of Borgo Egnazia in Puglia, a region in southern Italy.\n\nThe summit, which opens on Thursday, will come after far-right parties across the continent racked up gains of surprising magnitude at the just-concluded summit. European Union elections. These victories, coupled with upcoming elections in the United Kingdom, France and the United States, have shaken the global political establishment and added weight to this year's summit.\n\nYou hear this a lot when talking to U.S. and European officials: If we can't get it done now, whether on China or on assets, we may not get another chance, said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Councils GeoEconomics Center, an international affairs think tank. We don't know what the world will look like in three months, six months, nine months. \"\n\nThe G7 is an informal bloc of industrialized democracies that meets annually to discuss common issues and concerns. Biden is expected to arrive in Italy on Wednesday evening, his second trip outside the United States in as many weeks. The Democratic president was in France last week for a state visit in Paris and the ceremonies in Normandy marking the 80th anniversary of the Landing during WWII.\n\nAlthough last week's visit was celebratory, it will be dominated by pressing global issues, including how to maintain financial support for Ukraine as it struggles. Invasion of Russia. Biden's trip also comes a day after his son Hunter was convicted of federal gun chargesa hard blow that will certainly weigh heavily on the president's mind.\n\nDespite pressing global challenges, White House national security spokesman John Kirby said there is still a sense of relief among world leaders in 2024 because \"America was back\" referencing Biden's 2021 speech at the G7 in Cornwall, England.\n\nBiden's message then was that democracies must step up and show they can meet the expectations of their people, Kirby said. This is more true than ever.\n\nKirby said the United States is willing to work with democratically elected officials in the EU, whoever they may be, even if some of those who have been promoted have expressed far less support for Ukraine than current leaders.\n\nWe are confident that, whoever takes the seats in the European Parliament, we will continue to work closely with our EU partners on all issues relating to our common interests across the European continent,\" Kirby said . \"This includes support for Ukraine. .\n\nBiden and Zelenskyy, who met last week in Pariswill meet again on the sidelines of the summit on Thursday to discuss continued support for the Eastern European nation as it attempts to fend off an intense crisis. Russian offensive in the eastern regions of the country. They are expected to hold a joint press conference. Biden is also expected to meet face-to-face Giorgia Meloni, Italian Prime Ministerthe pope and other leaders.\n\nBiden, who insisted we would not leave Ukraine, last week publicly apologized to Zelensky of Congress' months-long delay in authorizing additional U.S. military aid. This delay allowed Russia to battlefield gains.\n\nBiden's back-to-back trips to France and Italy constitute a rare double bill of international diplomacy in the middle of the presidential election. The president will jump a peace conference in Ukraine in Switzerland this weekend to fly to Los Angeles for a fundraising campaign with big names from Hollywood. Vice President Kamala Harris will represent the United States at the Swiss conference.\n\nDespite delays in providing military aid, the Biden administration announced Tuesday that it would do so. send Ukraine another Patriot missile system to help repel Russian strikes, two U.S. officials told The Associated Press. Biden approved the move, the officials told the AP, as kyiv has desperately called for more air defenses in its fight against an intense Russian attack on the northeastern Kharkiv region.\n\nKirby said the United States would use the G7 summit to announce new sanctions and export control measures targeting those who helped Russia procure what it needs for the war. He said the new measures would make it harder for financiers to support Russia's defense mechanism.\n\nUkraine and many of its supporters have called for the confiscation of $260 billion in Russian assets frozen outside the country after the Feb. 24, 2022, invasion. But European officials have resisted, citing stability concerns legal and financial. Most of the frozen assets are in Europe.\n\nA European plan to use only interest from Russian funds would provide only a trickle of money each year, about $2.5-3 billion at current interest rates, barely enough to meet the needs of one-month funding from the Ukrainian government.\n\nTreasury Secretary Janet Yellen said recently that G7 finance ministers were discussing the possibility of providing a loan to Ukraine and using windfall profits from assets seized in Europe to repay it.\n\nKirby said the United States was optimistic the group would be able to agree on the issue.\n\nBiden is also expected to discuss economic concerns caused by Chinese manufacturing overcapacity, how to use artificial intelligence in ways that maximize profits while managing national security risks, and global migration.\n\nThe United States and other G7 countries are struggling to manage massive influxes of migrants arriving for complex reasons such as war, climate change and drought. Migration and how countries deal with the growing number of people at their borders has been a factor in the rise of the far right in certain regions of Europe.", "source": {"uri": "exbulletin.com", {"uri": "2024-06-387396532", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "16:01:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T16:01:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T15:34:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.kimt.com/news/biden-and-zelenskyy-will-sign-security-agreement-between-us-and-ukraine-when-they-meet-at/article_006e46ee-14f5-5e1b-8e65-11371b275f5e.html", "title": "Biden and Zelenskyy will sign security agreement between US and Ukraine when they meet at G7", "body": "ABOARD AIR FORCE ONE (AP) -- President Joe Biden and President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will sign a bilateral security agreement between the U.S. and Ukraine on Thursday when they meet on the sidelines of the Group of Seven summit, aiming to send signal to Russia of American resolve to supporting Kyiv, the White House said as Biden was headed to Italy.\n\nNational security adviser Jake Sullivan told reporters that the agreement would not commit U.S. troops directly to Ukraine's defense against Russia's invasion -- a red line drawn by Biden, who is fearful of being drawn into direct conflict between the nuclear-armed powers.\n\n\"We want to demonstrate that the U.S. supports the people of Ukraine, that we stand with them and that we'll continue to help address their security needs,\" Sullivan said, adding \"this agreement will show our resolve.\"\n\nSullivan called the agreement a \"bridge\" to when Ukraine is invited to join the NATO alliance -- a long-term priority of Zelenskyy's that the allies have said will first require an end to the Russia-Ukraine war.\n\nBiden heads to the summit of the world's leading democracies with an urgency to get big things done, including turning frozen Russian assets into billions of dollars to help Ukraine as it fights off Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\nThis year's Group of Seven summit comes three years after Biden declared at his first such gathering that America was back as a global leader following the disruptions to Western alliances that occurred when Donald Trump was president. Now, there's a chance this gathering could be the final G7 for Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of elections this year.\n\nBiden and his counterparts from Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related to the spread of artificial intelligence, migration, the Russian military's resurgence and China's economic might, among other topics. Pope Francis, Zelenskyy and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan are joining the gathering at the Borgo Egnazia resort in the Puglia region of southern Italy.\n\nThe summit, which opens Thursday, will play out after far-right parties across the continent racked up gains of surprising scale in just-concluded European Union elections. Those victories, coupled with upcoming elections in the United Kingdom, France and the United States, have rattled the global political establishment and added weightiness to this year's summit.\n\n\"You hear this a lot when you talk to U.S. and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether it's on China, whether it's on the assets, we may not have another chance,\" said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Council's GeoEconomics Center, an international affairs think tank. \"We don't know what the world will look like three months, six months, nine months from now.\"\n\nThe G7 is an informal bloc of industrialized democracies that meets annually to discuss shared issues and concerns. Biden is set to arrive in Italy on Wednesday night, his second trip outside the U.S. in as many weeks. The Democratic president was in France last week for a state visit in Paris and ceremonies in Normandy marking the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings in World War II.\n\nWhile last week's visit had a celebratory feel, this one will be dominated by pressing global issues, including how to keep financial support flowing to Ukraine as it fights Russia's invasion. Biden's trip also comes one day after his son Hunter was convicted on federal gun charges, a blow sure to weigh heavily on the president's mind.\n\nDespite pressing global challenges, White House national security spokesman John Kirby said there is still a sense of relief among world leaders in 2024 that \"America was back,\" referencing Biden's 2021 speech at the G7 in Cornwall, England.\n\n\"Biden's message then was that democracies need to step up and show they can deliver for their people,\" Kirby said. \"That's true now more than ever.\"\n\nKirby said the U.S. was prepared to work with democratically elected officials in the EU no matter who they are, though some of those being elevated have expressed far less support for Ukraine than current leaders.\n\n\"We have every confidence that regardless of who fills the seats in the European Parliament, we're going to continue to work closely with our EU partners on all the issues relative to our shared interests across the European continent,\" Kirby said. \"That includes supporting Ukraine.\"\n\nBiden and Zelenskyy, who met last week in Paris, will meet again Thursday on the sidelines of the summit to discuss continued support for the Eastern European nation, which is trying to fend off an intense Russian offensive in eastern areas of the country. They are expected to hold a joint news conference. Biden is also expected to meet with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, the pope and other leaders.\n\nBiden, who has been adamant that \"we will not walk away\" from Ukraine, last week publicly apologized to Zelenskyy for a monthslong delay by Congress in authorizing additional American military assistance. The delay allowed Russia to make gains on the battlefield.\n\nBiden's back-to-back trips to France and Italy amount to a rare doubleheader of diplomacy in the midst of the presidential election. The president will skip a Ukraine peace conference in Switzerland this weekend to jet to Los Angeles for a campaign fundraiser with big names from Hollywood. Vice President Kamala Harris will represent the U.S. at the conference.\n\nDespite the delays in military aid, the Biden administration on Tuesday announced it would send Ukraine another Patriot missile system to help fend off Russian strikes, two U.S. officials told The Associated Press. Biden approved the move, the officials told the AP, as Kyiv has desperately called for more air defenses in its battle against an intense Russian assault on the northeastern Kharkiv region.\n\nKirby said the U.S. would use the G7 summit to announce fresh sanctions and export control actions targeting those who have helped Russia procure what it needs for the war. He said the new measures would make it harder for financiers to support Russia's defense mechanism.\n\nUkraine and many of its supporters have called for the confiscation of $260 billion in Russian assets frozen outside the country after the Feb. 24, 2022, invasion. But European officials have resisted, citing legal and financial stability concerns. Most of the frozen assets are located in Europe.\n\nA European plan to just use the interest on the Russian funds would provide only a trickle of money every year -- about $2.5 billion to $3 billion at current interest rates, which would barely meet a month's financing needs for the Ukrainian government.\n\nTreasury Secretary Janet Yellen said recently that G7 finance ministers have been discussing the possibility of extending a loan to Ukraine and using the windfall profits of assets seized in Europe to pay it off.\n\nKirby said the U.S. was optimistic the group could agree on the matter.\n\nBiden is also expected to discuss economic concerns brought on by Chinese manufacturing overcapacity, how to use artificial intelligence in a way that maximizes benefits but still manages national security risks, and global migration.\n\nThe U.S. and other G7 nations are struggling to manage large influxes of migrants arriving for complicated reasons that include war, climate change and drought. Migration, and how nations cope with the growing numbers at their borders, has been a factor driving the far-right rise in some of Europe.", "source": {"uri": "kimt.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KIMT-TV 3 Mason City"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@kimt.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9644722", "eventUri": "eng-9644722", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.615686274509804, "wgt": 193, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-06-387433661", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "16:38:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T16:38:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T16:38:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/2/11/525424/World/War-in-Ukraine/Biden,-Zelensky-to-sign-security-deal-at-G-White-H.aspx", "title": "Biden, Zelensky to sign security deal at G7: White House - War in Ukraine - World", "body": "US President Joe Biden arrives to board Air Force One at Joint Base Andrews in Maryland. AFP\n\n\"Tomorrow, President Biden and President Zelensky will sit down to discuss our strong support for Ukraine now and into the future,\" National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan told reporters traveling with Biden to Italy.\n\n\"Following that meeting, the leaders will sign a bilateral security agreement, making clear our support will last long into the future.\"\n\nThe deal would not include any commitment to use US forces but would involve weapons and assistance for Ukraine, which Washington has backed since the 2022 invasion, said Sullivan.\n\nIt was similar to other deals signed between Ukraine and 15 other allies, he added.\n\n\"Any lasting peace in Ukraine has to be under its own ability to defend itself,\" Sullivan said.\n\n\"By signing this, we'll also be sending Russia a signal of our resolve to Vladimir Putin. He thinks that he can help mask the coalition supporting Ukraine. He's wrong.\"\n\nKyiv swiftly welcomed news of the deal.\n\n\"We have come a long way in our cooperation with the United States, and the entire team has done a great job to make this future agreement possible,\" said Andriy Yermak, the head of Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky's office.\n\nBiden headed to Italy on Wednesday for a summit of the world's leading democracies with an urgency to get big things done, including turning frozen Russian assets into billions of dollars to help Ukraine as it fights off Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\nThis year's Group of Seven summit comes three years after Biden declared at his first such gathering that America was back as a global leader following the disruptions to Western alliances that occurred when Donald Trump was president. Now, there's a chance this gathering could be the final G7 for Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of elections this year.\n\nBiden and his counterparts from Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related to the spread of artificial intelligence, migration, the Russian military's resurgence and China's economic might, among other topics. Pope Francis, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan are joining the gathering at the Borgo Egnazia resort in the Puglia region of southern Italy.\n\nThe summit, which opens Thursday, will play out after far-right parties across the continent racked up gains of surprising scale in just-concluded European Union elections. Those victories, coupled with upcoming elections in the United Kingdom, France and the United States, have rattled the global political establishment and added weightiness to this year's summit.\n\n\"You hear this a lot when you talk to US and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether it's on China, whether it's on the assets, we may not have another chance,\" said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Council's GeoEconomics Center, an international affairs think tank. \"We don't know what the world will look like three months, six months, nine months from now.\"\n\nThe G7 is an informal bloc of industrialized democracies that meets annually to discuss shared issues and concerns. Biden is set to arrive in Italy on Wednesday night, his second trip outside the US in as many weeks. The Democratic president was in France last week for a state visit in Paris and ceremonies in Normandy marking the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings in World War II.\n\nWhile last week's visit had a celebratory feel, this one will be dominated by pressing global issues, including how to keep financial support flowing to Ukraine as it fights Russia's invasion. Biden's trip also comes one day after his son Hunter was convicted on federal gun charges, a blow sure to weigh heavily on the president's mind.\n\nDespite pressing global challenges, White House national security spokesman John Kirby said there is still a sense of relief among world leaders in 2024 that \"America was back,\" referencing Biden's 2021 speech at the G7 in Cornwall, England.\n\n\"Biden's message then was that democracies need to step up and show they can deliver for their people,\" Kirby said. \"That's true now more than ever.\"\n\nKirby said the US was prepared to work with democratically elected officials in the EU no matter who they are, though some of those being elevated have expressed far less support for Ukraine than current leaders.\n\n\"We have every confidence that regardless of who fills the seats in the European Parliament, we're going to continue to work closely with our EU partners on all the issues relative to our shared interests across the European continent,\" Kirby said. \"That includes supporting Ukraine.\"\n\nBiden and Zelenskyy, who met last week in Paris, will meet again Thursday on the sidelines of the summit to discuss continued support for the Eastern European nation, which is trying to fend off an intense Russian offensive in eastern areas of the country. They are expected to hold a joint news conference. Biden is also expected to meet with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, the pope and other leaders.\n\nBiden, who has been adamant that \"we will not walk away\" from Ukraine, last week publicly apologized to Zelenskyy for a monthslong delay by Congress in authorizing additional American military assistance. The delay allowed Russia to make gains on the battlefield.\n\nBiden's back-to-back trips to France and Italy amount to a rare doubleheader of diplomacy in the midst of the presidential election. The president will skip a Ukraine peace conference in Switzerland this weekend to jet to Los Angeles for a campaign fundraiser with big names from Hollywood. Vice President Kamala Harris will represent the US at the conference.\n\nDespite the delays in military aid, the Biden administration on Tuesday announced it would send Ukraine another Patriot missile system to help fend off Russian strikes, two US officials told The Associated Press. Biden approved the move, the officials told the AP, as Kyiv has desperately called for more air defenses in its battle against an intense Russian assault on the northeastern Kharkiv region.\n\nKirby said the US would use the G7 summit to announce fresh sanctions and export control actions targeting those who have helped Russia procure what it needs for the war. He said the new measures would make it harder for financiers to support Russia's defense mechanism.\n\nUkraine and many of its supporters have called for the confiscation of $260 billion in Russian assets frozen outside the country after the Feb. 24, 2022, invasion. But European officials have resisted, citing legal and financial stability concerns. Most of the frozen assets are located in Europe.\n\nA European plan to just use the interest on the Russian funds would provide only a trickle of money every year -- about $2.5 billion to $3 billion at current interest rates, which would barely meet a month's financing needs for the Ukrainian government.\n\nTreasury Secretary Janet Yellen said recently that G7 finance ministers have been discussing the possibility of extending a loan to Ukraine and using the windfall profits of assets seized in Europe to pay it off.\n\nKirby said the US was optimistic the group could agree on the matter.\n\nBiden is also expected to discuss economic concerns brought on by Chinese manufacturing overcapacity, how to use artificial intelligence in a way that maximizes benefits but still manages national security risks, and global migration.\n\nThe US and other G7 nations are struggling to manage large influxes of migrants arriving for complicated reasons that include war, climate change and drought. Migration, and how nations cope with the growing numbers at their borders, has been a factor driving the far-right rise in some of Europe.", "source": {"uri": "english.ahram.org.eg", "dataType":
