"https://english.ahram.org.eg/Media/News/2024/6/12/41_2024-638538148200487902-48.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9644722", "eventUri": "eng-9644722", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.3176470588235294, "wgt": 193, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8174703703", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "17:35:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T17:35:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T17:34:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.firstpost.com/world/joe-biden-and-volodymyr-zelenskyy-to-sign-security-pact-at-g7-showcasing-us-resolve-to-russia-13781900.html", "title": "Joe Biden and Volodymyr Zelenskyy to sign security pact at G7, showcasing US resolve to Russia", "body": "(File) Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and US President Joe Biden. Image courtesy White House\n\nBiden and Zelenskyy will sign a security agreement between the US and Ukraine when they meet at G7\n\nBy DARLENE SUPERVILLE and COLLEEN LONG Associated Press\n\nABOARD AIR FORCE ONE: President Joe Biden and President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will sign a bilateral security agreement between the US and Ukraine on Thursday when they meet on the sidelines of the Group of Seven summit in Italy, aiming to send a signal to Russia of American resolve in supporting Kyiv, the White House said as Biden was headed to Europe.\n\nNational security adviser Jake Sullivan said the agreement would not commit US troops directly to Ukraine's defence against Russia's invasion -- a red line drawn by Biden, who's fearful of being pulled into direct conflict between the nuclear-armed powers. Announcement of the agreement comes as Biden heads to the summit of the world's leading democracies with an urgency to get big things done, including turning frozen Russian assets into billions of dollars to help Ukraine fight Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\n\"We want to demonstrate that the U.S. supports the people of Ukraine, that we stand with them and that we'll continue to help address their security needs,\" Sullivan said, adding \"this agreement will show our resolve.\"\n\nThis year's meeting comes three years after Biden declared at his first such gathering that America was back as a global leader following the disruptions to Western alliances that occurred when Donald Trump was president. Now, there's a chance this gathering could be the final G7 for Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of elections this year.\n\nBiden and his counterparts from Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related artificial intelligence, migration, the Russian military's resurgence and China's economic might, among other topics. Pope Francis, Zelenskyy and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan are joining the gathering at the Borgo Egnazia resort in the Puglia region of southern Italy.\n\nThe summit, opening Thursday, will play out after far-right parties across the continent racked up gains of surprising scale in just-concluded European Union elections. Those victories, coupled with upcoming elections in the United Kingdom, France and the United States, have rattled the global political establishment and added weightiness to this year's summit.\n\n\"You hear this a lot when you talk to US and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether it's on China, whether it's on the assets, we may not have another chance,\" said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Council's GeoEconomics Center, an international affairs think tank. \"We don't know what the world will look like three months, six months, nine months from now.\"\n\nThe G7 is an informal bloc of industrialised democracies that meets annually to discuss shared issues and concerns. Biden will arrive in Italy on Wednesday night, his second trip outside the U.S. in as many weeks. The Democratic president was in France last week for a state visit in Paris and ceremonies in Normandy marking the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings in World War II.\n\nWhile last week's visit had a celebratory feel, this one will be dominated by pressing global issues, including how to keep financial support flowing to Ukraine as it fights Russia's invasion. Biden's trip comes a day after his son Hunter was convicted on federal gun charges, a blow sure to weigh heavily on the president's mind.\n\nDespite pressing global challenges, White House national security spokesman John Kirby said there's still a sense of relief among world leaders in 2024 that \"America was back,\" referencing Biden's 2021 speech at the G7 in England.\n\n\"Biden's message then was that democracies need to step up and show they can deliver for their people,\" Kirby said. \"That's true now more than ever.\"\n\nKirby said the US was prepared to work with democratically elected officials in the EU no matter who they are, though some of those being elevated have expressed far less support for Ukraine than current leaders.\n\n\"We have every confidence that regardless of who fills the seats in the European Parliament, we're going to continue to work closely with our EU partners on all the issues relative to our shared interests across the European continent,\" Kirby said. \"That includes supporting Ukraine.\"\n\nBiden and Zelenskyy, who met last week in Paris, will meet again discuss continued support for the Eastern European nation, which is trying to fend off an intense Russian offensive in eastern areas of the country. They're expected to hold a joint news conference. Biden is also expected to meet with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, the pope and other leaders.\n\nBiden, who's been adamant \"we will not walk away\" from Ukraine, last week publicly apologized to Zelenskyy for a monthslong delay by Congress in authorizing additional American military assistance. The delay allowed Russia to make gains on the battlefield.\n\nSullivan called the security agreement a \"bridge\" to when Ukraine is invited to join the NATO alliance -- a long-term priority of Zelenskyy's that the allies have said will first require an end to the Russia-Ukraine war and that Putin has steadfastly opposed.\n\nBiden's back-to-back trips to France and Italy amount to a rare doubleheader of diplomacy in the midst of the presidential election. The president will skip a Ukraine peace conference in Switzerland this weekend to jet to Los Angeles for a campaign fundraiser with big names from Hollywood. Vice President Kamala Harris will represent the U.S. at the conference.\n\nDespite the delays in military aid, the Biden administration on Tuesday announced it would send Ukraine another Patriot missile system to help fend off Russian strikes, two US officials told The Associated Press. Biden approved the move, the officials told the AP, as Kyiv has desperately called for more air defenses in its battle against an intense Russian assault on the northeastern Kharkiv region.\n\nKirby said the U.S. would use the G7 summit to announce fresh sanctions and export control actions targeting those who have helped Russia procure what it needs for the war. He said the new measures would make it harder for financiers to support Russia's defense mechanism.\n\nUkraine and many of its supporters have called for the confiscation of $260 billion in Russian assets frozen outside the country after the Feb. 24, 2022, invasion. But European officials have resisted, citing legal and financial stability concerns. Most of the frozen assets are located in Europe.\n\nA European plan to just use the interest on the Russian funds would provide only a trickle of money every year -- about $2.5 billion to $3 billion at current interest rates, which would barely meet a month's financing needs for the Ukrainian government.\n\nTreasury Secretary Janet Yellen said recently that G7 finance ministers have been discussing the possibility of extending a loan to Ukraine and using the windfall profits of assets seized in Europe to pay it off.\n\nKirby said the U.S. was optimistic the group could agree on the matter.\n\nBiden is also expected to discuss economic concerns brought on by Chinese manufacturing overcapacity, how to use artificial intelligence in a way that maximizes benefits but still manages national security risks, and global migration.\n\nThe US and other G7 nations are struggling to manage large influxes of migrants arriving for complicated reasons that include war, climate change and drought. Migration, and how nations cope with the growing numbers at their borders, has been a factor driving the far-right rise in some of Europe.", "source": {"uri": "firstpost.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8175353989", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "05:09:34", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T05:09:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T05:08:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/world-news-biden-and-zelenskyy-will-sign-a-security-deal-as-g7-leaders-agree-to-use-russian-cash-to-help-kyiv-6034259.html", "title": "World News | Biden and Zelenskyy Will Sign a Security Deal, as G7 Leaders Agree to Use Russian Cash to Help Kyiv | LatestLY", "body": "Brindisi (Italy), Jun 13 (AP) President Joe Biden and President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will sign a bilateral security agreement between the US and Ukraine on Thursday when they meet on the sidelines of the Group of Seven summit in Italy.\n\nNegotiators for the group have also reached an agreement on how to provide Ukraine with up to $50 billion backed by frozen Russian assets.\n\nAlso Read | UFO Sighting in Canada: Barbell-Shaped UFO Glowing Indigo Blue Colour Spotted in Ontario, Claims Pentagon Engineer; Shares Electronic Evidence of 'Alien' Spacecraft.\n\nThe international group of wealthy democracies has been discussing ways of using the more than $260 billion in frozen Russian assets, most of which are outside the country, to help Ukraine fight Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\nEuropean officials have resisted confiscating the assets, citing legal and financial stability concerns, but the plan would use the interest earned on the assets to help Ukraine's war effort. An official with the French presidency confirmed the agreement Wednesday, saying most of the money would be flowing to Ukraine in the form of a loan from the U.S. government backed by the proceeds of the frozen Russian assets in the European Union. Two other people familiar with the matter confirmed the arrangement.\n\nAlso Read | Kuwait Fire Incident: Kamal Haasan Reacts to Tragic Death of Indian Nationals, Appeals to MEA for Support.\n\nFinal technical negotiations were underway ahead of the summit to finalize the legal terms of the deal.\n\nThe announcement of the agreement comes as Biden landed in Italy with an urgency to get big things done. Thursday's security arrangement was aimed to send a signal to Russia of American resolve in supporting Kyiv, the White House said.\n\nNational security adviser Jake Sullivan said the security agreement would not commit U.S. troops directly to Ukraine's defense against Russia's invasion - a red line drawn by Biden, who's fearful of being pulled into direct conflict between the nuclear-armed powers.\n\n\"We want to demonstrate that the U.S. supports the people of Ukraine, that we stand with them and that we'll continue to help address their security needs,\" Sullivan said, adding \"this agreement will show our resolve.\"\n\nSullivan said aboard Air Force One that the goal of the financing plan was to have a loan that would \"pull forward the windfall profits from the seized assets\" of Russia, giving Ukraine a \"substantial source of funding\" to meet its immediate needs.\n\nThe national security adviser said he had a specific sum of money in mind, but declined to say if that figure was $50 billion. He stressed the urgency of getting Ukraine financial resources as soon as possible and that multiple countries would back the agreement.\n\n\"It's to provide the necessary resources to Ukraine now for its economic energy and other needs, so that it's capable of having the resilience necessary to withstand Russia's continuing aggression,\" Sullivan said.\n\nThis year's meeting comes three years after Biden declared at his first such gathering that America was back as a global leader following the disruptions to Western alliances that occurred when Donald Trump was president. Now, there's a chance this gathering could be the final summit for Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of elections this year.\n\nBiden and his counterparts from Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related to artificial intelligence, migration, the Russian military's resurgence and China's economic might, among other topics. Pope Francis, Zelenskyy and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan are joining the gathering at the Borgo Egnazia resort in the Puglia region of southern Italy.\n\nThe summit, which opened Thursday, will play out after far-right parties across the continent racked up gains of surprising scale in just-concluded European Union elections. Those victories - coupled with upcoming elections in the United Kingdom, France and the United States - have rattled the global political establishment and added weightiness to this year's summit.\n\n\"You hear this a lot when you talk to U.S. and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether it's on China, whether it's on the assets, we may not have another chance,\" said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Council's GeoEconomics Center, an international affairs think tank. \"We don't know what the world will look like three months, six months, nine months from now.\"\n\nThe G7 is an informal bloc of industrialized democracies that meets annually to discuss shared issues and concerns. This is Biden's second trip outside the U.S. in as many weeks; the Democratic president was in France last week for a state visit in Paris and ceremonies in Normandy marking the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings in World War II.\n\nWhile last week's visit had a celebratory feel, this one will be dominated by pressing global issues, including how to keep financial support flowing to Ukraine as it fights Russia's invasion. Biden's trip comes days after his son Hunter was convicted on federal gun charges, a blow sure to weigh heavily on the president's mind.\n\nDespite pressing global challenges, White House national security spokesman John Kirby said there's still a sense of relief among world leaders in 2024 that \"America was back,\" referencing Biden's 2021 speech at the G7 in England.\n\n\"Biden's message then was that democracies need to step up and show they can deliver for their people,\" Kirby said. \"That's true now more than ever.\"\n\nKirby said the U.S. was prepared to work with democratically elected officials in the EU no matter who they are, though some of those being elevated have expressed far less support for Ukraine than current leaders.\n\n\"We have every confidence that regardless of who fills the seats in the European Parliament, we're going to continue to work closely with our EU partners on all the issues relative to our shared interests across the European continent,\" Kirby said. \"That includes supporting Ukraine.\"\n\nBiden and Zelenskyy, who met last week in Paris, are expected to hold a joint news conference while meeting at the G7 summit. Biden is also expected to meet with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, the pope and other leaders.\n\nBiden, who's been adamant \"we will not walk away\" from Ukraine, last week publicly apologized to Zelenskyy for a monthslong delay by Congress in authorizing additional American military assistance. The delay allowed Russia to make gains on the battlefield.\n\nSullivan called the security agreement a \"bridge\" to when Ukraine is invited to join the NATO alliance - a long-term priority of Zelenskyy's that the allies have said will first require an end to the Russia-Ukraine war and that Putin has steadfastly opposed.\n\nBiden's back-to-back trips to France and Italy amount to a rare doubleheader of diplomacy in the midst of the presidential election. The president, however, will skip a Ukraine peace conference in Switzerland this weekend to jet to Los Angeles for a campaign fundraiser with big names from Hollywood. Vice President Kamala Harris will represent the U.S. at the conference.\n\nDespite the delays in military aid, the Biden administration on Tuesday announced it would send Ukraine another Patriot missile system to help fend off Russian strikes, two U.S. officials told The Associated Press.\n\nEarlier Wednesday, the U.S. also announced fresh sanctions targeting Chinese companies that help Russia pursue its war in Ukraine, as well as Russia's financial infrastructure. Sullivan said, \"These actions will ratchet up the risk that foreign financial institutions take by dealing with Russia's war economy.\"\n\nBiden is also expected to discuss economic concerns brought on by Chinese manufacturing overcapacity, how to use artificial intelligence in a way that maximizes benefits but still manages national security risks, and global migration.\n\nThe U.S. and other G7 nations are struggling to manage large influxes of migrants arriving for complicated reasons that include war, climate change and drought. Migration, and how nations cope with the growing numbers at their borders, has been a factor driving the far-right rise in some of Europe. "https://st1.latestly.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/Latestly-World-News-784x441.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9644722", "eventUri": "eng-9644722", "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Italy"}}, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-06-13", "textStart": 18, "textEnd": 24}], "sentiment": 0.2156862745098038, "wgt": 191, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8174618713", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "16:31:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T16:31:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T16:30:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://medicinehatnews.com/news/world-news/2024/06/12/biden-and-zelenskyy-will-sign-a-security-agreement-between-the-us-and-ukraine-when-they-meet-at-g7/", "title": "Biden and Zelenskyy will sign a security agreement between the US and Ukraine when they meet at G7 - Medicine Hat News", "body": "By Darlene Superville And Colleen Long, The Associated Press on June 12, 2024.\n\nSUBSCRIBE NOW ABOARD AIR FORCE ONE (AP) - President Joe Biden and President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will sign a bilateral security agreement between the U.S. and Ukraine on Thursday when they meet on the sidelines of the Group of Seven summit in Italy, aiming to send a signal to Russia of American resolve in supporting Kyiv, the White House said as Biden was headed to Europe. National security adviser Jake Sullivan said the agreement would not commit U.S. troops directly to Ukraine's defense against Russia's invasion - a red line drawn by Biden, who's fearful of being pulled into direct conflict between the nuclear-armed powers. Announcement of the agreement comes as Biden heads to the summit of the world's leading democracies with an urgency to get big things done, including turning frozen Russian assets into billions of dollars to help Ukraine fight Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine. \"We want to demonstrate that the U.S. supports the people of Ukraine, that we stand with them and that we'll continue to help address their security needs,\"\u009d Sullivan said, adding \"this agreement will show our resolve.\"\u009d This year's meeting comes three years after Biden declared at his first such gathering that America was back as a global leader following the disruptions to Western alliances that occurred when Donald Trump was president. Now, there's a chance this gathering could be the final G7 for Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of elections this year. Biden and his counterparts from Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related artificial intelligence, migration, the Russian military's resurgence and China's economic might, among other topics. Pope Francis, Zelenskyy and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan are joining the gathering at the Borgo Egnazia resort in the Puglia region of southern Italy. The summit, opening Thursday, will play out after far-right parties across the continent racked up gains of surprising scale in just-concluded European Union elections. Those victories, coupled with upcoming elections in the United Kingdom, France and the United States, have rattled the global political establishment and added weightiness to this year's summit. \"You hear this a lot when you talk to U.S. and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether it's on China, whether it's on the assets, we may not have another chance,\"\u009d said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Council's GeoEconomics Center, an international affairs think tank. \"We don't know what the world will look like three months, six months, nine months from now.\" The G7 is an informal bloc of industrialized democracies that meets annually to discuss shared issues and concerns. Biden will arrive in Italy on Wednesday night, his second trip outside the U.S. in as many weeks. The Democratic president was in France last week for a state visit in Paris and ceremonies in Normandy marking the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings in World War II. While last week's visit had a celebratory feel, this one will be dominated by pressing global issues, including how to keep financial support flowing to Ukraine as it fights Russia's invasion. Biden's trip comes a day after his son Hunter was convicted on federal gun charges, a blow sure to weigh heavily on the president's mind. Despite pressing global challenges, White House national security spokesman John Kirby said there's still a sense of relief among world leaders in 2024 that \"America was back,\" referencing Biden's 2021 speech at the G7 in England. \"Biden's message then was that democracies need to step up and show they can deliver for their people,\"\u009d Kirby said. \"That's true now more than ever.\"\u009d Kirby said the U.S. was prepared to work with democratically elected officials in the EU no matter who they are, though some of those being elevated have expressed far less support for Ukraine than current leaders. \"We have every confidence that regardless of who fills the seats in the European Parliament, we're going to continue to work closely with our EU partners on all the issues relative to our shared interests across the European continent,\" Kirby said. \"That includes supporting Ukraine.\"\u009d Biden and Zelenskyy, who met last week in Paris, will meet again discuss continued support for the Eastern European nation, which is trying to fend off an intense Russian offensive in eastern areas of the country. They're expected to hold a joint news conference. Biden is also expected to meet with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, the pope and other leaders. Biden, who's been adamant \"we will not walk away\"\u009d from Ukraine, last week publicly apologized to Zelenskyy for a monthslong delay by Congress in authorizing additional American military assistance. The delay allowed Russia to make gains on the battlefield. Sullivan called the security agreement a \"bridge\"\u009d to when Ukraine is invited to join the NATO alliance - a long-term priority of Zelenskyy's that the allies have said will first require an end to the Russia-Ukraine war and that Putin has steadfastly opposed. Biden's back-to-back trips to France and Italy amount to a rare doubleheader of diplomacy in the midst of the presidential election. The president will skip a Ukraine peace conference in Switzerland this weekend to jet to Los Angeles for a campaign fundraiser with big names from Hollywood. Vice President Kamala Harris will represent the U.S. at the conference. Despite the delays in military aid, the Biden administration on Tuesday announced it would send Ukraine another Patriot missile system to help fend off Russian strikes, two U.S. officials told The Associated Press. Biden approved the move, the officials told the AP, as Kyiv has desperately called for more air defenses in its battle against an intense Russian assault on the northeastern Kharkiv region. Kirby said the U.S. would use the G7 summit to announce fresh sanctions and export control actions targeting those who have helped Russia procure what it needs for the war. He said the new measures would make it harder for financiers to support Russia's defense mechanism. Ukraine and many of its supporters have called for the confiscation of $260 billion in Russian assets frozen outside the country after the Feb. 24, 2022, invasion. But European officials have resisted, citing legal and financial stability concerns. Most of the frozen assets are located in Europe. A European plan to just use the interest on the Russian funds would provide only a trickle of money every year - about $2.5 billion to $3 billion at current interest rates, which would barely meet a month's financing needs for the Ukrainian government. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said recently that G7 finance ministers have been discussing the possibility of extending a loan to Ukraine and using the windfall profits of assets seized in Europe to pay it off. Kirby said the U.S. was optimistic the group could agree on the matter. Biden is also expected to discuss economic concerns brought on by Chinese manufacturing overcapacity, how to use artificial intelligence in a way that maximizes benefits but still manages national security risks, and global migration. The U.S. and other G7 nations are struggling to manage large influxes of migrants arriving for complicated reasons that include war, climate change and drought. Migration, and how nations cope with the growing numbers at their borders, has been a factor driving the far-right rise in some of Europe. ___ Superville reported from Bari, Italy.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8174647490", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "16:54:59", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T16:54:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T16:51:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/world-news-biden-and-zelenskyy-will-sign-security-agreement-between-us-and-ukraine-when-they-meet-at-g7-6033752.html", "title": "World News | Biden and Zelenskyy Will Sign Security Agreement Between US and Ukraine when They Meet at G7 | LatestLY", "body": "Aboard Air Force One, Jun 12 (AP) President Joe Biden and President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will sign a bilateral security agreement between the US and Ukraine on Thursday when they meet on the sidelines of the Group of Seven summit in Italy, aiming to send a signal to Russia of American resolve in supporting Kyiv, the White House said as Biden was headed to Europe.\n\nNational security adviser Jake Sullivan said the agreement would not commit US troops directly to Ukraine's defence against Russia's invasion -- a red line drawn by Biden, who's fearful of being pulled into direct conflict between the nuclear-armed powers.\n\nAlso Read | G7 Summit 2024: Joe Biden and Volodymyr Zelenskyy Will Sign Security Agreement Between US and Ukraine When They Meet at Group of Seven Summit.\n\nAnnouncement of the agreement comes as Biden heads to the summit of the world's leading democracies with an urgency to get big things done, including turning frozen Russian assets into billions of dollars to help Ukraine fight Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\n\"We want to demonstrate that the US supports the people of Ukraine, that we stand with them and that we'll continue to help address their security needs,\" Sullivan said, adding \"this agreement will show our resolve\".\n\nAlso Read | Kuwait Building Fire: Death Toll in Building Blaze Climbs to 49; PM Narendra Modi, EAM S Jaishankar Condole Deaths (Watch Videos).\n\nThis year's meeting comes three years after Biden declared at his first such gathering that America was back as a global leader following the disruptions to Western alliances that occurred when Donald Trump was president. Now, there's a chance this gathering could be the final G7 for Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of elections this year.\n\nBiden and his counterparts from Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related artificial intelligence, migration, the Russian military's resurgence and China's economic might, among other topics. Pope Francis, Zelenskyy and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan are joining the gathering at the Borgo Egnazia resort in the Puglia region of southern Italy.\n\nThe summit, opening Thursday, will play out after far-right parties across the continent racked up gains of surprising scale in just-concluded European Union elections. Those victories, coupled with upcoming elections in the United Kingdom, France and the United States, have rattled the global political establishment and added weightiness to this year's summit.\n\n\"You hear this a lot when you talk to US and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether it's on China, whether it's on the assets, we may not have another chance,\" said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Council's GeoEconomics Centre, an international affairs think tank. \"We don't know what the world will look like three months, six months, nine months from now.\"\n\nThe G7 is an informal bloc of industrialised democracies that meets annually to discuss shared issues and concerns. Biden will arrive in Italy on Wednesday night, his second trip outside the US in as many weeks. The Democratic president was in France last week for a state visit in Paris and ceremonies in Normandy marking the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings in World War II.\n\nWhile last week's visit had a celebratory feel, this one will be dominated by pressing global issues, including how to keep financial support flowing to Ukraine as it fights Russia's invasion. Biden's trip comes a day after his son Hunter was convicted on federal gun charges, a blow sure to weigh heavily on the president's mind.\n\nDespite pressing global challenges, White House national security spokesman John Kirby said there's still a sense of relief among world leaders in 2024 that \"America was back\", referencing Biden's 2021 speech at the G7 in England.\n\n\"Biden's message then was that democracies need to step up and show they can deliver for their people,\" Kirby said. \"That's true now more than ever.\"\n\nKirby said the US was prepared to work with democratically elected officials in the EU no matter who they are, though some of those being elevated have expressed far less support for Ukraine than current leaders.\n\n\"We have every confidence that regardless of who fills the seats in the European Parliament, we're going to continue to work closely with our EU partners on all the issues relative to our shared interests across the European continent,\" Kirby said. \"That includes supporting Ukraine.\"\n\nBiden and Zelenskyy, who met last week in Paris, will meet again discuss continued support for the Eastern European nation, which is trying to fend off an intense Russian offensive in eastern areas of the country. They're expected to hold a joint news conference. Biden is also expected to meet with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, the pope and other leaders.\n\nBiden, who's been adamant \"we will not walk away\" from Ukraine, last week publicly apologised to Zelenskyy for a monthslong delay by Congress in authorising additional American military assistance. The delay allowed Russia to make gains on the battlefield.\n\nSullivan called the security agreement a \"bridge\" to when Ukraine is invited to join the NATO alliance -- a long-term priority of Zelenskyy's that the allies have said will first require an end to the Russia-Ukraine war and that Putin has steadfastly opposed.\n\nBiden's back-to-back trips to France and Italy amount to a rare doubleheader of diplomacy in the midst of the presidential election. The president will skip a Ukraine peace conference in Switzerland this weekend to jet to Los Angeles for a campaign fundraiser with big names from Hollywood. Vice President Kamala Harris will represent the US at the conference.\n\nDespite the delays in military aid, the Biden administration on Tuesday announced it would send Ukraine another Patriot missile system to help fend off Russian strikes, two US officials told The Associated Press. Biden approved the move, the officials told the AP, as Kyiv has desperately called for more air defences in its battle against an intense Russian assault on the northeastern Kharkiv region.\n\nKirby said the US would use the G7 summit to announce fresh sanctions and export control actions targeting those who have helped Russia procure what it needs for the war. He said the new measures would make it harder for financiers to support Russia's defence mechanism.\n\nUkraine and many of its supporters have called for the confiscation of USD 260 billion in Russian assets frozen outside the country after the February 24, 2022, invasion. But European officials have resisted, citing legal and financial stability concerns. Most of the frozen assets are located in Europe.\n\nA European plan to just use the interest on the Russian funds would provide only a trickle of money every year -- about USD 2.5 billion to USD 3 billion at current interest rates, which would barely meet a month's financing needs for the Ukrainian government.\n\nTreasury Secretary Janet Yellen said recently that G7 finance ministers have been discussing the possibility of extending a loan to Ukraine and using the windfall profits of assets seized in Europe to pay it off.\n\nKirby said the US was optimistic the group could agree on the matter.\n\nBiden is also expected to discuss economic concerns brought on by Chinese manufacturing overcapacity, how to use artificial intelligence in a way that maximises benefits but still manages national security risks, and global migration.\n\nThe US and other G7 nations are struggling to manage large influxes of migrants arriving for complicated reasons that include war, climate change and drought. Migration, and how nations cope with the growing numbers at their borders, has been a factor driving the far-right rise in some of Europe. {"uri": "8174671934", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "17:10:12", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T17:10:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T17:09:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/at-g7-biden-and-zelenskyy-will-sign-a-u-s-ukraine-security-agreement", "title": "At G7, Biden and Zelenskyy will sign a U.S.-Ukraine security agreement", "body": "ABOARD AIR FORCE ONE (AP) -- President Joe Biden and President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will sign a bilateral security agreement between the U.S. and Ukraine on Thursday when they meet on the sidelines of the Group of Seven summit in Italy, aiming to send a signal to Russia of American resolve in supporting Kyiv, the White House said as Biden was headed to Europe.\n\nNational security adviser Jake Sullivan said the agreement would not commit U.S. troops directly to Ukraine's defense against Russia's invasion -- a red line drawn by Biden, who's fearful of being pulled into direct conflict between the nuclear-armed powers. Announcement of the agreement comes as Biden heads to the summit of the world's leading democracies with an urgency to get big things done, including turning frozen Russian assets into billions of dollars to help Ukraine fight Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\n\"We want to demonstrate that the U.S. supports the people of Ukraine, that we stand with them and that we'll continue to help address their security needs,\" Sullivan said, adding \"this agreement will show our resolve.\"\n\nREAD MORE: At D-Day 80th anniversary, Biden pledges not to walk away from defending Ukraine\n\nThis year's meeting comes three years after Biden declared at his first such gathering that America was back as a global leader following the disruptions to Western alliances that occurred when Donald Trump was president. Now, there's a chance this gathering could be the final G7 for Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of elections this year.\n\nBiden and his counterparts from Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related artificial intelligence, migration, the Russian military's resurgence and China's economic might, among other topics. Pope Francis, Zelenskyy and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan are joining the gathering at the Borgo Egnazia resort in the Puglia region of southern Italy.\n\nThe summit, opening Thursday, will play out after far-right parties across the continent racked up gains of surprising scale in just-concluded European Union elections. Those victories, coupled with upcoming elections in the United Kingdom, France and the United States, have rattled the global political establishment and added weightiness to this year's summit.\n\n\"You hear this a lot when you talk to U.S. and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether it's on China, whether it's on the assets, we may not have another chance,\" said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Council's GeoEconomics Center, an international affairs think tank. \"We don't know what the world will look like three months, six months, nine months from now.\"\n\nThe G7 is an informal bloc of industrialized democracies that meets annually to discuss shared issues and concerns. Biden will arrive in Italy on Wednesday night, his second trip outside the U.S. in as many weeks. The Democratic president was in France last week for a state visit in Paris and ceremonies in Normandy marking the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings in World War II.\n\nREAD MORE: U.S. lifts ban on providing weapons and training for Ukraine's controversial Azov Brigade\n\nWhile last week's visit had a celebratory feel, this one will be dominated by pressing global issues, including how to keep financial support flowing to Ukraine as it fights Russia's invasion. Biden's trip comes a day after his son Hunter was convicted on federal gun charges, a blow sure to weigh heavily on the president's mind.\n\nDespite pressing global challenges, White House national security spokesman John Kirby said there's still a sense of relief among world leaders in 2024 that \"America was back,\" referencing Biden's 2021 speech at the G7 in England.\n\n\"Biden's message then was that democracies need to step up and show they can deliver for their people,\" Kirby said. \"That's true now more than ever.\"\n\nKirby said the U.S. was prepared to work with democratically elected officials in the EU no matter who they are, though some of those being elevated have expressed far less support for Ukraine than current leaders.\n\n\"We have every confidence that regardless of who fills the seats in the European Parliament, we're going to continue to work closely with our EU partners on all the issues relative to our shared interests across the European continent,\" Kirby said. \"That includes supporting Ukraine.\"\n\nBiden and Zelenskyy, who met last week in Paris, will meet again discuss continued support for the Eastern European nation, which is trying to fend off an intense Russian offensive in eastern areas of the country. They're expected to hold a joint news conference. Biden is also expected to meet with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, the pope and other leaders.\n\nBiden, who's been adamant \"we will not walk away\" from Ukraine, last week publicly apologized to Zelenskyy for a monthslong delay by Congress in authorizing additional American military assistance. The delay allowed Russia to make gains on the battlefield.\n\nSullivan called the security agreement a \"bridge\" to when Ukraine is invited to join the NATO alliance -- a long-term priority of Zelenskyy's that the allies have said will first require an end to the Russia-Ukraine war and that Putin has steadfastly opposed.\n\nREAD MORE: Russian warships arrive in Cuban waters for military exercises\n\nBiden's back-to-back trips to France and Italy amount to a rare doubleheader of diplomacy in the midst of the presidential election. The president will skip a Ukraine peace conference in Switzerland this weekend to jet to Los Angeles for a campaign fundraiser with big names from Hollywood. Vice President Kamala Harris will represent the U.S. at the conference.\n\nDespite the delays in military aid, the Biden administration on Tuesday announced it would send Ukraine another Patriot missile system to help fend off Russian strikes, two U.S. officials told The Associated Press. Biden approved the move, the officials told the AP, as Kyiv has desperately called for more air defenses in its battle against an intense Russian assault on the northeastern Kharkiv region.\n\nKirby said the U.S. would use the G7 summit to announce fresh sanctions and export control actions targeting those who have helped Russia procure what it needs for the war. He said the new measures would make it harder for financiers to support Russia's defense mechanism.\n\nUkraine and many of its supporters have called for the confiscation of $260 billion in Russian assets frozen outside the country after the Feb. 24, 2022, invasion. But European officials have resisted, citing legal and financial stability concerns. Most of the frozen assets are located in Europe.\n\nA European plan to just use the interest on the Russian funds would provide only a trickle of money every year -- about $2.5 billion to $3 billion at current interest rates, which would barely meet a month's financing needs for the Ukrainian government.\n\nTreasury Secretary Janet Yellen said recently that G7 finance ministers have been discussing the possibility of extending a loan to Ukraine and using the windfall profits of assets seized in Europe to pay it off.\n\nKirby said the U.S. was optimistic the group could agree on the matter.\n\nBiden is also expected to discuss economic concerns brought on by Chinese manufacturing overcapacity, how to use artificial intelligence in a way that maximizes benefits but still manages national security risks, and global migration.\n\nThe U.S. and other G7 nations are struggling to manage large influxes of migrants arriving for complicated reasons that include war, climate change and drought. Migration, and how nations cope with the growing numbers at their borders, has been a factor driving the far-right rise in some of Europe.\n\nSuperville reported from Bari, Italy.", "source": {"uri": Why is it different this year?\n\n\"There's a possibility that Russia might regain access to the frozen assets, or the income from those assets might not be enough to cover the loan. In that case, we'll need to discuss how to share the responsibility of repaying the loan,\" the source said.\n\nUS President Joe Biden will sign a new security agreement with Ukraine on Thursday to vow America's long-term support to the country.\n\nPrime Minister Narendra Modi is heading to Italy to attend G7 summit, which is likely to be dominated by Ukraine and Gaza ceasefire talks.\n\nThe {"uri": "2024-06-387332319", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "15:01:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T15:01:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T13:09:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/06/12/fresh-off-france-trip-biden-heads-back-to-europe-for-g7-summit-to-talk-ukraine-support-migration/", "title": "Fresh off France trip, Biden heads back to Europe for G7 summit to talk Ukraine support, migration", "body": "This year's Group of Seven summit comes three years after Biden declared at his first such gathering that America was back as a global leader following the disruptions to Western alliances that occurred when Donald Trump was president. Now, there's a chance this gathering could be the final G7 for Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of elections this year.\n\nBiden and his counterparts from Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related to the spread of artificial intelligence, migration, the Russian military's resurgence and China's economic might, among other topics. Pope Francis, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan are joining the gathering at the Borgo Egnazia resort in the Puglia region of southern Italy.\n\nThe summit, which opens Thursday, will play out after far-right parties across the continent racked up gains of surprising scale in just-concluded European Union elections. Those victories, coupled with upcoming elections in the United Kingdom, France and the United States, have rattled the global political establishment and added weightiness to this year's summit.\n\n\"You hear this a lot when you talk to U.S. and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether it's on China, whether it's on the assets, we may not have another chance,\" said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Council's GeoEconomics Center, an international affairs think tank. \"We don't know what the world will look like three months, six months, nine months from now.\"\n\nThe G7 is an informal bloc of industrialized democracies that meets annually to discuss shared issues and concerns. Biden is set to arrive in Italy on Wednesday night, his second trip outside the U.S. in as many weeks. The Democratic president was in France last week for a state visit in Paris and ceremonies in Normandy marking the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings in World War II.\n\nWhile last week's visit had a celebratory feel, this one will be dominated by pressing global issues, including how to keep financial support flowing to Ukraine as it fights Russia's invasion. Biden's trip also comes one day after his son Hunter was convicted on federal gun charges, a blow sure to weigh heavily on the president's mind.\n\nDespite pressing global challenges, White House national security spokesman John Kirby said there is still a sense of relief among world leaders in 2024 that \"America was back,\" referencing Biden's 2021 speech at the G7 in Cornwall, England.\n\n\"Biden's message then was that democracies need to step up and show they can deliver for their people,\" Kirby said. \"That's true now more than ever.\"\n\nKirby said the U.S. was prepared to work with democratically elected officials in the EU no matter who they are, though some of those being elevated have expressed far less support for Ukraine than current leaders.\n\n\"We have every confidence that regardless of who fills the seats in the European Parliament, we're going to continue to work closely with our EU partners on all the issues relative to our shared interests across the European continent,\" Kirby said. \"That includes supporting Ukraine.\"\n\nBiden and Zelenskyy, who met last week in Paris, will meet again Thursday on the sidelines of the summit to discuss continued support for the Eastern European nation, which is trying to fend off an intense Russian offensive in eastern areas of the country. They are expected to hold a joint news conference. Biden is also expected to meet with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, the pope and other leaders.\n\nBiden, who has been adamant that \"we will not walk away\" from Ukraine, last week publicly apologized to Zelenskyy for a monthslong delay by Congress in authorizing additional American military assistance. The delay allowed Russia to make gains on the battlefield.\n\nBiden's back-to-back trips to France and Italy amount to a rare doubleheader of diplomacy in the midst of the presidential election. The president will skip a Ukraine peace conference in Switzerland this weekend to jet to Los Angeles for a campaign fundraiser with big names from Hollywood. Vice President Kamala Harris will represent the U.S. at the conference.\n\nDespite the delays in military aid, the Biden administration on Tuesday announced it would send Ukraine another Patriot missile system to help fend off Russian strikes, two U.S. officials told The Associated Press. Biden approved the move, the officials told the AP, as Kyiv has desperately called for more air defenses in its battle against an intense Russian assault on the northeastern Kharkiv region.\n\nKirby said the U.S. would use the G7 summit to announce fresh sanctions and export control actions targeting those who have helped Russia procure what it needs for the war. He said the new measures would make it harder for financiers to support Russia's defense mechanism.\n\nUkraine and many of its supporters have called for the confiscation of $260 billion in Russian assets frozen outside the country after the Feb. 24, 2022, invasion. But European officials have resisted, citing legal and financial stability concerns. Most of the frozen assets are located in Europe.\n\nA European plan to just use the interest on the Russian funds would provide only a trickle of money every year -- about $2.5 billion to $3 billion at current interest rates, which would barely meet a month's financing needs for the Ukrainian government.\n\nTreasury Secretary Janet Yellen said recently that G7 finance ministers have been discussing the possibility of extending a loan to Ukraine and using the windfall profits of assets seized in Europe to pay it off.\n\nKirby said the U.S. was optimistic the group could agree on the matter.\n\nBiden is also expected to discuss economic concerns brought on by Chinese manufacturing overcapacity, how to use artificial intelligence in a way that maximizes benefits but still manages national security risks, and global migration.\n\nThe U.S. and other G7 nations are struggling to manage large influxes of migrants arriving for complicated reasons that include war, climate change and drought. Migration, and how nations cope with the growing numbers at their borders, has been a factor driving the far-right rise in some of Europe.", "source": {"uri": "tribtown.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "2024-06-387279065", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "14:12:15", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T14:12:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T13:34:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/world-news-fresh-off-france-trip-biden-heads-back-to-europe-for-g7-summit-to-talk-ukraine-support-migration-6033318.html", "title": "World News | Fresh off France Trip, Biden Heads Back to Europe for G7 Summit to Talk Ukraine Support, Migration", "body": "Washington, Jun 12 (AP) President Joe Biden heads to Italy on Wednesday for a summit of the world's leading democracies with an urgency to get big things done, including turning frozen Russian assets into billions of dollars to help Ukraine as it fights off Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\nThis year's Group of Seven summit comes three years after Biden declared at his first such gathering that America was back as a global leader following the disruptions to Western alliances that occurred under President Donald Trump.\n\nAlso Read | Gandhi Statue Vandalised in Italy: MEA Slams Vandalisation of Mahatma Gandhi Statue by Khalistani Separatists Ahead of PM Narendra Modi's Visit.\n\nNow, there's a chance this gathering could be the final G7 for Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of elections this year.\n\nBiden and his counterparts from Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related to the spread of artificial intelligence, migration, the Russian military's resurgence and China's economic might, among other topics.\n\nAlso Read | PM Narendra Modi to Leave for Italy on June 13 for G7 Summit; Will Hold Bilateral Meeting With His Italian Counterpart Giorgia Meloni.\n\nPope Francis, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan are joining the gathering at the Borgo Egnazia resort in the Puglia, a region of southern Italy.\n\nThe summit, which opens on Thursday, will play out after far-right parties across the continent racked up gains of surprising scale in just-concluded European Union elections. Those victories -- coupled with upcoming elections in the United Kingdom, France and the United States -- have rattled the global political establishment and added weightiness to this year's summit.\n\n\"You hear this a lot when you talk to US and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether it's on China, whether it's on the assets, we may not have another chance,\" said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Council's GeoEconomics Center, an international affairs think tank.\n\n\"We don't know what the world will look like three months, six months, nine months from now.\"\n\nThe G7 is an informal bloc of industrialised democracies that meets annually to discuss shared issues and concerns. Biden is set to arrive in Italy on Wednesday night, his second trip outside the US in as many weeks. The Democratic president was in France last week for a state visit in Paris and ceremonies in Normandy marking the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings in World War II.\n\nWhile last week's visit had a celebratory feel, this one will be dominated by pressing global issues, including how to keep financial support flowing to Ukraine as it fights Russia's invasion. Biden's trip also comes one day after his son Hunter was convicted on federal gun charges, a blow sure to weigh heavily on the president's mind.\n\nDespite pressing global challenges, White House national security spokesman John Kirby said there is still a sense of relief among world leaders in 2024 that \"America was back,\" referencing Biden's 2021 speech at the G7 in Cornwall, England.\n\n\"Biden's message then was that democracies need to step up and show they can deliver for their people,\" Kirby said. \"That's true now more than ever.\"\n\nKirby said the US was prepared to work with democratically elected officials in the EU no matter who they are, though some of those being elevated have expressed far less support for Ukraine than current leaders.\n\n\"We have every confidence that regardless of who fills the seats in the European Parliament, we're going to continue to work closely with our EU partners on all the issues relative to our shared interests across the European continent,\" Kirby said. \"That includes supporting Ukraine.\"\n\nBiden and Zelenskyy, who met last week in Paris, will meet again on Thursday on the sidelines of the summit to discuss continued support for the Eastern European nation, which is trying to fend off an intense Russian offensive in eastern areas of the country. They are expected to hold a joint news conference.\n\nBiden is also expected to meet one-on-one with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, the pope and other leaders.\n\nBiden, who has been adamant that \"we will not walk away\" from Ukraine, last week publicly apologised to Zelenskyy for a months-long delay by Congress in authorising additional American military assistance. The delay allowed Russia to make gains on the battlefield.\n\nBiden's back-to-back trips to France and Italy amount to a rare doubleheader of international diplomacy in the midst of the presidential election.\n\nThe president will skip a Ukraine peace conference in Switzerland this weekend to jet to Los Angeles for a campaign fundraiser with big names from Hollywood. Vice President Kamala Harris will represent the US at the Swiss conference.\n\nDespite the delays in military aid, the Biden administration on Tuesday announced it would send Ukraine another Patriot missile system to help fend off Russian strikes, two US officials told The Associated Press.\n\nBiden approved the move, the officials told the AP, as Kyiv has desperately called for more air defences in its battle against an intense Russian assault on the northeastern Kharkiv region.\n\nKirby said the US would use the G7 summit to announce fresh sanctions and export control actions targeting those who have helped Russia procure what it needs for the war. He said the new measures would make it harder for financiers to support Russia's defense mechanism.\n\nUkraine and many of its supporters have called for the confiscation of USD 260 billion in Russian assets frozen outside the country after the February 24, 2022, invasion. But European officials have resisted, citing legal and financial stability concerns. Most of the frozen assets are located in Europe.\n\nA European plan to just use the interest on the Russian funds would provide only a trickle of money every year -- about USD 2.5 billion to USD 3 billion at current interest rates, which would barely meet a month's financing needs for the Ukrainian government.\n\nTreasury Secretary Janet Yellen said recently that G7 finance ministers have been discussing the possibility of extending a loan to Ukraine and using the windfall profits of assets seized in Europe to pay it off.\n\nKirby said the US was optimistic the group could agree on the matter.\n\nBiden is also expected to discuss economic concerns brought on by Chinese manufacturing overcapacity, how to use artificial intelligence in a way that maximizes benefits but still manages national security risks, and global migration.\n\nThe US and other G7 nations are struggling to manage large influxes of migrants arriving for complicated reasons that include war, climate change and drought. Migration, and how nations cope with the growing numbers at their borders, has been a factor driving the far-right rise in some of Europe. {"uri": "8175715908", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "09:25:32", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T09:25:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T09:24:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.breakingnews.ie/ukraine/biden-and-zelensky-to-sign-security-agreement-between-us-and-ukraine-at-summit-1637562.html", "title": "Biden and Zelenskiy to sign security agreement between US and Ukraine at summit | BreakingNews.ie", "body": "US president Joe Biden and Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskiy will sign a bilateral security agreement between the US and Ukraine on Thursday when they meet on the sidelines of the G7 summit.\n\nThe announcement came as negotiators for the group reached an agreement on how to provide Ukraine with up to $50 billion backed by frozen Russian assets, according to two people familiar with the matter.\n\nThe international group of wealthy democracies has been discussing ways of using the more than $260 billion in Russian assets frozen outside the country after the February 2022 invasion of Ukraine to help Kyiv.\n\nEuropean officials have resisted confiscating the assets, citing legal and financial stability concerns - most of the frozen assets are located in Europe - but the plan would use the interest earned on the assets to help Ukraine's war effort.\n\nAn official with the French presidency confirmed the announcement on Wednesday.\n\nThe announcement of the agreement comes as Mr Biden heads to the G7 summit with an urgency to get big things done, including turning frozen Russian assets into billions of dollars to help Ukraine fight Russian president Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\nThe security arrangement was aimed at sending a signal to Russia of American resolve in supporting Kyiv, the White House said as Mr Biden was headed to Europe.\n\nNational security adviser Jake Sullivan told reporters that the agreement would not commit US troops directly to Ukraine's defence against Russia's invasion - a red line drawn by Mr Biden, who is fearful of being drawn into direct conflict between the nuclear-armed powers.\n\n\"We want to demonstrate that the US supports the people of Ukraine, that we stand with them and that we'll continue to help address their security needs,\" Mr Sullivan said, adding \"this agreement will show our resolve\".\n\nMr Sullivan called the agreement a \"bridge\" to when Ukraine is invited to join the Nato alliance - a long-term priority of Mr Zelenskiy's that the allies have said will first require an end to the Russia-Ukraine war.\n\nMr Biden heads to the summit of the world's leading democracies with an urgency to get big things done, including turning frozen Russian assets into billions of dollars to help Ukraine as it fights off Mr Putin's war machine.\n\nThis year's G7 summit comes three years after Mr Biden declared at his first such gathering that America was back as a global leader following the disruptions to western alliances that occurred when Donald Trump was president.\n\nNow, there is a chance this gathering could be the final G7 for Mr Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of elections this year.\n\nMr Biden and his counterparts from Canada, the UK, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related to the spread of artificial intelligence, migration, the Russian military's resurgence and China's economic might, among other topics.\n\nPope Francis, Mr Zelenskiy and Turkish president Recep Tayyip Erdogan are joining the gathering at the Borgo Egnazia resort in the Puglia region of southern Italy.\n\nThe summit, which opens on Thursday, will play out after far-right parties across the continent secured gains of surprising scale in just-concluded European Union elections.\n\nThose victories, coupled with upcoming elections in the UK, France and the US, have rattled the global political establishment and added weightiness to this year's summit.\n\n\"You hear this a lot when you talk to US and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether it's on China, whether it's on the assets, we may not have another chance,\" said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Council's GeoEconomics Centre, an international affairs think tank.\n\n\"We don't know what the world will look like three months, six months, nine "https://img.resized.co/breaking--and-zelenskiy-to-sign-security-agreement-between-us-and-ukraine-at-summit.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9644722", "eventUri": "eng-9644722", {"uri": "8174712625", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "17:42:18", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T17:42:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T17:41:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.pressherald.com/2024/06/12/biden-and-zelensky-will-sign-a-security-agreement-when-they-meet-at-g7/", "title": "Biden and Zelensky will sign a security agreement when they meet at G7", "body": "President Biden is escorted by Air Force Col. Angela Ochoa, commander of the 89th Airlift Wing, as he arrives at Andrews Air Force Base, Md., on Wednesday. Biden is headed to Italy for the G7 summit. Biden's granddaughter Finnegan Biden walks at right. Alex Brandon/Associated Press\n\nABOARD AIR FORCE ONE -- President Biden and President Volodymyr Zelensky will sign a bilateral security agreement between the U.S. and Ukraine on Thursday when they meet on the sidelines of the Group of Seven summit in Italy, aiming to send a signal to Russia of American resolve in supporting Kyiv, the White House said as Biden was headed to Europe.\n\nNational security adviser Jake Sullivan said the agreement would not commit U.S. troops directly to Ukraine's defense against Russia's invasion -- a red line drawn by Biden, who's fearful of being pulled into direct conflict between the nuclear-armed powers. Announcement of the agreement comes as Biden heads to the summit of the world's leading democracies with an urgency to get big things done, including turning frozen Russian assets into billions of dollars to help Ukraine fight Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\n\"We want to demonstrate that the U.S. supports the people of Ukraine, that we stand with them and that we'll continue to help address their security needs,\" Sullivan said, adding \"this agreement will show our resolve.\"\n\nThis year's meeting comes three years after Biden declared at his first such gathering that America was back as a global leader following the disruptions to Western alliances that occurred when Donald Trump was president. Now, there's a chance this gathering could be the final G7 for Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of elections this year.\n\nBiden and his counterparts from Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related to artificial intelligence, migration, the Russian military's resurgence and China's economic might, among other topics. Pope Francis, Zelensky and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan are joining the gathering at the Borgo Egnazia resort in the Puglia region of southern Italy.\n\nThe summit, opening Thursday, will play out after far-right parties across the continent racked up gains of surprising scale in just-concluded European Union elections. Those victories, coupled with upcoming elections in the United Kingdom, France and the United States, have rattled the global political establishment and added weightiness to this year's summit.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"You hear this a lot when you talk to U.S. and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether it's on China, whether it's on the assets, we may not have another chance,\" said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Council's GeoEconomics Center, an international affairs think tank. \"We don't know what the world will look like three months, six months, nine months from now.\"\n\nThe G7 is an informal bloc of industrialized democracies that meets annually to discuss shared issues and concerns. Biden will arrive in Italy on Wednesday night, his second trip outside the U.S. in as many weeks. The Democratic president was in France last week for a state visit in Paris and ceremonies in Normandy marking the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings in World War II.\n\nRelated Biden apologizes to Zelensky for monthslong holdup in approving weapons\n\nWhile last week's visit had a celebratory feel, this one will be dominated by pressing global issues, including how to keep financial support flowing to Ukraine as it fights Russia's invasion. Biden's trip comes a day after his son Hunter was convicted on federal gun charges, a blow sure to weigh heavily on the president's mind.\n\nDespite pressing global challenges, White House national security spokesman John Kirby said there's still a sense of relief among world leaders in 2024 that \"America was back,\" referencing Biden's 2021 speech at the G7 in England.\n\n\"Biden's message then was that democracies need to step up and show they can deliver for their people,\" Kirby said. \"That's true now more than ever.\"\n\nKirby said the U.S. was prepared to work with democratically elected officials in the EU no matter who they are, though some of those being elevated have expressed far less support for Ukraine than current leaders.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"We have every confidence that regardless of who fills the seats in the European Parliament, we're going to continue to work closely with our EU partners on all the issues relative to our shared interests across the European continent,\" Kirby said. \"That includes supporting Ukraine.\"\n\nBiden and Zelensky, who met last week in Paris, will meet again discuss continued support for the Eastern European nation, which is trying to fend off an intense Russian offensive in eastern areas of the country. They're expected to hold a joint news conference. Biden is also expected to meet with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, the pope and other leaders.\n\nBiden, who's been adamant \"we will not walk away\" from Ukraine, last week publicly apologized to Zelensky for a monthslong delay by Congress in authorizing additional American military assistance. The delay allowed Russia to make gains on the battlefield.\n\nSullivan called the security agreement a \"bridge\" to when Ukraine is invited to join the NATO alliance -- a long-term priority of Zelensky's that the allies have said will first require an end to the Russia-Ukraine war and that Putin has steadfastly opposed.\n\nBiden's back-to-back trips to France and Italy amount to a rare doubleheader of diplomacy in the midst of the presidential election. The president will skip a Ukraine peace conference in Switzerland this weekend to jet to Los Angeles for a campaign fundraiser with big names from Hollywood. Vice President Kamala Harris will represent the U.S. at the conference.\n\nDespite the delays in military aid, the Biden administration on Tuesday announced it would send Ukraine another Patriot missile system to help fend off Russian strikes, two U.S. officials told The Associated Press. Biden approved the move, the officials told the AP, as Kyiv has desperately called for more air defenses in its battle against an intense Russian assault on the northeastern Kharkiv region.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nAnd earlier Wednesday, the U.S. announced fresh sanctions targeting Chinese companies that help Russia pursue its war in Ukraine, as well as Russia's financial infrastructure. Sullivan said \"these actions will rachet up the risk that foreign financial institutions take by dealing with Russia's war economy.\"\n\nUkraine and many of its supporters have called for the confiscation of $260 billion in Russian assets frozen outside the country after the Feb. 24, 2022, invasion. But European officials have resisted, citing legal and financial stability concerns. Most of the frozen assets are located in Europe.\n\nA European plan to just use the interest on the Russian funds would provide only a trickle of money every year -- about $2.5 billion to $3 billion at current interest rates, which would barely meet a month's financing needs for the Ukrainian government.\n\nTreasury Secretary Janet Yellen said recently that G7 finance ministers have been discussing the possibility of extending a loan to Ukraine and using the windfall profits of assets seized in Europe to pay it off.\n\nKirby said the U.S. was optimistic the group could agree on the matter.\n\nBiden is also expected to discuss economic concerns brought on by Chinese manufacturing overcapacity, how to use artificial intelligence in a way that maximizes benefits but still manages national security risks, and global migration.\n\nThe U.S. and other G7 nations are struggling to manage large influxes of migrants arriving for complicated reasons that include war, climate change and drought. Migration, and how nations cope with the growing numbers at their borders, has been a factor driving the far-right rise in some of Europe.\n\nCopy the Story Link Related Headlines 90 countries to attend Ukraine peace summit that Russia is snubbing Biden apologizes to Zelensky for monthslong holdup in approving weapons\n\nInvalid username/password.\n\nPlease check your email to confirm and complete your registration.\n\nCreate a commenting profile by providing an email address, password and display name. {"uri": "8174349263", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "13:33:36", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T13:33:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T13:32:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.thepeterboroughexaminer.com/news/world/united-states/fresh-off-france-trip-biden-heads-back-to-europe-for-g7-summit-to-talk-ukraine/article_4fc6bbd0-514f-516c-ad3b-c74f36c31e78.html", "title": "Fresh off France trip, Biden heads back to Europe for G7 summit to talk Ukraine support, migration", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- President Joe Biden heads to Italy on Wednesday for a summit of the world's leading democracies with an urgency to get big things done, including turning frozen Russian assets into billions of dollars to help Ukraine as it fights off Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\nThis year's Group of Seven summit comes three years after Biden declared at his first such gathering that America was back as a global leader following the disruptions to Western alliances that occurred under President Donald Trump. Now, there's a chance this gathering could be the final G7 for Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of elections this year.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nBiden and his counterparts from Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related to the spread of artificial intelligence, migration, the Russian military's resurgence and China's economic might, among other topics. Pope Francis, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan are joining the gathering at the Borgo Egnazia resort in the Puglia, a region of southern Italy.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe summit, which opens Thursday, will play out after far-right parties across the continent racked up gains of surprising scale in just-concluded European Union elections. Those victories -- coupled with upcoming elections in the United Kingdom, France and the United States -- have rattled the global political establishment and added weightiness to this year's summit.\n\n\"You hear this a lot when you talk to U.S. and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether it's on China, whether it's on the assets, we may not have another chance,\" said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Council's GeoEconomics Center, an international affairs think tank. \"We don't know what the world will look like three months, six months, nine months from now.\"\n\nThe G7 is an informal bloc of industrialized democracies that meets annually to discuss shared issues and concerns. Biden is set to arrive in Italy on Wednesday night, his second trip outside the U.S. in as many weeks. The Democratic president was in France last week for a state visit in Paris and ceremonies in Normandy marking the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings in World War II.\n\nWhile last week's visit had a celebratory feel, this one will be dominated by pressing global issues, including how to keep financial support flowing to Ukraine as it fights Russia's invasion. Biden's trip also comes one day after his son Hunter was convicted on federal gun charges, a blow sure to weigh heavily on the president's mind.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nDespite pressing global challenges, White House national security spokesman John Kirby said there is still a sense of relief among world leaders in 2024 that \"America was back,\" referencing Biden's 2021 speech at the G7 in Cornwall, England.\n\nYou might be interested in Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"Biden's message then was that democracies need to step up and show they can deliver for their people,\" Kirby said. \"That's true now more than ever.\"\n\nKirby said the U.S. was prepared to work with democratically elected officials in the EU no matter who they are, though some of those being elevated have expressed far less support for Ukraine than current leaders.\n\n\"We have every confidence that regardless of who fills the seats in the European Parliament, we're going to continue to work closely with our EU partners on all the issues relative to our shared interests across the European continent,\" Kirby said. \"That includes supporting Ukraine.\"\n\nBiden and Zelenskyy, who met last week in Paris, will meet again Thursday on the sidelines of the summit to discuss continued support for the Eastern European nation, which is trying to fend off an intense Russian offensive in eastern areas of the country. They are expected to hold a joint news conference. Biden is also expected to meet one-on-one with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, the pope and other leaders.\n\nBiden, who has been adamant that \"we will not walk away\" from Ukraine, last week publicly apologized to Zelenskyy for a monthslong delay by Congress in authorizing additional American military assistance. The delay allowed Russia to make gains on the battlefield.\n\nBiden's back-to-back trips to France and Italy amount to a rare doubleheader of international diplomacy in the midst of the presidential election. The president will skip a Ukraine peace conference in Switzerland this weekend to jet to Los Angeles for a campaign fundraiser with big names from Hollywood. Vice President Kamala Harris will represent the U.S. at the Swiss conference.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nDespite the delays in military aid, the Biden administration on Tuesday announced it would send Ukraine another Patriot missile system to help fend off Russian strikes, two U.S. officials told The Associated Press. Biden approved the move, the officials told the AP, as Kyiv has desperately called for more air defenses in its battle against an intense Russian assault on the northeastern Kharkiv region.\n\nKirby said the U.S. would use the G7 summit to announce fresh sanctions and export control actions targeting those who have helped Russia procure what it needs for the war. He said the new measures would make it harder for financiers to support Russia's defense mechanism.\n\nUkraine and many of its supporters have called for the confiscation of $260 billion in Russian assets frozen outside the country after the Feb. 24, 2022, invasion. But European officials have resisted, citing legal and financial stability concerns. Most of the frozen assets are located in Europe.\n\nA European plan to just use the interest on the Russian funds would provide only a trickle of money every year -- about $2.5 billion to $3 billion at current interest rates, which would barely meet a month's financing needs for the Ukrainian government.\n\nTreasury Secretary Janet Yellen said recently that G7 finance ministers have been discussing the possibility of extending a loan to Ukraine and using the windfall profits of assets seized in Europe to pay it off.\n\nKirby said the U.S. was optimistic the group could agree on the matter.\n\nBiden is also expected to discuss economic concerns brought on by Chinese manufacturing overcapacity, how to use artificial intelligence in a way that maximizes benefits but still manages national security risks, and global migration.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe U.S. and other G7 nations are struggling to manage large influxes of migrants arriving for complicated reasons that include war, climate change and drought. Migration, and how nations cope with the growing numbers at their borders, has been a factor driving the far-right rise in some of Europe.\n\n___\n\nSuperville reported from Bari, Italy.", "source":
