{"uri": "8175853652", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "10:48:59", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T10:48:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T10:48:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://bdnews24.com/world/0c4348ce4144", "title": "Biden will sign new security agreement with Ukraine during G7 summit", "body": "US President Joe Biden waves as he boards Air Force One upon his departure for the G7 summit in Italy, from Joint Base Andrews in Maryland, US, June 12, 2024. REUTERS\n\nUS President Joe Biden will sign a new security agreement with Ukraine on Thursday to pledge America's long-term support to the country, during his meeting with leaders of the Group of Seven democracies in Italy, a top US official said.\n\nBiden departed for Italy on Wednesday to increase pressure on Russia over its war against Ukraine and on China for its support of Moscow and excess industrial capacity.\n\nThe agreement will make clear \"our support will last long into the future... particularly in the defense and security space,\" White House national security adviser Jake Sullivan told reporters aboard Air Force One.\n\n\"By signing this we'll also be sending Russia a signal of our resolve. If Vladimir Putin thinks he can outlast the coalition supporting Ukraine, he's wrong,\" Sullivan said.\n\nFifteen countries have signed their own security agreements, which will strengthen Ukraine's \"defensive deterrence capability,\" he said. The US agreement will include a commitment to working with the US Congress on funding Ukraine going forward but will not commit to using US forces on the ground, Sullivan added.\n\nThe White House had said earlier that Biden will meet again with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky at the summit, followed by a joint press conference. The US also expects Biden to meet India's Narendra Modi, who was sworn in as prime minister for a third term, and is waiting for India to formally confirm Modi's attendance at the summit.\n\nThe G7 leaders arrive at the summit confronting myriad woes at home even as they seek solutions for many of the world's most pressing problems.\n\nBiden, 81, spent Tuesday evening at his home in Wilmington, Delaware, after a 12-member jury convicted his son Hunter Biden of lying about his drug use to illegally buy a gun in 2018, making him the first child of a sitting US president to be convicted of a crime.\n\nThe trial followed the May 30 criminal conviction of Republican former President Donald Trump, the first former US president to be found guilty of a felony. Biden and Trump are running against each other in the November presidential election and are neck-and-neck in the polls.\n\nThe heads of the world's most developed democracies will address multiple challenges during the June 13-15 meeting, including wars in Ukraine and the Middle East, trade imbalances with China, threats posed by artificial intelligence and development challenges in Africa.\n\nThe leaders will also announce new sanctions and export controls against Russia that target entities and networks helping Putin's forces fight the war in Ukraine. Efforts to curb Russia's growing war economy will be a major discussion topic, administration officials have said.\n\nThe US on Wednesday dramatically broadened sanctions on Russia, including by targeting China-based companies selling semiconductors to Moscow, as part of its effort to undercut the Russian military machine waging war on Ukraine.\n\nSeparately, the Commerce Department said it was targeting shell companies in Hong Kong for diverting semiconductors to Russia, taking steps that would affect nearly $100 million of high-priority items for Moscow including such chips.\n\n\"These actions heighten the risk for financial institutions dealing with Russia's war economy, slows down avenues for evasion while diminishes Russia's ability to benefit from access to foreign technology, equipment, software and IT services,\" Sullivan said.\n\nShoring up funding for Ukraine will be a top priority at the G7 meeting, with US and European officials eager to lock in solutions, ahead of a possible Trump re-election and the uncertainty it would raise over future US support for Kyiv.\n\nThe Group of Seven nations and the European Union are considering how to use profits generated by Russian assets immobilized in the West to provide Ukraine with a large up-front loan to secure Kyiv's financing for 2025.\n\nThe White House's Sullivan said the US is \"making good progress in generating an outcome in which those proceeds from those frozen assets can be put to good use.\"\n\nBiden will press other G7 leaders to agree to an innovative plan to use future interest on some $281 billion of Russian central bank funds to back up a $50 billion loan to Ukraine.\n\nG7 leaders also face electoral challenges, with polls indicating British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak will likely lose power in a national vote next month, and the leaders of France and Germany reeling from heavy defeats in recent European elections.", "source": {"uri": "bdnews24.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8175878095", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "11:04:14", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T11:04:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T11:03:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.digitaljournal.com/world/g7-to-agree-50-bn-ukraine-loan-at-italy-summit/article", "title": "G7 to agree $50-bn Ukraine loan at Italy summit", "body": "Leaders of the G7 wealthy nations gather in southern Italy this week against the backdrop of global and political turmoil, with boosting support for Ukraine top of the agenda. - Copyright AFP Filippo MONTEFORTE\n\nG7 leaders were set to agree on a new $50-billion loan for Ukraine as they gathered Thursday for a summit in southern Italy, using the profits from frozen Russian assets.\n\nUkrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky will join US President Joe Biden and leaders from Italy, Britain, France, Germany, Canada and Japan for the talks at the luxury Borgo Egnazia resort in Puglia.\n\nTop of the agenda is a plan for an urgent $50-billion loan to help Kyiv with defence, budgetary support and reconstruction after more than two years of war with Russia.\n\nThe loan would be secured against the future profits from interest on 300 billion euros ($325 billion) of Russian central bank assets frozen by Western allies.\n\n\"Good news from the G7: another $50 billion for Ukraine,\" German Finance Minister Christian Lindner wrote on X.\n\n\"We are using interest from frozen assets for this -- a smart instrument that shows (Russian President Vladimir) Putin our unity, greatly helps Ukraine and relieves the burden on budgets.\n\n\"Now we are working on the details.\"\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron's office had on Wednesday said there was a deal on providing the money by the end of this year.\n\n\"We are on the verge of a good outcome here,\" US National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan said Thursday, adding that the details still needed to be thrashed out.\n\n- Common vision -\n\nAhead of his arrival later in the day, Zelensky said he was expecting \"important decisions\" at the summit.\n\nHe also said he would sign two more security agreements with Japan and the United States in Puglia.\n\nThe G7 countries have been Ukraine's key military and financial backers since Russia invaded in February 2022.\n\nZelensky, who was due to hold a joint press conference with Biden later Thursday, has been engaged in a flurry of diplomacy aimed at boosting international support.\n\nHe spoke earlier this week in Berlin at a reconstruction conference and is set to join more than 90 countries and organisations this weekend for a peace summit in Switzerland.\n\nSullivan said the G7 leaders were aiming for a \"common vision\" on using the frozen assets.\n\n\"We have the major tentpoles of this decided but some of the specifics will be left to be worked through by experts on a defined timetable,\" he told reporters.\n\nThe European Union agreed earlier this year to use the profits from the frozen Russian assets for Ukraine, worth up to three billion euros a year.\n\nBut the idea at the G7 is to use this to provide more and faster help through a massive upfront loan.\n\nThe US this week also announced a raft of new sanctions aimed at constraining Moscow's war machine, while raising the stakes for foreign banks that still deal with Russia.\n\n- Irreplaceable role -\n\nThe summit comes at a time of extraordinary global turmoil.\n\nApart from the conflict in Ukraine, the Hamas-Israel conflict is raging and economic tensions are rising between China and Western countries.\n\nMany G7 countries are also in political flux. Everyone in Puglia is aware this could be Biden's last G7 summit if he loses to Donald Trump in November US elections.\n\nBritain's Rishi Sunak is tipped to be ousted in July 4 elections, while France's Macron and Germany's Olaf Scholz are both under pressure after gains by the far right in EU elections last weekend.\n\nBy contrast, meeting host Giorgia Meloni, Italy's prime minister, is riding high after her far-right party topped European Parliament elections last weekend.\n\nMeloni laughed and joked with her G7 counterparts as she welcomed them among the olive trees of the Borgo Egnazia resort on Thursday morning -- but had a serious message.\n\n\"The Group of Seven in recent decades has assumed an irreplaceable role in the management of global crises, especially those that jeopardise our freedom and our democracy,\" she told an opening session.\n\nThe talks began with short session on Africa, development and climate change, before turning to the Middle East.\n\nThe G7 leaders have already announced their support for a Gaza truce deal outlined by Biden, which would also see the release of hostages taken in Hamas's October 7 attack on Israel.\n\nAnother key issue in Puglia, to be discussed Friday, will be concerns about China's so-called \"industrial overcapacity\", particularly in green energy and technology sectors such as solar panels and electric vehicles.\n\nAround a dozen of non-G7 leaders have also been invited to Puglia for talks on Friday, including Jordan's King Abdullah II, Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, UAE president Sheikh Mohamed bin Zayed and India's Narendra Modi.", "source": {"uri": "digitaljournal.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Digital Journal"}, "authors": [{"uri": "agence_france_presse@digitaljournal.com", {"uri": "8175225456", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "03:02:14", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T03:02:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T03:01:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.channelnewsasia.com/world/g7-eyes-ukraine-funding-plan-italy-summit-4406926", "title": "G7 eyes Ukraine funding plan at Italy summit", "body": "BARI: G7 leaders gather on Thursday (Jun 13) for the first day of an Italy summit, seeking to seal a deal on using frozen Russian assets to help war-torn Ukraine.\n\nUkrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will join US President Joe Biden and leaders from Italy, Britain, France, Germany, Canada and Japan at the luxury Borgo Egnazia resort in Puglia.\n\nThe G7 leaders are hoping to agree on a US$50 billion loan for Kyiv, secured against the future profits from interest on \u20ac300 billion (US$325 billion) of Russian central bank assets frozen after the February 2022 invasion.\n\nThe European Union - where most of the funds are being held - agreed earlier this year to use the profits for Ukraine, worth up to \u20ac3 billion a year.\n\nBut the idea at the G7 is to use this to provide more, faster help in the form of a massive upfront loan - although key questions such as who issues the debt and who shares the risk are still being hammered out.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron's office on Wednesday said a deal had been agreed on providing US$50 billion for Ukraine before the end of the year, but said that technical details still needed to be finalised.\n\nBritain, meanwhile, said it would announce up to US$310 million in new bilateral assistance to Kyiv at the summit, adding leaders would \"explore all lawful avenues by which immobilised Russian assets can be used to support Ukraine\".\n\nThe White House also said it expected to announce at the summit \"new steps to unlock the value\" of the Russian assets.\n\nBut US National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan was on Wednesday more guarded about what this may entail, saying only that the G7 was working towards announcing \"a framework\", including a timeframe.\n\nZelenskyy is attending as part of a week of Billion Aid To Ukraine", "body": "US President Joe Biden is to meet with Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky on Thursday during the G7 summit in Puglia, Italy.\n\nG7 leaders had aimed to agree a deal on using frozen Russian central bank assets.\n\nParis:\n\nGroup of Seven leaders have agreed to provide Ukraine with $50 billion via the use of frozen Russian assets by the end of the year, the French presidency said on Wednesday.\n\n\"We have an agreement,\" a presidency official said, ahead of a G7 summit in Italy on Thursday that will focus on backing Kyiv's fight against Russia's invasion.\n\nG7 leaders had aimed to agree a deal on using the profits from the interest on 300 billion euros ($325 billion) of frozen Russian central bank assets to help Kyiv, using the profits as collateral for a loan of up to $50 billion.\n\nUS President Joe Biden is to meet with Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky on Thursday during the G7 summit in Puglia, Italy.\n\n\"Originally this was an American initiative,\" the French presidency official said, adding that in theory the loan to Ukraine would be repaid with \"the proceeds from the frozen Russian assets\".\n\nPromotedListen to the latest songs, only on JioSaavn.com\n\n\"But if for some reason or another, if the Russian assets are unfrozen or the proceeds from the Russian assets are not enough to finance the loan, then we'll The European Union also takes part.\n\nKyiv can expect to receive a huge new aid package from the G7 for its defence against Russia. The leaders are set to agree to finance a loan of $50 billion for Ukraine with interest from frozen Russian state assets.\n\nThe lion's share of the frozen assets - around 210 billion euros- is within the European Union. The Russian money generates billions in interest income every year.\n\nAfter months of negotiations, Biden and Zelensky will also sign a bilateral security agreement between the United States and Ukraine on the sidelines of the G7, the White House said.\n\nWashington also announced on the eve of the summit it was imposing sanctions on more than 300 individuals and entities connected to Russia's war economy, including financial institutions, the Moscow Stock Exchange and Chinese companies.\n\nUkraine is in the spotlight at back-to-back international gatherings in Europe. Berlin hosted the Ukraine Recovery Conference On Tuesday and Wednesday. After the G7 wraps up on Saturday, many of the same leaders are due to head to Switzerland for a Ukraine peace summit at which Russia will be absent.\n\nBesides Zelensky, the leaders of Turkey, Brazil and India will also be attending the Italy talks. Pope Francis will be the first pontiff to take part in a G7 summit; He was invited to address the risks posed by artificial intelligence.\n\nOther topics include relations with Africa and migration.", The European Union also takes part.\n\nKyiv can expect to receive a huge new aid package from the G7 for its defence against Russia. The leaders are set to agree to finance a loan of $50 billion for Ukraine with interest from frozen Russian state assets.\n\nThe lion's share of the frozen assets - around 210 billion euros- is within the European Union. The Russian money generates billions in interest income every year.\n\nAfter months of negotiations, Biden and Zelensky will also sign a bilateral security agreement between the United States and Ukraine on the sidelines of the G7, the White House said.\n\nWashington also announced on the eve of the summit it was imposing sanctions on more than 300 individuals and entities connected to Russia's war economy, including financial institutions, the Moscow Stock Exchange and Chinese companies.\n\nUkraine is in the spotlight at back-to-back international gatherings in Europe. Berlin hosted the Ukraine Recovery Conference On Tuesday and Wednesday. After the G7 wraps up on Saturday, many of the same leaders are due to head to Switzerland for a Ukraine peace summit at which Russia will be absent.\n\nBesides Zelensky, the leaders of Turkey, Brazil and India will also be attending the Italy talks. Pope Francis will be the first pontiff to take part in a G7 summit; He was invited to address the risks posed by artificial intelligence.\n\nOther topics include relations with Africa and migration.", Perennial issues such as climate change and China also will be discussed.\n\nThe G7 is an informal forum with an annual summit to discuss economic policy and security issues. The members are Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom and the United States.\n\nCurrently:\n\n-- Italy's Meloni will welcome the G7 summit fortified by an EU vote that shook French, German leaders\n\n-- In Italy's Puglia region, women take the lead in challenging the local mafia at great personal risk\n\n-- US pushes for Ukraine aid, united front against China's trade practices at G7 finance meeting\n\nHere's the latest:\n\nBARI, Italy -- Officials say the world's seven wealthiest democracies have agreed on lending Ukraine up to $50 billion using frozen Russian assets as collateral.\n\nDiplomats confirmed the agreement, which was struck before Thursday's start of the three-day G7 summit that brings together Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom and the United States.\n\nU.S. President Joe Biden and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will also sign a bilateral security agreement during the summit.\n\nEuropean officials have resisted confiscating the assets, citing legal and financial stability concerns. But the plan would use the interest earned on the assets to help Ukraine's war effort.\n\nThe U.S. proposal involves using profits from the roughly $260 billion in frozen Russian central bank assets, most of them held in the European Union, to help Ukraine.\n\nThe U.S. would issue Ukraine the $50 billion loan using windfall profits from the immobilized funds as collateral.\n\nLONDON -- U.K. Prime Minister Rishi Sunak is announcing up to 242 million pounds (286 million euros or $310 million) in nonmilitary aid to Ukraine as Group of Seven leaders gather for a summit overshadowed by war.\n\nSunak is taking time out from the U.K. election campaign to attend Thursday's gathering in southern Italy.\n\nThe U.K. government says the money will go towards \"immediate humanitarian, energy and stabilization needs\" in Ukraine. Sunak has also thrown his support behind a plan to use interest from seized Russian assets to help Ukraine rebuild.\n\nSunak said the war is at a \"critical moment\" and Ukraine's allies \"must move from 'as long as it takes' to 'whatever it takes' if we are to end this illegal war.\"\n\nThe U.K. has pledged 12.5 billion pounds to Ukraine since Russia launched its full-scale invasion on Feb. 24, 2022. That includes 7.6 billion pounds worth of military assistance.\n\nSunak is battling to keep his job after the U.K. election on July 4, with opinion polls putting his Conservatives far behind the opposition Labour Party. Labour leader Keir Starmer says he will keep up the United Kingdom's strong support for Ukraine if he becomes prime minister.", "source": {"uri": "newsmax.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8174644843", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "16:50:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T16:50:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T16:49:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/world/our-support-will-last-long-into-the-future-biden-to-sign-new-ukraine-security-deal-during-g7-summit-1.6923637", "title": "'Our support will last long into the future': Biden to sign new Ukraine security deal during G7 summit", "body": "U.S. President Joe Biden will sign a new security agreement with Ukraine on Thursday to pledge America's long-term support to the country, during his trip to Italy to meet with the Group of Seven leaders, a top U.S. official said.\n\nBiden departed for Italy on Wednesday to increase pressure on Russia over its war against Ukraine and on China for its support of Moscow and excess industrial capacity.\n\nThe agreement will make clear \"our support will last long into the future... particularly in the defence and security space,\" White House national security adviser Jake Sullivan told reporters aboard Air Force One.\n\n\"By signing this we'll also be sending Russia a signal of our resolve. If Vladimir Putin thinks he can outlast the coalition supporting Ukraine, he's wrong,\" Sullivan said.\n\nFifteen countries have signed the security agreement, which will strengthen Ukraine's \"defensive deterrence capability,\" he added.\n\nThe White House had said earlier Biden will meet again with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy at the summit, followed by a joint press conference.\n\nThe G7 leaders arrive at the summit confronting myriad woes at home even as they seek solutions for many of the world's most pressing problems.\n\nBiden, 81, spent Tuesday evening at his home in Wilmington, Del., after a 12-member jury convicted his son Hunter Biden of lying about his drug use to illegally buy a gun in 2018, making him the first child of a sitting U.S. president to be convicted of a crime.\n\nThe trial followed the May 30 criminal conviction of Republican former president Donald Trump, the first former U.S. president to be found guilty of a felony. Biden and Trump are running against each other in the November presidential election and are neck-and-neck in the polls.\n\nThe heads of the world's most developed democracies will address multiple challenges during the June 13-15 meeting, including wars in Ukraine and the Middle East, trade imbalances with China, threats posed by artificial intelligence and development challenges in Africa.\n\nThe leaders will also announce new sanctions and export controls against Russia that target entities and networks helping Putin's forces fight the war in Ukraine, White House spokesperson John Kirby said on Tuesday.\n\n\"We're going to continue to drive up costs for the Russian war machine,\" Kirby said.\n\nWashington plans to widen sanctions on the sale of semiconductor chips and other goods to Russia, with the goal of targeting third-party sellers in China, sources familiar with the plans said late on Tuesday.\n\nThe administration will announce it is broadening existing export controls to include U.S.-branded goods, not just those made in the United States, the sources said. It will identify certain Hong Kong entities it says are shipping goods to Moscow.\n\nShoring up funding for Ukraine will be a top priority at the G7 meeting, with U.S. and European officials eager to lock in solutions, ahead of a possible Trump re-election and the uncertainty it would raise over future U.S. support for Kyiv.\n\nThe Group of Seven nations and the European Union are considering how to use profits generated by Russian assets immobilized in the West to provide Ukraine with a large up-front loan to secure Kyiv's financing for 2025.\n\n\"We will announce new steps to unlock the value of the immobilized Russian sovereign assets to benefit Ukraine and to help them recover from the destruction that Mr. Putin's army has caused,\" Kirby said.\n\nBiden will press other G7 leaders to agree to an innovative plan to use future interest on some US$281 billion of Russian central bank funds to back up a US$50-billion loan to Ukraine.\n\nG7 leaders also face electoral challenges, with polls indicating British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak will likely lose power in a national vote next month, and the leaders of France and Germany reeling from heavy defeats in recent European "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.breakingnews.ie/world/biden-and-zelensky-to-sign-security-agreement-between-us-and-ukraine-at-summit-1637562.html", "title": "Biden and Zelensky to sign security agreement between US and Ukraine at summit | BreakingNews.ie", "body": "President Joe Biden and President Volodymyr Zelensky will sign a bilateral security agreement between the US and Ukraine on Thursday when they meet on the sidelines of the G7 summit.\n\nThe aim is to send a signal to Russia of American resolve over support for Kyiv, the White House said as Mr Biden headed to Italy.\n\nNational security adviser Jake Sullivan told reporters that the agreement would not commit US troops directly to Ukraine's defence against Russia's invasion - a red line drawn by Mr Biden, who is fearful of being drawn into direct conflict between the nuclear-armed powers.\n\n\"We want to demonstrate that the US supports the people of Ukraine, that we stand with them and that we'll continue to help address their security needs,\" Mr Sullivan said, adding \"this agreement will show our resolve\".\n\nMr Sullivan called the agreement a \"bridge\" to when Ukraine is invited to join the Nato alliance - a long-term priority of Mr Zelensky's that the allies have said will first require an end to the Russia-Ukraine war.\n\nMr Biden heads to the summit of the world's leading democracies with an urgency to get big things done, including turning frozen Russian assets into billions of dollars to help Ukraine as it fights off Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\nThis year's G7 summit comes three years after Mr Biden declared at his first such gathering that America was back as a global leader following the disruptions to western alliances that occurred when Donald Trump was president.\n\nNow, there is a chance this gathering could be the final G7 for Mr Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of elections this year.\n\nMr Biden and his counterparts from Canada, the UK, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related to the spread of artificial intelligence, migration, the Russian military's resurgence and China's economic might, among other topics.\n\nPope Francis, Mr Zelensky and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan are joining the gathering at the Borgo Egnazia resort in the Puglia region of southern Italy.\n\nThe summit, which opens on Thursday, will play out after far-right parties across the continent secured gains of surprising scale in just-concluded European Union elections.\n\nThose victories, coupled with upcoming elections in the UK, France and the US, have rattled the global political establishment and added weightiness to this year's summit.\n\n\"You hear this a lot when you talk to US and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether it's on China, whether it's on the assets, we may not have another chance,\" said Josh Lipsky, senior director of the Atlantic Council's GeoEconomics Centre, an international affairs think tank.\n\n\"We don't know what the world will look like three months, six months, nine months from now.\"", {"uri": "8174764027", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "18:24:02", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T18:24:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T18:23:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://tribune.com.pk/story/2471293/us-to-sign-new-security-deal-with-ukraine", "title": "US to sign new security deal with Ukraine", "body": "United States (US) President Joe Biden will sign a new security agreement with Ukraine on Thursday to pledge America's long-term support to the country, during his trip to Italy to meet with the Group of Seven leaders, a top US official said.\n\nBiden departed for Italy on Wednesday to increase pressure on Russia over its war against Ukraine and on China for its support of Moscow and excess industrial capacity.\n\nThe agreement will make clear \"our support will last long into the future... particularly in the defense and security space,\" White House national security adviser Jake Sullivan told reporters aboard Air Force One.\n\n\"By signing this, we'll also be sending Russia a signal of our resolve. If Vladimir Putin thinks he can outlast the coalition supporting Ukraine, he's wrong,\" Sullivan said. Fifteen countries have signed the security agreement, which will strengthen Ukraine's \"defensive deterrence capability,\" he added.\n\nThe White House had said earlier that Biden would meet again with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy at the summit, followed by a joint press conference.\n\nThe G7 leaders arrive at the summit confronting myriad woes at home even as they seek solutions for many of the world's most pressing problems.\n\nBiden spent Tuesday evening at his home in Wilmington, Delaware, after a 12-member jury convicted his son Hunter Biden of lying about his drug use to illegally buy a gun in 2018, making him the first child of a sitting US president to be convicted of a crime.\n\nThe trial followed the May 30 criminal conviction of Republican former President Donald Trump, the first former US president to be found guilty of a felony. Biden and Trump are running against each other in the November presidential election and are neck-and-neck in the polls.\n\nThe heads of the world's most developed democracies will address multiple challenges during the June 13-15 meeting, including wars in Ukraine and the Middle East, trade imbalances with China, threats posed by artificial intelligence, and development challenges in Africa.\n\nThe leaders will also announce new sanctions and export controls against Russia that target entities and networks helping Putin's forces fight the war in Ukraine, White House spokesperson John Kirby said on Tuesday.\n\n\"We're going to continue to drive up costs for the Russian war machine,\" Kirby said.\n\nWashington plans to widen sanctions on the sale of semiconductor chips and other goods to Russia, to target third-party sellers in China, sources familiar with the plans said late on Tuesday.\n\nThe administration will announce it is broadening existing export controls to include US-branded goods, not just those made in the United States, the sources said. It will identify certain Hong Kong entities that ship goods to Moscow.\n\nShoring up funding for Ukraine will be a top priority at the G7 meeting, with US and European officials eager to lock in solutions, ahead of a possible Trump re-election and the uncertainty it would raise over future US support for Kyiv.\n\nThe Group of Seven nations and the European Union are considering how to use profits generated by Russian assets immobilized in the West to provide Ukraine with a large up-front loan to secure Kyiv's financing for 2025.\n\n\"We will announce new steps to unlock the value of the immobilized Russian sovereign assets to benefit Ukraine and to help them recover from the destruction that Mr. Putin's army has caused,\" Kirby said.\n\nBiden will press other G7 leaders to agree to an innovative plan to use future interest on some $281 billion of Russian central bank funds to back up a $50 billion loan to Ukraine.\n\nG7 leaders also face electoral challenges, with polls indicating British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak will likely lose power in a national vote next month, and the leaders of France and Germany reeling from heavy defeats in recent European elections.", Perennial issues such as climate change and China also will be discussed.\n\nThe G7 is an informal forum with an annual summit to discuss economic policy and security issues. The members are Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom and the United States.\n\nCurrently:\n\n- Italy\u00b4s Meloni will welcome the G7 summit fortified by an EU vote that shook French, German leaders\n\nItalian Carabinieri, paramilitary policemen, patrol at a roadblock near Borgo Egnazia, venue of the G7 summit in southern Italy, Wednesday, June 12, 2024. A Group of Seven summit aiming to consolidate support for Ukraine opens Thursday under a vastly different political landscape than even a few days ago, after European Parliament elections jolted the leaders of France and Germany and emboldened Italian Premier Giorgia Meloni. (AP Photo/Gregorio Borgia)\n\n- In Italy\u00b4s Puglia region, women take the lead in challenging the local mafia at great personal risk\n\n- US pushes for Ukraine aid, united front against China\u00b4s trade practices at G7 finance meeting\n\nHere's the latest:\n\nBARI, Italy - Officials say the world\u00b4s seven wealthiest democracies have agreed on lending Ukraine up to $50 billion using frozen Russian assets as collateral.\n\nDiplomats confirmed the agreement, which was struck before Thursday\u00b4s start of the three-day G7 summit that brings together Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom and the United States.\n\nU.S. President Joe Biden and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will also sign a bilateral security agreement during the summit.\n\nEuropean officials have resisted confiscating the assets, citing legal and financial stability concerns. But the plan would use the interest earned on the assets to help Ukraine\u00b4s war effort.\n\nThe U.S. proposal involves using profits from the roughly $260 billion in frozen Russian central bank assets, most of them held in the European Union, to help Ukraine.\n\nThe U.S. would issue Ukraine the $50 billion loan using windfall profits from the immobilized funds as collateral.\n\nLONDON - U.K. Prime Minister Rishi Sunak is announcing up to 242 million pounds (286 million euros or $310 million) in nonmilitary aid to Ukraine as Group of Seven leaders gather for a summit overshadowed by war.\n\nSunak is taking time out from the U.K. election campaign to attend Thursday's gathering in southern Italy.\n\nThe U.K. government says the money will go towards \"immediate humanitarian, energy and stabilization needs\" in Ukraine. Sunak has also thrown his support behind a plan to use interest from seized Russian assets to help Ukraine rebuild.\n\nSunak said the war is at a \"critical moment\" and Ukraine\u00b4s allies \"must move from 'as long as it takes\u00b4 to 'whatever it takes\u00b4 if we are to end this illegal war.\"\n\nThe U.K. has pledged 12.5 billion pounds to Ukraine since Russia launched its full-scale invasion on Feb. 24, 2022. That includes 7.6 billion pounds worth of military assistance.\n\nSunak is battling to keep his job after the U.K. election on July 4, with opinion polls putting his Conservatives far behind the opposition Labour Party. Labour leader Keir Starmer says he will keep up the United Kingdom's strong support for Ukraine if he becomes prime minister.\n\nWorkers give the last touch to the illumination set for the Patron Saint feast in Fasano, near Borgo Egnazia, southern Italy, Wednesday, June 12, 2024. A Group of Seven summit aiming to consolidate support for Ukraine opens Thursday under a vastly different political landscape than even a few days ago, after European Parliament elections jolted the leaders of France and Germany and emboldened Italian Premier Giorgia Meloni. {"uri": "8175870778", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "10:59:53", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T10:59:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T10:59:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.legit.ng/business-economy/economy/1597204-g7-agree-50-bn-ukraine-loan-italy-summit/", "title": "G7 to agree $50-bn Ukraine loan at Italy summit", "body": "PAY ATTENTION: Legit.ng Entertainment Awards 2024 Voting Is Alive. Choose the best entertainer in 15 categories for FREE.\n\nG7 leaders were set to agree on a new $50-billion loan for Ukraine as they gathered Thursday for a summit in southern Italy, using the profits from frozen Russian assets.\n\nUkrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky will join US President Joe Biden and leaders from Italy, Britain, France, Germany, Canada and Japan for the talks at the luxury Borgo Egnazia resort in Puglia.\n\nTop of the agenda is a plan for an urgent $50-billion loan to help Kyiv with defence, budgetary support and reconstruction after more than two years of war with Russia.\n\nThe loan would be secured against the future profits from interest on 300 billion euros ($325 billion) of Russian central bank assets frozen by Western allies.\n\n\"Good news from the G7: another $50 billion for Ukraine,\" German Finance Minister Christian Lindner wrote on X.\n\n\"We are using interest from frozen assets for this -- a smart instrument that shows (Russian President Vladimir) Putin our unity, greatly helps Ukraine and relieves the burden on budgets.\n\n\"Now we are working on the details.\"\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron's office had on Wednesday said there was a deal on providing the money by the end of this year.\n\n\"We are on the verge of a good outcome here,\" US National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan said Thursday, adding that the details still needed to be thrashed out.\n\nAhead of his arrival later in the day, Zelensky said he was expecting \"important decisions\" at the summit.\n\nHe also said he would sign two more security agreements with Japan and the United States in Puglia.\n\nThe G7 countries have been Ukraine's key military and financial backers since Russia invaded in February 2022.\n\nZelensky, who was due to hold a joint press conference with Biden later Thursday, has been engaged in a flurry of diplomacy aimed at boosting international support.\n\nHe spoke earlier this week in Berlin at a reconstruction conference and is set to join more than 90 countries and organisations this weekend for a peace summit in Switzerland.\n\nSullivan said the G7 leaders were aiming for a \"common vision\" on using the frozen assets.\n\n\"We have the major tentpoles of this decided but some of the specifics will be left to be worked through by experts on a defined timetable,\" he told reporters.\n\nThe European Union agreed earlier this year to use the profits from the frozen Russian assets for Ukraine, worth up to three billion euros a year.\n\nBut the idea at the G7 is to use this to provide more and faster help through a massive upfront loan.\n\nThe US this week also announced a raft of new sanctions aimed at constraining Moscow's war machine, while raising the stakes for foreign banks that still deal with Russia.\n\nThe summit comes at a time of extraordinary global turmoil.\n\nApart from the conflict in Ukraine, the Hamas-Israel conflict is raging and economic tensions are rising between China and Western countries.\n\nMany G7 countries are also in political flux. Everyone in Puglia is aware this could be Biden's last G7 summit if he loses to Donald Trump in November US elections.\n\nBritain's Rishi Sunak is tipped to be ousted in July 4 elections, while France's Macron and Germany's Olaf Scholz are both under pressure after gains by the far right in EU elections last weekend.\n\nBy contrast, meeting host Giorgia Meloni, Italy's prime minister, is riding high after her far-right party topped European Parliament elections last weekend.\n\nMeloni laughed and joked with her G7 counterparts as she welcomed them among the olive trees of the Borgo Egnazia resort on Thursday morning -- but had a serious message.\n\n\"The Group of Seven in recent decades has assumed an irreplaceable role in the management of global crises, especially those that jeopardise our freedom and our democracy,\" she told an opening session.\n\nThe talks began with short session on Africa, development and climate change, before turning to the Middle East.\n\nThe G7 leaders have already announced their support for a Gaza truce deal outlined by Biden, which would also see the release of hostages taken in Hamas's October 7 attack on Israel.\n\nAnother key issue in Puglia, to be discussed Friday, will be concerns about China's so-called \"industrial overcapacity\", particularly in green energy and technology sectors such as solar panels and electric vehicles.\n\nAround a dozen of non-G7 leaders have also been invited to Puglia for talks on Friday, including Jordan's King Abdullah II, Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, UAE president Sheikh Please try again later{{ /verifyErrors }}\n\nItaly is hosting the summit of the Group of Seven leading industrialized nations in the wake of the European Parliament election, which saw a surge in support for the far right in places like G7 members France and Germany.\n\nItalian Premier Giorgia Meloni also leads a far-right party but continues to hew to the center, particularly on foreign policy, which has made her a reassuring transatlantic partner amid Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine and the Israel-Hamas war in Gaza.\n\nThe G7 summit through Saturday is focusing on global conflicts, the spread of artificial intelligence and on Africa issues, with a view in particular to Italy's longstanding concern about uncontrolled migration to Europe and human traffickers. Perennial issues such as climate change and China also will be discussed.\n\nThe G7 is an informal forum with an annual summit to discuss economic policy and security issues. The members are Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom and the United States.\n\nCurrently:\n\n-- Italy's Meloni will welcome the G7 summit fortified by an EU vote that shook French, German leaders\n\n-- In Italy's Puglia region, women take the lead in challenging the local mafia at great personal risk\n\n-- US pushes for Ukraine aid, united front against China's trade practices at G7 finance meeting\n\nHere's the latest:\n\nG7 leaders agree to lend Ukraine $50 billion using frozen Russian assets as collateral\n\nBARI, Italy -- Officials say the world's seven wealthiest democracies have agreed on lending Ukraine up to $50 billion using frozen Russian assets as collateral.\n\nDiplomats confirmed the agreement, which was struck before Thursday's start of the three-day G7 summit that brings together Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom and the United States.\n\nU.S. President Joe Biden and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will also sign a bilateral security agreement during the summit.\n\nEuropean officials have resisted confiscating the assets, citing legal and financial stability concerns. But the plan would use the interest earned on the assets to help Ukraine's war effort.\n\nThe U.S. proposal involves using profits from the roughly $260 billion in frozen Russian central bank assets, most of them held in the European Union, to help Ukraine.\n\nThe U.S. would issue Ukraine the $50 billion loan using windfall profits from the immobilized funds as collateral.\n\nUnited Kingdom pledges $310 million in nonmilitary aid to Ukraine\n\nLONDON -- U.K. Prime Minister Rishi Sunak is announcing up to 242 million pounds (286 million euros or $310 million) in nonmilitary aid to Ukraine as Group of Seven leaders gather for a summit overshadowed by war.\n\nSunak is taking time out from the U.K. election campaign to attend Thursday's gathering in southern Italy.\n\nThe U.K. government says the money will go towards \"immediate humanitarian, energy and stabilization needs\" in Ukraine. Sunak has also thrown his support behind a plan to use interest from seized Russian assets to help Ukraine rebuild.\n\nSunak said the war is at a \"critical moment\" and Ukraine's allies \"must move from 'as long as it takes' to 'whatever it takes' if we are to end this illegal war.\"\n\nThe U.K. has pledged 12.5 billion pounds to Ukraine since Russia launched its full-scale invasion on Feb. 24, 2022. That includes 7.6 billion pounds worth of military assistance.\n\nSunak is battling to keep his job after the U.K. election on July 4, with opinion polls putting his Conservatives far behind the opposition Labour Party. Labour leader Keir Starmer says he will keep up the United Kingdom's strong support for Ukraine if he becomes prime minister.\n\nTown hosting G7 summit also a faux medieval venue for Hollywood elite\n\nBORGO EGNAZIA, Italy -- Madonna and the Beckhams have reportedly stayed there, and Jessica Biel and Justin Timberlake got married there.\n\nBorgo Egnazia in Italy's southern Puglia region has certainly had its share of star power and on Thursday hosts another set of VIP guests: the leaders of the world's industrialized democracies.\n\nBut the venue for the Group of Seven summit is also something of a theater set, a faux town made to resemble one of Puglia's medieval white-washed hamlets but that actually only dates from 2010.\n\nLocated next to an actual archaeological park, Borgo Egnazia features narrow streets, villas, restaurants and a town square complete with a clocktower.", "source": {"uri": "independent.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Independent"}, "authors": {"uri": "8174877578", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "20:07:17", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T20:07:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T20:06:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/2980793-bidens-bold-security-pact-long-term-support-for-ukraine-and-stand-against-russia", "title": "Biden's Bold Security Pact: Long-Term Support for Ukraine and Stand Against Russia | Politics", "body": "U.S. President Joe Biden will sign a new security agreement with Ukraine on Thursday to pledge America's long-term support to the country, during his meeting with leaders of the Group of Seven democracies in Italy, a top U.S. official said. Biden departed for Italy on Wednesday to increase pressure on Russia over its war against Ukraine and on China for its support of Moscow and excess industrial capacity.\n\nThe agreement will make clear \"our support will last long into the future... particularly in the defense and security space,\" White House national security adviser Jake Sullivan told reporters aboard Air Force One. \"By signing this we'll also be sending Russia a signal of our resolve. If Vladimir Putin thinks he can outlast the coalition supporting Ukraine, he's wrong,\" Sullivan said.\n\nFifteen countries have signed their own security agreements, which will strengthen Ukraine's \"defensive deterrence capability,\" he said. The U.S. agreement will include a commitment to working with the U.S. Congress on funding Ukraine going forward but will not commit to using U.S. forces on the ground, Sullivan added. The White House had said earlier that Biden will meet again with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy at the summit, followed by a joint press conference. The U.S. also expects Biden to meet India's Narendra Modi, who was sworn in as prime minister for a third term, and is waiting for India to formally confirm Modi's attendance at the summit.\n\nThe G7 leaders arrive at the summit confronting myriad woes at home even as they seek solutions for many of the world's most pressing problems. Biden, 81, spent Tuesday evening at his home in Wilmington, Delaware, after a 12-member jury convicted his son Hunter Biden of lying about his drug use to illegally buy a gun in 2018, making him the first child of a sitting U.S. president to be convicted of a crime.\n\nThe trial followed the May 30 criminal conviction of Republican former President Donald Trump, the first former U.S. president to be found guilty of a felony. Biden and Trump are running against each other in the November presidential election and are neck-and-neck in the polls. The heads of the world's most developed democracies will address multiple challenges during the June 13-15 meeting, including wars in Ukraine and the Middle East, trade imbalances with China, threats posed by artificial intelligence and development challenges in Africa.\n\nThe leaders will also announce new sanctions and export controls against Russia that target entities and networks helping Putin's forces fight the war in Ukraine. Efforts to curb Russia's growing war economy will be a major discussion topic, administration officials have said. The U.S. on Wednesday dramatically broadened sanctions on Russia, including by targeting China-based companies selling semiconductors to Moscow, as part of its effort to undercut the Russian military machine waging war on Ukraine.\n\nSeparately, the Commerce Department said it was targeting shell companies in Hong Kong for diverting semiconductors to Russia, taking steps that would affect nearly $100 million of high-priority items for Moscow including such chips. \"These actions heighten the risk for financial institutions dealing with Russia's war economy, slows down avenues for evasion while diminishes Russia's ability to benefit from access to foreign technology, equipment, software and IT services,\" Sullivan said.\n\nShoring up funding for Ukraine will be a top priority at the G7 meeting, with U.S. and European officials eager to lock in solutions, ahead of a possible Trump re-election and the uncertainty it would raise over future U.S. support for Kyiv. The Group of Seven nations and the European Union are considering how to use profits generated by Russian assets immobilized in the West to provide Ukraine with a large up-front loan to secure Kyiv's financing for 2025.\n\nThe White House's Sullivan said the U.S. is \"making good progress in generating an outcome in which those proceeds from those frozen assets can be put to good use.\" Biden will press other G7 leaders to agree to an innovative plan to use future interest on some $281 billion of Russian central bank funds to back up a $50 billion loan to Ukraine.\n\nG7 leaders also face electoral challenges, with polls indicating British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak will likely lose power in a national vote next month, and the leaders of France and Germany reeling from heavy defeats in recent European elections.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8175198948", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "02:27:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T02:27:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T02:27:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.asiaone.com/world/biden-will-sign-new-security-agreement-ukraine-during-g7-summit", "title": "AsiaOne", "body": "WASHINGTON -- US President Joe Biden will sign a new security agreement with Ukraine on Thursday (June 13) to pledge America's long-term support to the country, during his meeting with leaders of the Group of Seven democracies in Italy, a top US official said.\n\nBiden departed for Italy on Wednesday to increase pressure on Russia over its war against Ukraine and on China for its support of Moscow and excess industrial capacity.\n\nThe agreement will make clear \"our support will last long into the future... particularly in the defence and security space,\" White House national security adviser Jake Sullivan told reporters aboard Air Force One.\n\n\"By signing this we'll also be sending Russia a signal of our resolve. If Vladimir Putin thinks he can outlast the coalition supporting Ukraine, he's wrong,\" Sullivan said.\n\nFifteen countries have signed their own security agreements, which will strengthen Ukraine's \"defencive deterrence capability,\" he said. The US agreement will include a commitment to working with the US Congress on funding Ukraine going forward but will not commit to using US forces on the ground, Sullivan added.\n\nThe White House had said earlier that Biden will meet again with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy at the summit, followed by a joint press conference. The US also expects Biden to meet India's Narendra Modi, who was sworn in as prime minister for a third term, and is waiting for India to formally confirm Modi's attendance at the summit.\n\nThe G7 leaders arrive at the summit confronting myriad woes at home even as they seek solutions for many of the world's most pressing problems.\n\nBiden, 81, spent Tuesday evening at his home in Wilmington, Delaware, after a 12-member jury convicted his son Hunter Biden of lying about his drug use to illegally buy a gun in 2018, making him the first child of a sitting US president to be convicted of a crime.\n\nThe trial followed the May 30 criminal conviction of Republican former President Donald Trump, the first former US president to be found guilty of a felony. Biden and Trump are running against each other in the November presidential election and are neck-and-neck in the polls.\n\nThe heads of the world's most developed democracies will address multiple challenges during the June 13-15 meeting, including wars in Ukraine and the Middle East, trade imbalances with China, threats posed by artificial intelligence and development challenges in Africa.\n\nThe leaders will also announce new sanctions and export controls against Russia that target entities and networks helping Putin's forces fight the war in Ukraine. Efforts to curb Russia's growing war economy will be a major discussion topic, administration officials have said.\n\nThe US on Wednesday dramatically broadened sanctions on Russia, including by targeting China-based companies selling semiconductors to Moscow, as part of its effort to undercut the Russian military machine waging war on Ukraine.\n\nSeparately, the Commerce Department said it was targeting shell companies in Hong Kong for diverting semiconductors to Russia, taking steps that would affect nearly US$100 million (S$134 million) of high-priority items for Moscow including such chips.\n\n\"These actions heighten the risk for financial institutions dealing with Russia's war economy, slows down avenues for evasion while diminishes Russia's ability to benefit from access to foreign technology, equipment, software and IT services,\" Sullivan said.\n\nShoring up funding for Ukraine will be a top priority at the G7 meeting, with US and European officials eager to lock in solutions, ahead of a possible Trump re-election and the uncertainty it would raise over future US support for Kyiv.\n\nThe Group of Seven nations and the European Union are considering how to use profits generated by Russian assets immobilised in the West to provide Ukraine with a large up-front loan to secure Kyiv's financing for 2025.\n\nThe White House's Sullivan said the US is \"making good progress in generating an outcome in which those proceeds from those frozen assets can be put to good use.\"\n\nBiden will press other G7 leaders to agree to an innovative plan to use future interest on some US$281 billion of Russian central bank funds to back up a US$50 billion loan to Ukraine.\n\nG7 leaders also face electoral challenges, with polls indicating British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak will likely lose power in a national vote next month, and the leaders of France and Germany reeling from heavy defeats in recent European elections.", "source": {"uri": "asiaone.com", {"uri": "2024-06-387926708", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "05:52:34", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T05:52:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T05:47:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.newindianexpress.com/world/2024/Jun/13/g7-summit-opens-with-deal-to-use-russian-assets-for-ukraine-as-eus-traditional-powers-recalibrate", "title": "G7 summit opens with deal to use Russian assets for Ukraine as EU's traditional powers recalibrate", "body": "BARI: A Group of Seven summit is opening Thursday with agreement on a U.S. proposal to back a $50 billion loan to Ukraine using frozen Russian assets as collateral, giving Kyiv a strong show of support even as Europe's political chessboard shifts to the right.\n\nDiplomats confirmed that an agreement had been reached on the deal before the leaders even landed in southern Italy for the three-day summit. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will be on hand and is expected to sign a separate bilateral security agreement with U.S. President Joe Biden.\n\nBeyond the Ukraine war, Pope Francis will become the first pope to address a G7 summit, adding a dash of celebrity and moral authority to the annual gathering that is being held this year in Italy's sun-drenched Puglia region. He'll be speaking Friday about the promises and perils of artificial intelligence, but is expected to also renew his appeal for a peaceful end to wars in Ukraine and Gaza.\n\nThe G7 includes Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom and the United States. Host Italy has invited several African leaders -- Algerian President Abdelmadjid Tebboune, Kenyan President William Ruto and Tunisian President Kais Saied -- to press Italy's Africa initiatives. Other guests include Brazilian President Luiz In\u00e1cio Lula da Silva, Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, fresh off his own election, and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.\n\nWith Biden, British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak and now French President Emmanuel Macron facing elections in the coming months, pressure was on the G7 to get done what it can while the status quo lasts.\n\nFrozen Russian assets to support Ukraine\n\nThe U.S. proposal involves using profits from the roughly $260 billion in frozen Russian central bank assets, most of them held in the European Union, to help Ukraine, and issuing a $50 billion loan from the U.S. government to Kyiv, using windfall profits from the immobilized funds as collateral.\n\nA French official, briefing reporters Wednesday, said a political decision by the leaders had been reached but that technical and legal details of the mechanism to tap into the assets still had to be worked out. The issue is complicated because if the Russian assets one day are unfrozen -- say if the war ends -- then the windfall profits will no longer be able to be used to pay off the loan, requiring a burden-sharing arrangement with other countries.\n\nOn the eve of the summit, Washington also sent strong signals of support for Ukraine, with widened sanctions against Russia to target Chinese companies that are helping its war machine.\n\nEurope's new political chessboard\n\nItalian Premier Giorgia Meloni goes into the meeting fortified at home and abroad after her far-right party had an even stronger showing in weekend European Parliament elections than the 2022 elections that made her Italy's first female premier. Known for its revolving-door governments, Italy is now in the unusual position of being the most stable power in the EU.\n\nThe leaders of the G7's two other EU members, Germany and France, didn't fare nearly as well, rattled after hard-right parties made strong showings in the vote. Macron called a snap election and German Chancellor Olaf Scholz saw the far-right Alternative for Germany beat out his Social Democrats.", "source": {"uri": "newindianexpress.com", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.channelnewsasia.com/world/g7-expects-us50-billion-ukraine-plan-italy-summit-4406926", "title": "G7 expects US$50 billion Ukraine plan at Italy summit", "body": "G7 leaders gather on Thursday (Jun 13) for the first day of an Italy summit, hoping to seal a deal on providing US$50 billion for Ukraine using frozen Russian assets.\n\nUkrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will join US President Joe Biden and leaders from Italy, Britain, France, Germany, Canada and Japan at the luxury Borgo Egnazia resort in Puglia.\n\nThe G7 leaders hope to agree on an urgent US$50 billion loan to help Kyiv with defence, budgetary support and help for reconstruction after more than two years of war with Russia.\n\nThe loan would be secured against the future profits from interest on \u20ac300 billion (US$325 billion) of Russian central bank assets frozen by Western allies.\n\n\"We are on the verge of a good outcome here,\" US National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan said.\n\n\"Hopefully by the time that leaders meet today, we will have a common vision on the way forward,\" he told reporters ahead of the formal opening of the summit.\n\nBut he said delegations were still thrashing out the details, including how many countries would \"step up\" and the kind of financial vehicle involved.\n\n\"We have the major tentpoles of this decided but some of the specifics will be left to be worked through by experts on a defined timetable,\" he told reporters.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron's office on Wednesday said a deal had been agreed on providing US$50 billion for Ukraine before the end of the year, but said that technical details still needed to be finalised.\n\nThe European Union agreed earlier this year to use the profits from the frozen Russian assets for Ukraine, worth up to \u20ac3 billion a year.\n\nBut the idea at the G7 is to use this to provide more and faster help through a massive upfront loan.\n\nZelenskyy is attending the Puglia summit as part of a week of diplomatic efforts to rally support, which will culminate in an international conference on Ukraine in Switzerland this weekend.\n\nG7 nations are also expected to announce further bilateral support, with Biden and Zelenskyy due to sign a US-Ukraine security deal, and Britain announcing up to US$310 million for Kyiv.\n\nThe US this week announced a raft of new sanctions aimed at constraining Moscow's war machine while raising the stakes for foreign banks that still deal with Russia.", "source": {"uri": "channelnewsasia.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8175756948", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "09:51:32", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T09:51:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T09:50:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.ndtv.com/world-news/biden-to-sign-new-security-agreement-with-ukraine-at-g7-summit-5880859", "title": "Biden To Sign New Security Agreement With Ukraine At G7 Summit", "body": "The agreement will make clear \"our support will last long into the future...\"\n\nWashington:\n\nU.S. President Joe Biden will sign a new security agreement with Ukraine on Thursday to pledge America's long-term support to the country, during his meeting with leaders of the Group of Seven democracies in Italy, a top U.S. official said.\n\nBiden departed for Italy on Wednesday to increase pressure on Russia over its war against Ukraine and on China for its support of Moscow and excess industrial capacity.\n\nThe agreement will make clear \"our support will last long into the future... particularly in the defense and security space,\" White House national security adviser Jake Sullivan told reporters aboard Air Force One.\n\n\"By signing this we'll also be sending Russia a signal of our resolve. If Vladimir Putin thinks he can outlast the coalition supporting Ukraine, he's wrong,\" Sullivan said.\n\nFifteen countries have signed their own security agreements, which will strengthen Ukraine's \"defensive deterrence capability,\" he said. The U.S. agreement will include a commitment to working with the U.S. Congress on funding Ukraine going forward but will not commit to using U.S. forces on the ground, Sullivan added.\n\nThe White House had said earlier that Biden will meet again with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy at the summit, followed by a joint press conference. The U.S. also expects Biden to meet India's Narendra Modi, who was sworn in as prime minister for a third term and is waiting for India to formally confirm Modi's attendance at the summit.\n\nThe G7 leaders arrive at the summit confronting myriad problems at home even as they seek solutions for many of the world's most pressing problems.\n\nBiden, 81, spent Tuesday evening at his home in Wilmington, Delaware, after a 12-member jury convicted his son Hunter Biden of lying about his drug use to illegally buy a gun in 2018, making him the first child of a sitting U.S. president to be convicted of a crime.\n\nThe trial followed the May 30 criminal conviction of Republican former President Donald Trump, the first former U.S. president to be found guilty of a felony. Biden and Trump are running against each other in the November presidential election and are neck-and-neck in the polls.\n\nThe heads of the world's most developed democracies will address multiple challenges during the June 13-15 meeting, including wars in Ukraine and the Middle East, trade imbalances with China, threats posed by artificial intelligence and development challenges in Africa.\n\nThe leaders will also announce new sanctions and export controls against Russia that target entities and networks helping Putin's forces fight the war in Ukraine. Efforts to curb Russia's growing war economy will be a major discussion topic, administration officials have said.\n\nThe U.S. on Wednesday dramatically broadened sanctions on Russia, including by targeting China-based companies selling semiconductors to Moscow, as part of its effort to undercut the Russian military machine waging war on Ukraine.\n\nSeparately, the Commerce Department said it was targeting shell companies in Hong Kong for diverting semiconductors to Russia, taking steps that would affect nearly $100 million of high-priority items for Moscow including such chips.\n\n\"These actions heighten the risk for financial institutions dealing with Russia's war economy, slows down avenues for evasion while diminishes Russia's ability to benefit from access to foreign technology, equipment, software, and IT services,\" Sullivan said.\n\nShoring up funding for Ukraine will be a top priority at the G7 meeting, with U.S. and European officials eager to lock in solutions, ahead of a possible Trump re-election and the uncertainty it would raise over future U.S. support for Kyiv.\n\nThe Group of Seven nations and the European Union are considering how to use profits generated by Russian assets immobilized in the West to provide Ukraine with a large up-front loan to secure Kyiv's financing for 2025.\n\nThe White House's Sullivan said the U.S. is \"making good progress in generating an outcome in which those proceeds from those frozen assets can be put to good use.\"\n\nBiden will press other G7 leaders to agree to an innovative plan to use future interest on some $281 billion of Russian central bank funds to back up a $50 billion loan to Ukraine.\n\nPromotedListen to the latest songs, only on JioSaavn.com\n\nG7 leaders also face electoral challenges, with polls indicating British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak will likely lose power in a national vote next month, and the leaders of France and Germany reeling from heavy defeats in recent European elections.\n\n(Except for the headline, this story has not been edited by NDTV staff and is published from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "ndtv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NDTV"}, "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.bssnews.net/news/194917", "title": "G7 eyes Ukraine funding plan at Italy summit | News", "body": "BARI, Italy, June 13, 2024 (BSS/AFP) - G7 leaders gather Thursday for the first day of an Italy summit, seeking to seal a deal on using frozen Russian assets to help war-torn Ukraine.\n\nUkrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky will join US President Joe Biden and leaders from Italy, Britain, France, Germany, Canada and Japan at the luxury Borgo Egnazia resort in Puglia.\n\nThe G7 leaders are hoping to agree on a $50 billion loan for Kyiv, secured against the future profits from interest on 300 billion euros ($325 billion) of Russian central bank assets frozen after the February 2022 invasion.\n\nThe European Union -- where most of the funds are being held -- agreed earlier this year to use the profits for Ukraine, worth up to three billion euros a year.\n\nBut the idea at the G7 is to use this to provide more, faster help in the form of a massive upfront loan -- although key questions such as who issues the debt and who shares the risk are still being hammered out.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron's office on Wednesday said a deal had been agreed on providing $50 billion for Ukraine before the end of the year, but said that technical details still needed to be finalised.\n\nBritain, meanwhile, said it would announce up to $310 million in new bilateral assistance to Kyiv at the summit, adding leaders would \"explore all lawful avenues by which immobilised Russian assets can be used to support Ukraine\".\n\nThe White House also said it expected to announce at the summit \"new steps to unlock the value\" of the Russian assets.\n\nBut US National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan was on Wednesday more guarded about what this may entail, saying only that the G7 was working towards announcing \"a framework\", including a timeframe.\n\nZelensky is attending as part of a week of diplomatic efforts to rally support as his country's outmanned and outgunned forces struggle against Russia.\n\nIt will culminate in an international conference on Ukraine in Switzerland this weekend.\n\n- Mideast, China -\n\nThe summit comes at a time of extraordinary global turmoil.\n\nAs well as the conflict in Ukraine -- now in its third year -- the Hamas-Israel conflict is raging and economic tensions are rising between China and Western countries.\n\nMany G7 countries are also in political flux. Everyone in Puglia is aware this could be Biden's last G7 summit if he loses to Donald Trump in November US elections.\n\nBritain's Rishi Sunak is tipped to be ousted in July 4 elections, while France's Macron and Germany's Olaf Scholz are both under pressure after gains by the far right in EU elections last weekend.\n\nThe G7 summit opens Thursday morning with a short session on Africa, development and climate change, before turning to the Middle East.\n\nThe leaders have already announced their support for a Gaza truce deal outlined by Biden, which would also see the release of hostages taken in Hamas's October 7 attack on Israel.\n\nJordan's King Abdullah II -- a strong supporter of the Palestinian cause whose country signed a peace treaty with Israel 30 years ago -- is among around a dozen non-G7 guests also attending who are not, however, participating in the working sessions.\n\nThey include Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, UAE president Sheikh Mohamed bin Zayed and India's Narendra Modi.\n\nBrazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva -- whose country holds the rotating G20 presidency this year -- as well as Argentina's Javier Milei and UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres also plan to attend.\n\nAll the guests are invited to a dinner Friday night at the Borgo Egnazia luxury hotel complex, built in the style of a traditional village.\n\nWith security extremely tight, the venue is far away from protesters and journalists, with the media centre located some 60 kilometres away in Bari.\n\nAnother key issue in Puglia, to be discussed Friday, will be concerns about China's so-called \"industrial overcapacity\", particularly in green energy and technology sectors such as solar panels and electric vehicles.\n\nThe US, EU and Japan have all voiced concern that generous subsidies from Beijing are resulting in a flood of cheap goods hitting the global market, threatening Western firms.", "source": {"uri": "bssnews.net", "dataType": "news", "body": "Bari (Italy) (AFP) - G7 leaders gather Thursday for the first day of an Italy summit, seeking to seal a deal on using frozen Russian assets to help war-torn Ukraine.\n\nUkrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky will join US President Joe Biden and leaders from Italy, Britain, France, Germany, Canada and Japan at the luxury Borgo Egnazia resort in Puglia.\n\nThe G7 leaders are hoping to agree on a $50 billion loan for Kyiv, secured against the future profits from interest on 300 billion euros ($325 billion) of Russian central bank assets frozen after the February 2022 invasion.\n\nThe European Union -- where most of the funds are being held -- agreed earlier this year to use the profits for Ukraine, worth up to three billion euros a year.\n\nBut the idea at the G7 is to use this to provide more, faster help in the form of a massive upfront loan -- although key questions such as who issues the debt and who shares the risk are still being hammered out.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron's office on Wednesday said a deal had been agreed on providing $50 billion for Ukraine before the end of the year, but said that technical details still needed to be finalised.\n\nBritain, meanwhile, said it would announce up to $310 million in new bilateral assistance to Kyiv at the summit, adding leaders would \"explore all lawful avenues by which immobilised Russian assets can be used to support Ukraine\".\n\nThe White House also said it expected to announce at the summit \"new steps to unlock the value\" of the Russian assets.\n\nBut US National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan was on Wednesday more guarded about what this may entail, saying only that the G7 was working towards announcing \"a framework\", including a timeframe.\n\nZelensky is attending as part of a week of diplomatic efforts to rally support as his country's outmanned and outgunned forces struggle against Russia.\n\nIt will culminate in an international conference on Ukraine in Switzerland this weekend.\n\nMideast, China\n\nThe summit comes at a time of extraordinary global turmoil.\n\nAs well as the conflict in Ukraine -- now in its third year -- the Hamas-Israel conflict is raging and economic tensions are rising between China and Western countries.\n\nMany G7 countries are also in political flux. Everyone in Puglia is aware this could be Biden's last G7 summit if he loses to Donald Trump in November US elections.\n\nBritain's Rishi Sunak is tipped to be ousted in July 4 elections, while France's Macron and Germany's Olaf Scholz are both under pressure after gains by the far right in EU elections last weekend.\n\nThe G7 summit opens Thursday morning with a short session on Africa, development and climate change, before turning to the Middle East.\n\nThe leaders have already announced their support for a Gaza truce deal outlined by Biden, which would also see the release of hostages taken in Hamas's October 7 attack on Israel.\n\nJordan's King Abdullah II -- a strong supporter of the Palestinian cause whose country signed a peace treaty with Israel 30 years ago -- is among around a dozen non-G7 guests also attending who are not, however, participating in the working sessions.\n\nThey include Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, UAE president Sheikh Mohamed bin Zayed and India's Narendra Modi.\n\nBrazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva -- whose country holds the rotating G20 presidency this year -- as well as Argentina's Javier Milei and UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres also plan to attend.\n\nAll the guests are invited to a dinner Friday night at the Borgo Egnazia luxury hotel complex, built in the style of a traditional village.\n\nWith security extremely tight, the venue is far away from protesters and journalists, with the media centre located some 60 kilometres away in Bari.\n\nAnother key issue in Puglia, to be discussed Friday, will be concerns about China's so-called \"industrial overcapacity\", particularly in green energy and technology sectors such as solar panels and electric vehicles.\n\nThe US, EU and Japan have all
