{"uri": "8175616869", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "08:24:53", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T08:24:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T08:24:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/politics/2742233/", "title": "G7 summit opens with deal to use Russian assets for Ukraine as traditional EU powers recalibrate - ExBulletin", "body": "BARI, Italy (AP) -- A Group of Seven summit opens Thursday with agreement on a U.S. proposal to guarantee a $50 billion loan to Ukraine using frozen Russian assets as collateral, giving Kiev a strong show of support even as the European political spectrum shifts to the right.\n\nDiplomats confirmed that agreement had been reached on the deal even before the leaders landed in southern Italy for the three-day summit. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will attend and is expected to sign a separate bilateral security agreement with US President Joe Biden.\n\nBeyond the war in Ukraine, Pope Francis will become the first pope to address a G7 summit, adding a touch of celebrity and moral authority to the annual gathering being held this year in sunny Puglia in Italy. He will speak on Friday about the promises and perils of artificial intelligence, but is also expected to renew his call for a peaceful end to the wars in Ukraine and Gaza.\n\nThe G7 includes Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom and the United States. Host Italy invited several African leaders - Algerian President Abdelmadjid Tebboune, Kenyan President William Ruto and Tunisian President Kais Saied - to lobby Italy's African initiatives. Other guests include Brazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, newly elected Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.\n\nWith Biden, British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak and now French President Emmanuel Macron facing elections in the coming months, the pressure was on the G7 to do what it can while the status quo lasts. what.\n\nRussian assets frozen to support Ukraine The US proposal involves using profits from the Russian central bank's roughly $260 billion in frozen assets, most held in the European Union, to help Ukraine, and providing a $50 billion loan from the US government to Kiev, using windfall profits from funds tied up as collateral.\n\nA French official, speaking to reporters on Wednesday, said a political decision by leaders had been made but the technical and legal details of the mechanism to exploit the assets still needed to be worked out. The issue is complicated because if Russian assets are ever thawed - for example if the war ends - then the windfall profits can no longer be used to repay the loan, requiring a burden-sharing agreement with other countries. .\n\nOn the eve of the summit, Washington also sent strong signals of support to Ukraine, expanding sanctions against Russia to target Chinese companies that support its war machine.\n\nEurope's new political chessboard Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni enters the meeting fortified at home and abroad after her far-right party performed even stronger in the weekend's elections to the European Parliament than in the 2022 elections which made her Italy's first female Prime Minister. Known for its revolving-door governments, Italy now finds itself in the unusual position of being the most stable power in the EU.\n\nThe leaders of the EU's two other G7 members, Germany and France, are not faring as well, shaken by the strong showings of far-right parties in the vote. Macron called early elections and German Chancellor Olaf Scholz watched as the far-right Alternative for Germany defeated his Social Democrats.\n\nAs a result, Meloni will likely be able to steer the three-day meeting toward its main priority points while strengthening its role on the world stage, analysts say. In a signal sign of his far-right muscles: Meloni's office denied media reports that Italy was trying to water down language on abortion access in the final communiqu\u00e9.\n\n\"While recent results are unlikely to radically change the direction of the next G7 summit, this election victory provides Prime Minister Meloni with additional leverage to make it a 'quintessentially Mediterranean summit',\" said Nick O' Connell, Deputy Director of the Atlantic Council.\n\nThis includes promoting his migration agenda as Meloni seeks to leverage his agenda for a non-exploitative relationship with Africa to boost development while curbing illegal migration to Europe.\n\nItaly, which for decades has been at ground zero of Europe's migration debate, is promoting its Mattei plan as a way to create jobs and opportunities in Africa and discourage its young people from undertaking dangerous journeys across the Mediterranean Sea . The plan includes pilot projects in areas such as education, healthcare, water, sanitation, agriculture and energy infrastructure.\n\nThe Pope and artificial intelligence Pope Francis has called for an international treaty to ensure that AI is developed and used ethically, recognizing the promise it offers but highlighting the serious and existential threats it poses.\n\nHe will carry this campaign to the industrialized countries of the world while wars rage on several fronts. One of his biggest concerns is the use of AI in the arms sector, which is an ongoing concern of the Jesuit pope who has called even traditional weapons makers \"dealers of death.\"\n\nBut Francis also worries about what AI means for the poorest and weakest: technology that could determine the trustworthiness of a mortgage applicant, the right of a migrant to receive political asylum or the risk of recidivism of a person previously convicted of a crime.\n\nThe 87-year-old pope said he would also reiterate his calls for peace when holding half a dozen bilateral meetings on the sidelines of the summit.\n\nWhere is this happening? The G7 summit is taking place in a sprawling luxury resort that looks like a theater set, a fake town designed to look like one of Puglia's whitewashed medieval hamlets, but which actually only dates from 2010 .\n\nLocated next to a real archaeological park, Borgo Egnazia features narrow streets, villas, restaurants and a square with a clock tower. A favorite of celebrities, it will be closed to outsiders for the duration of the summit.\n\nNo such five-star accommodation awaits the more than 2,000 police and carabinieri deployed to provide security. Authorities sequestered the decommissioned cruise ship sheltering them in the port of Brindisi on Wednesday after the police union complained about unacceptable hygiene conditions on board.\n\nAs throughout the G7, a range of anti-globalization, anti-war and climate activists are organizing protests around the summit venue, but far from where the leaders are meeting. A group is organizing a \"dinner for the poor\" on Friday evening calling for \"peace, the rights of people and against the Big 7 who claim to decide the destiny of the world and our planet.\"", {"uri": "2024-06-387768120", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "01:29:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T01:29:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T01:14:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://arab.news/jtzep", "title": "Troubled G7 leaders focus on Ukraine war, China in Italian summit", "body": "Determined to claim the initiative, the G7 leaders look likely to announce they have agreed on plans to issue $50 billion of loans for Ukraine using interest from frozen Russian assets to back the multi-year debt package\n\nBARI, Italy: Group of Seven (G7) leaders start their annual summit on Thursday looking to double down on support for Ukraine in its war with Russia and offer a united face in confronting China's political and economic ambitions.\n\nWith the Middle East, migration and artificial intelligence (AI) also on a packed agenda, the June 13-15 summit in southern Italy would be taxing for leaders at the best of times, but most of them are also bowed down by their own domestic woes.\n\nUS President Joe Biden, facing a tough re-election bid in November, arrived in Italy the day after his son Hunter Biden was convicted of lying about his drug use to illegally buy a gun.\n\nBritish Prime Minister Rishi Sunak appears destined to lose power in a July 4 election, the leaders of France and Germany are reeling from political defeats, and opinion polls are bleak for the prime ministers of Canada and Japan.\n\nOnly the host, Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, is riding high after triumphing in Italy's European election last weekend, but achieving meaningful results in the luxury Borgo Egnazia hotel resort will be a tall order.\n\nDetermined to claim the initiative, the G7 leaders look likely to announce they have agreed on plans to issue $50 billion of loans for Ukraine using interest from frozen Russian assets to back the multi-year debt package.\n\nHowever officials acknowledge the plan is complex, meaning any deal will only be in principle, with legal experts still having to thrash out the details that will need the backing of European nations, particularly Belgium, which is not in the G7.\n\nFor a second year running, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky will attend the summit and is due to sign a new, long-term security accord with Biden.\n\n\"By signing this we'll also be sending Russia a signal of our resolve. If (Russian President) Vladimir Putin thinks he can outlast the coalition supporting Ukraine, he's wrong,\" White House national security adviser Jake Sullivan told reporters.\n\nCONFRONTING CHINA\n\nUnderscoring US determination to punish Moscow for its 2022 invasion of Ukraine, Washington on Wednesday dramatically broadened sanctions on Moscow, including by targeting China-based companies selling semiconductors to Moscow.\n\nBy announcing new restrictions on Chinese firms on the eve of the G7 meeting, Biden is no doubt hoping to persuade Western allies to show greater resolve in confronting Beijing over its support for Russia and its industrial over-capacity.\n\nThe European Commission told automakers on Wednesday it would impose extra duties of up to 38.1 percent on imported Chinese electric cars from July, less than a month after Washington quadrupled duties for Chinese EVs to 100 percent.\n\nWhile G7 leaders are expected to express concern over high Chinese production levels, which they say disrupt global supply chains and market stability, EU diplomats warn that Europe is anxious to avoid a full-blown trade war with Beijing.\n\nEager not to appear like an elitist fortress, the G7 has thrown open its doors to a large number of outsiders this year, including Pope Francis, who is expected to give a keynote speech on Friday on both the risks and potential of AI.\n\nAmong those who have also been invited to Puglia are the leaders of some of the biggest regional powers across the globe such as India, Brazil, Argentina, Turkiye, Algeria and Kenya.\n\nAlthough the summit is scheduled to run until Saturday, many G7 chiefs will leave on Friday night, including Biden, meaning the final day has been earmarked for bilateral meetings for those "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/g7-eyes-ukraine-funding-plan-at-italy-summit/article_24371e08-a2cf-5048-9ed0-256e3c4dea0a.html", "title": "G7 eyes Ukraine funding plan at Italy summit", "body": "Security at the summit is tight, with the venue far away from protesters and journalists\n\nG7 leaders gather Thursday for the first day of an Italy summit, seeking to seal a deal on using frozen Russian assets to help war-torn Ukraine.\n\nUkrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky will join US President Joe Biden and leaders from Italy, Britain, France, Germany, Canada and Japan at the luxury Borgo Egnazia resort in Puglia.\n\nThe G7 leaders are hoping to agree on a $50 billion loan for Kyiv, secured against the future profits from interest on 300 billion euros ($325 billion) of Russian central bank assets frozen after the February 2022 invasion.\n\nThe European Union -- where most of the funds are being held -- agreed earlier this year to use the profits for Ukraine, worth up to three billion euros a year.\n\nBut the idea at the G7 is to use this to provide more, faster help in the form of a massive upfront loan -- although key questions such as who issues the debt and who shares the risk are still being hammered out.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron's office on Wednesday said a deal had been agreed on providing $50 billion for Ukraine before the end of the year, but said that technical details still needed to be finalised.\n\nBritain, meanwhile, said it would announce up to $310 million in new bilateral assistance to Kyiv at the summit, adding leaders would \"explore all lawful avenues by which immobilised Russian assets can be used to support Ukraine\".\n\nThe White House also said it expected to announce at the summit \"new steps to unlock the value\" of the Russian assets.\n\nBut US National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan was on Wednesday more guarded about what this may entail, saying only that the G7 was working towards announcing \"a framework\", including a timeframe.\n\nZelensky is attending as part of a week of diplomatic efforts to rally support as his country's outmanned and outgunned forces struggle against Russia.\n\nIt will culminate in an international conference on Ukraine in Switzerland this weekend.\n\n- Mideast, China -\n\nThe summit comes at a time of extraordinary global turmoil.\n\nMore from this section Police: 2 men charged in Southampton park robbery Daughter of mom injured in moose collision applauds new fencing for part of Trans-Canada Highway Live Life Better: How to organize your backyard shed\n\nAs well as the conflict in Ukraine -- now in its third year -- the Hamas-Israel conflict is raging and economic tensions are rising between China and Western countries.\n\nMany G7 countries are also in political flux. Everyone in Puglia is aware this could be Biden's last G7 summit if he loses to Donald Trump in November US elections.\n\nBritain's Rishi Sunak is tipped to be ousted in July 4 elections, while France's Macron and Germany's Olaf Scholz are both under pressure after gains by the far right in EU elections last weekend.\n\nThe G7 summit opens Thursday morning with a short session on Africa, development and climate change, before turning to the Middle East.\n\nThe leaders have already announced their support for a Gaza truce deal outlined by Biden, which would also see the release of hostages taken in Hamas's October 7 attack on Israel.\n\nJordan's King Abdullah II -- a strong supporter of the Palestinian cause whose country signed a peace treaty with Israel 30 years ago -- is among around a dozen non-G7 guests also attending who are not, however, participating in the working sessions.\n\nThey include Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, UAE president Sheikh Mohamed bin Zayed and India's Narendra Modi.\n\nBrazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva -- whose country holds the rotating G20 presidency this year -- as well as Argentina's Javier Milei and UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres also plan to attend.\n\nAll the guests are invited to a dinner Friday night at the Borgo Egnazia luxury hotel complex, built in the style of a traditional village.\n\nWith security extremely tight, the venue is far away from protesters and journalists, with the media centre located some 60 kilometres away in Bari.\n\nAnother key issue in Puglia, to be discussed Friday, will be concerns about China's so-called \"industrial overcapacity\", particularly in green energy and technology sectors such as solar panels and electric vehicles.\n\nThe US, EU and Japan have all voiced concern that generous subsidies from Beijing are resulting in a flood of cheap goods hitting the global market, threatening Western firms.\n\nbur-ar/ide/yad/smw", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8175916054", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "11:26:43", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T11:26:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T11:25:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.newschannel5.com/world/europe/g7-summit-opens-with-deal-to-use-russian-assets-for-ukraine-as-eus-traditional-powers-recalibrate", "title": "G7 summit opens with deal to use Russian assets for Ukraine as EU's traditional powers recalibrate", "body": "The agreement for Ukraine gives Kyiv a strong show of support even as Europe's political chessboard shifts to the right. (Scripps News)\n\nA Group of Seven summit is opening Thursday with agreement on a U.S. proposal to back a $50 billion loan to Ukraine using frozen Russian assets as collateral, giving Kyiv a strong show of support even as Europe's political chessboard shifts to the right.\n\nDiplomats confirmed that an agreement had been reached on the deal before the leaders even landed in southern Italy for the three-day summit. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy is on hand and is expected to sign a separate bilateral security agreement with U.S. President Joe Biden.\n\nBeyond the the war in Ukraine, Pope Francis will become the first pope to address a G7 summit, adding a dash of celebrity and moral authority to the annual gathering that is being held this year in Italy's sun-drenched Puglia region. He'll be speaking Friday about the promises and perils of artificial intelligence, but is expected to also renew his appeal for a peaceful end to Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine and the Israel-Hamas war in Gaza.\n\nThe G7 includes Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom and the United States. Italy, which is hosting the summit, has invited several African leaders -- Algerian President Abdelmadjid Tebboune, Kenyan President William Ruto and Tunisian President Kais Saied -- to press Italy's development and migration initiatives on the continent.\n\nOther guests include Brazilian President Luiz In\u00e1cio Lula da Silva, Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, fresh off his own election, and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.\n\nWith Biden, U.K. Prime Minister Rishi Sunak and now French President Emmanuel Macron facing elections in the coming months, pressure was on the G7 to get done what it can while the status quo lasts.\n\nFrozen Russian assets to support Ukraine\n\nThe U.S. proposal involves engineering a $50 billion loan to help Ukraine in its fight against Russia that would use interest earned on profits from Russia's frozen central bank assets, most of them held in the European Union, as collateral.\n\nA French official, briefing reporters Wednesday, said a political decision by the leaders had been reached but that technical and legal details of the mechanism to tap into the assets still had to be worked out. The issue is complicated because if the Russian assets one day are unfrozen -- say if the war ends -- then the windfall profits will no longer be able to be used to pay off the loan, requiring a burden-sharing arrangement with other countries.\n\nIn addition to the deal, Sunak announced up to $310 million in nonmilitary aid to Ukraine for humanitarian, energy and stabilization needs. Washington also sent strong signals of support, with widened sanctions against Russia to target Chinese companies that are helping its war machine.\n\nEurope's new political chessboard\n\nItalian Premier Giorgia Meloni goes into the meeting fortified at home and abroad after her far-right party had an even stronger showing in the European Parliament election than the national general election in 2022 that made her Italy's first female premier. Known for its revolving-door governments, Italy is now in the unusual position of being the most stable power in the EU.\n\nThe leaders of the G7's two other EU members, Germany and France, didn't fare nearly as well, rattled after hard-right parties made strong showings in the vote. Macron called a snap election and German Chancellor Olaf Scholz saw his Social Democrats finish behind mainstream conservatives and the far-right Alternative for Germany.\n\nAs a result, Meloni is likely to be able to steer the three-day meeting to her key priority items as she further cements her role on the world stage, analysts said. One sign of her flexed far-right muscles: Meloni's office denied media reports that Italy was trying to water down language about access to abortion in the final communique.\n\nA French official, speaking anonymously in line with Macron's office customary practices, said there were diverging views with Italian negotiators on some topics, including on sexual and reproductive health and vaccines.\n\nItalian Foreign Minister Antonio Tajani confirmed abortion was being discussed, but said discussions were continuing.\n\n\"While it's unlikely the recent results will radically shift the focus of the upcoming G7 Summit, this electoral win offers Premier Meloni additional leverage to frame this as an essentially 'Mediterranean Summit,\" said Nick O'Connell, deputy director of the Atlantic Council.\n\nThat includes pushing her migration agenda as Meloni seeks to leverage her program for a nonexploitative relationship with Africa to boost development while curbing illegal migration to Europe.\n\nThe pope and artificial intelligence\n\nPope Francis has called for an international treaty to ensure AI is developed and used ethically, acknowledging the promise it offers but emphasizing the grave and existential threats it poses.\n\nHe'll bring that campaign to the world's industrialized countries as wars are raging across multiple fronts. One of his greatest concerns has been on the use of AI in the armaments sector, which has been a frequent focus of the Jesuit pope who has called even traditional weapons makers \"merchants of death.\"\n\nBut Francis is also concerned about what AI means for the poorest and weakest: technology that could determine the reliability of an applicant for a mortgage, the right of a migrant to receive political asylum or the chance of reoffending by someone previously convicted of a crime.\n\nIt's happening where?\n\nThe G7 summit is taking place in a sprawling luxury resort that's something of a theater set, a faux town made to resemble one of Puglia's medieval white-washed hamlets but that actually only dates from 2010.\n\nLocated next to an actual archaeological park, Borgo Egnazia features narrow streets, villas, restaurants and a town square complete with a clocktower. A favorite of celebrities, it will be sealed off to outsiders for the duration of the summit.\n\nNo such five-star accommodations await the 2,000-plus police and Carabinieri forces who have been brought in to provide security. Authorities on Wednesday sequestered the decommissioned cruise ship that had been housing them in Brindisi's port, after the police union complained about unacceptable hygienic conditions on board.\n\nAs with any G7, an assortment of anti-global, anti-war and climate activists are staging protests around the summit venue, but far from where the leaders are meeting. One group is staging a \"dinner for the poor\" on Friday night calling for \"peace, the rights of peoples and against the Big 7 who claim to decide the destiny of the world and our planet.\"", Russian assets for Ukraine | BreakingNews.ie", "body": "The G7 summit in Italy was opening on Thursday with an agreement on a US proposal to back a 50 billion dollar (\u00a339 billion) loan to Ukraine using frozen Russian assets as collateral, giving Kyiv a strong show of support even as Europe's political chessboard shifts to the right.\n\nDiplomats confirmed an agreement had been reached on the deal before the leaders even landed for the three-day gathering.\n\nUkrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky is expected to sign a separate bilateral security agreement with US President Joe Biden.\n\nBeyond the the war in Ukraine, Pope Francis will become the first pontiff to address a G7 summit, adding a dash of celebrity and moral authority to the annual gathering that is being held this year in Borgo Egnazia in southern Italy's sun-drenched Puglia region.\n\nHe will be speaking on Friday about the promises and perils of artificial intelligence, but is expected to also renew his appeal for a peaceful end to Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine and the Israel-Hamas war in Gaza.\n\nThe G7 comprises Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom and the United States.\n\nItaly, which is hosting the summit, has invited several African leaders - Algerian President Abdelmadjid Tebboune, Kenyan President William Ruto and Tunisian President Kais Saied - to press Italy's development and migration initiatives on the continent.\n\nOther guests include Brazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, fresh off his own election, and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.\n\nWith Mr Biden, UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak and now French President Emmanuel Macron facing elections in the coming months, pressure is on the G7 to get done what it can while the status quo lasts.\n\nThe US proposal involves engineering a 50 billion dollar (\u00a339 billion) loan to help Ukraine in its fight against Russia which would use interest earned on profits from Russia's frozen central bank assets, most of them held in the European Union, as collateral.\n\nA French official, briefing reporters on Wednesday, said a political decision by the leaders has been reached but that technical and legal details of the mechanism to tap into the assets still have to be worked out.\n\nThe issue is complicated because if the Russian assets are eventually unfrozen - for example, if the war ends - then the windfall profits will no longer be able to be used to pay off the loan, requiring a burden-sharing arrangement with other countries.\n\nIn addition to the deal, Mr Sunak announced up to \u00a3242 million (310 million dollars) in non-military aid to Ukraine for humanitarian, energy and stabilization needs.\n\nWashington also sent strong signals of support, with widened sanctions against Russia to target Chinese companies that are helping its war machine.\n\nItalian Premier Giorgia Meloni goes into the meeting fortified at home and abroad after her far-right party had an even stronger showing in the European Parliament election than the national general election in 2022 that made her Italy's first female premier.\n\nKnown for its revolving-door governments, Italy is now in the unusual position of being the most stable power in the EU.\n\nThe leaders of the G7's two other EU members, Germany and France, did not fare nearly as well, rattled after hard-right parties made strong showings in the vote.\n\nMr Macron called a snap election and German Chancellor Olaf Scholz saw his Social Democrats finish behind mainstream conservatives and the far-right Alternative for Germany.\n\nAs a result, Ms Meloni is likely to be able to steer the three-day meeting to her key priority items as she further cements her role on the world stage, analysts said.\n\nIn one sign of her flexed far-right muscles, Ms Meloni's office denied media reports that Italy is trying to water down language about access to abortion in the final communique.\n\nA French official said there are diverging views with Italian negotiators on some topics, including on sexual and reproductive health and vaccines.\n\nItalian Foreign Minister Antonio Tajani confirmed abortion is being discussed, but said talks are continuing.\n\nNick O'Connell, deputy director of the Atlantic Council, said: \"While it's unlikely the recent results will radically shift the focus of the upcoming G7 summit, this electoral win offers Premier Meloni additional leverage to frame this as an essentially 'Mediterranean Summit.\"\n\nThat includes pushing her migration {"uri": "8175305990", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "04:30:09", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T04:30:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T04:21:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13524787/G7-summit-opens-deal-use-Russian-assets-Ukraine-EUs-traditional-powers-recalibrate.html", "title": "G7 summit opens with deal to use Russian assets for Ukraine as EU's...", "body": "BARI, Italy (AP) - A Group of Seven summit is opening Thursday with agreement on a U.S. proposal to back a $50 billion loan to Ukraine using frozen Russian assets as collateral, giving Kyiv a strong show of support even as Europe's political chessboard shifts to the right.\n\nDiplomats confirmed that an agreement had been reached on the deal before the leaders even landed in southern Italy for the three-day summit. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will be on hand and is expected to sign a separate bilateral security agreement with U.S. President Joe Biden.\n\nBeyond the Ukraine war, Pope Francis will become the first pope to address a G7 summit, adding a dash of celebrity and moral authority to the annual gathering that is being held this year in Italy's sun-drenched Puglia region. He\u00b4ll be speaking Friday about the promises and perils of artificial intelligence, but is expected to also renew his appeal for a peaceful end to wars in Ukraine and Gaza.\n\nThe G7 includes Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom and the United States. Host Italy has invited several African leaders - Algerian President Abdelmadjid Tebboune, Kenyan President William Ruto and Tunisian President Kais Saied - to press Italy's Africa initiatives. Other guests include Brazilian President Luiz In\u00e1cio Lula da Silva, Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, fresh off his own election, and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.\n\nWith Biden, British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak and now French President Emmanuel Macron facing elections in the coming months, pressure was on the G7 to get done what it can while the status quo lasts.\n\nThe U.S. proposal involves using profits from the roughly $260 billion in frozen Russian central bank assets, most of them held in the European Union, to help Ukraine, and issuing a $50 billion loan from the U.S. government to Kyiv, using windfall profits from the immobilized funds as collateral.\n\nItalian Carabinieri, paramilitary policemen, patrol at a roadblock near Borgo Egnazia, venue of the G7 summit in southern Italy, Wednesday, June 12, 2024. A Group of Seven summit aiming to consolidate support for Ukraine opens Thursday under a vastly different political landscape than even a few days ago, after European Parliament elections jolted the leaders of France and Germany and emboldened Italian Premier Giorgia Meloni. (AP Photo/Gregorio Borgia)\n\nA French official, briefing reporters Wednesday, said a political decision by the leaders had been reached but that technical and legal details of the mechanism to tap into the assets still had to be worked out. The issue is complicated because if the Russian assets one day are unfrozen - say if the war ends - then the windfall profits will no longer be able to be used to pay off the loan, requiring a burden-sharing arrangement with other countries.\n\nOn the eve of the summit, Washington also sent strong signals of support for Ukraine, with widened sanctions against Russia to target Chinese companies that are helping its war machine.\n\nItalian Premier Giorgia Meloni goes into the meeting fortified at home and abroad after her far-right party had an even stronger showing in weekend European Parliament elections than the 2022 elections that made her Italy\u00b4s first female premier. Known for its revolving-door governments, Italy is now in the unusual position of being the most stable power in the EU.\n\nThe leaders of the G7\u00b4s two other EU members, Germany and France, didn't fare nearly as well, rattled after hard-right parties made strong showings in the vote. Macron called a snap election and German Chancellor Olaf Scholz saw the far-right Alternative for Germany beat out his Social Democrats.\n\nAs a result, Meloni is likely to be able to steer the three-day meeting to her key priority items as she further cements her role on the world stage, analysts said. One reported sign of her flexed far-right muscles: Meloni's office denied media reports that Italy was trying to water down language about access to abortion in the final communique.\n\n\"While it\u00b4s unlikely the recent results will radically shift the focus of the upcoming G7 Summit, this electoral win offers Premier Meloni additional leverage to frame this as an essentially 'Mediterranean Summit,\" said Nick O\u00b4Connell, deputy director of the Atlantic Council.\n\nThat includes pushing her migration agenda as Meloni seeks to leverage her program for a non-exploitative relationship with Africa to boost development while curbing illegal migration to Europe.\n\nItaly, which for decades has been ground zero in Europe\u00b4s migration debate, has been promoting its Mattei Plan as a way to create jobs and opportunity in Africa and discourage its young people from making dangerous trips across the Mediterranean Sea. The plan involves pilot projects in areas such as education, health care, water, sanitation, agriculture and energy infrastructure.\n\nPope Francis has called for an international treaty to ensure AI is developed and used ethically, acknowledging the promise it offers but emphasizing the grave and existential threats it poses.\n\nHe'll bring that campaign to the world's industrialized countries as wars are raging across multiple fronts. One of his greatest concerns has been on the use of AI in the armaments sector, which has been a frequent focus of the Jesuit pope who has called even traditional weapons makers \"merchants of death.\"\n\nBut Francis is also concerned about what AI means for the poorest and weakest: technology that could determine the reliability of an applicant for a mortgage, the right of a migrant to receive political asylum or the chance of reoffending by someone previously convicted of a crime.\n\nThe 87-year-old pope has said he would also repeat his calls for peace while holding a half-dozen bilateral meetings on the sidelines of the summit.\n\nThe G7 summit is taking place in a sprawling luxury resort that\u00b4s something of a theater set, a faux town made to resemble one of Puglia\u00b4s medieval white-washed hamlets but that actually only dates from 2010.\n\nLocated next to an actual archaeological park, Borgo Egnazia features narrow streets, villas, restaurants and a town square complete with a clocktower. A favorite of celebrities, it will be sealed off to outsiders for the duration of the summit.\n\nNo such five-star accommodations await the 2,000-plus police and carabinieri forces who have been brought in to provide security. Authorities on Wednesday sequestered the decommissioned cruise ship that had been housing them in Brindisi\u00b4s port, after the police union complained about unacceptable hygienic conditions on board.\n\nAs with any G7, an assortment of anti-global, anti-war and climate activists are staging protests around the summit venue, but far from where the leaders are meeting. One group is staging a \"dinner for the poor\" on Friday night calling for \"peace, the rights of peoples and against the Big 7 who claim to decide the destiny of the world and our planet.\"\n\nAssociated Press journalists Angela Charlton and Sylvie Corbet in Paris contributed to this report.\n\nWorkers give the last touch to the illumination set for the Patron Saint feast in Fasano, near Borgo Egnazia, southern Italy, Wednesday, June 12, 2024. A Group of Seven summit aiming to consolidate support for Ukraine opens Thursday under a vastly different political landscape than even a few days ago, after European Parliament elections jolted the leaders of France and Germany and emboldened Italian Premier Giorgia Meloni. (AP Photo/Gregorio Borgia)\n\nItalian Army soldier patrols at a roadblock near Borgo Egnatia, venue of the G7 summit in southern Italy, Wednesday, June 12, 2024. (AP Photo/Gregorio Borgia)\n\nItalian Carabinieri, paramilitary policemen, patrol at a roadblock near Borgo Egnatia, venue of the G7 summit in southern Italy, Wednesday, June 12, 2024. A Group of Seven summit aiming to consolidate support for Ukraine opens Thursday under a vastly different political landscape than even a few days ago, after European Parliament elections jolted the leaders of France and Germany and emboldened Italian Premier Giorgia Meloni. {"uri": "8175677407", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "09:07:22", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T09:07:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T09:02:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13525537/G7-summit-opens-deal-use-frozen-Russian-assets-Ukraine.html", "title": "G7 summit opens with deal to use frozen Russian assets for Ukraine", "body": "The G7 summit in Italy was opening on Thursday with an agreement on a US proposal to back a 50 billion dollar (\u00a339 billion) loan to Ukraine using frozen Russian assets as collateral, giving Kyiv a strong show of support even as Europe's political chessboard shifts to the right.\n\nDiplomats confirmed an agreement had been reached on the deal before the leaders even landed for the three-day gathering.\n\nUkrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky is expected to sign a separate bilateral security agreement with US President Joe Biden.\n\nBeyond the the war in Ukraine, Pope Francis will become the first pontiff to address a G7 summit, adding a dash of celebrity and moral authority to the annual gathering that is being held this year in Borgo Egnazia in southern Italy's sun-drenched Puglia region.\n\nHe will be speaking on Friday about the promises and perils of artificial intelligence, but is expected to also renew his appeal for a peaceful end to Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine and the Israel-Hamas war in Gaza.\n\nPope Francis will address the G7 summit on Friday (Alessandra Tarantino/AP)\n\nThe G7 comprises Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom and the United States.\n\nItaly, which is hosting the summit, has invited several African leaders - Algerian President Abdelmadjid Tebboune, Kenyan President William Ruto and Tunisian President Kais Saied - to press Italy's development and migration initiatives on the continent.\n\nOther guests include Brazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, fresh off his own election, and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.\n\nWith Mr Biden, UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak and now French President Emmanuel Macron facing elections in the coming months, pressure is on the G7 to get done what it can while the status quo lasts.\n\nThe US proposal involves engineering a 50 billion dollar (\u00a339 billion) loan to help Ukraine in its fight against Russia which would use interest earned on profits from Russia's frozen central bank assets, most of them held in the European Union, as collateral.\n\nThe summit is being held at the luxury Borgo Egnazia complex in Italy\u00b4s Puglia region (Luca Bruno/AP)\n\nA French official, briefing reporters on Wednesday, said a political decision by the leaders has been reached but that technical and legal details of the mechanism to tap into the assets still have to be worked out.\n\nThe issue is complicated because if the Russian assets are eventually unfrozen - for example, if the war ends - then the windfall profits will no longer be able to be used to pay off the loan, requiring a burden-sharing arrangement with other countries.\n\nIn addition to the deal, Mr Sunak announced up to \u00a3242 million (310 million dollars) in non-military aid to Ukraine for humanitarian, energy and stabilization needs.\n\nWashington also sent strong signals of support, with widened sanctions against Russia to target Chinese companies that are helping its war machine.\n\nItalian Premier Giorgia Meloni goes into the meeting fortified at home and abroad after her far-right party had an even stronger showing in the European Parliament election than the national general election in 2022 that made her Italy's first female premier.\n\nKnown for its revolving-door governments, Italy is now in the unusual position of being the most stable power in the EU.\n\nItalian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni\u00b4s far-right party had a strong showing in the European Parliament election (Luca Bruno/AP)\n\nThe leaders of the G7's two other EU members, Germany and France, did not fare nearly as well, rattled after hard-right parties made strong showings in the vote.\n\nMr Macron called a snap election and German Chancellor Olaf Scholz saw his Social Democrats finish behind mainstream conservatives and the far-right Alternative for Germany.\n\nAs a result, Ms Meloni is likely to be able to steer the three-day meeting to her key priority items as she further cements her role on the world stage, analysts said.\n\nIn one sign of her flexed far-right muscles, Ms Meloni's office denied media reports that Italy is trying to water down language about access to abortion in the final communique.\n\nA French official said there are diverging views with Italian negotiators on some topics, including on sexual and reproductive health and vaccines.\n\nItalian Foreign Minister Antonio Tajani confirmed abortion is being discussed, but said Assets At G7 - UrduPoint", "body": "The White House said Tuesday that steps to use frozen Russian assets will be announced during this week's G7 summit in Italy, as well as new sanctions and export controls over Moscow's invasion of Ukraine\n\nWashington, (APP - UrduPoint / Pakistan Point News - 12th Jun, 2024) The White House said Tuesday that steps to use frozen Russian assets will be announced during this week's G7 summit in Italy, as well as new sanctions and export controls over Moscow's invasion of Ukraine.\n\n\"We will announce new steps to unlock the value of the immobilized Russian sovereign assets to benefit Ukraine,\" National Security Council spokesman John Kirby told journalists.\n\nG7 leaders hope to agree a deal on using the profits from the interest on 300 billion euros ($325 billion) of frozen Russian central bank assets to help Kyiv.\n\nThe idea is to use the profits as collateral for a loan of up to $50 billion, but there is still debate over who would issue the debt as well as a raft of technical issues -- including what would happen if the assets were unfrozen in the event of peace.\n\nKirby also said that \"an impactful set of new sanctions and export control actions\" will be announced, without providing specifics.\n\nThe G7 summit comes against the backdrop of global and political turmoil, and boosting support for Ukraine is at the top of the agenda.\n\nUkrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky will attend a discussion Thursday on Russia's war on his country, now into its third year, where he will again press for more help from Western {"uri": "8175437939", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "06:20:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T06:20:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T06:19:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/politics/2742118/", "title": "G7 summit opens with deal to use Russian assets for Ukraine as traditional EU powers recalibrate - ExBulletin", "body": "BARI A Group of Seven summit opens Thursday with agreement on a US proposal to support a $50 billion loan to Ukraine using frozen Russian assets as collateral, giving Kiev a strong show of support even as the European political spectrum shifts to the right.\n\nDiplomats confirmed that agreement had been reached on the deal even before the leaders landed in southern Italy for the three-day summit. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will attend and is expected to sign a separate bilateral security agreement with US President Joe Biden.\n\nBeyond the war in Ukraine, Pope Francis will become the first pope to address a G7 summit, adding a touch of celebrity and moral authority to the annual gathering being held this year in Italy's sunny Puglia region. I will speak on Friday promises and perils of artificial intelligencebut he should also renew his call for a peaceful end to the wars in Ukraine and Gaza.\n\nThe G7 includes Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom and the United States. Host Italy invited several Algerian African leaders President Abdelmadjid Tebboune, Kenyan President William Ruto and Tunisian President Kais Saied to promote Italian initiatives in favor of Africa. Other guests include Brazilian President Luiz Incio Lula da Silvathe newly elected Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.\n\nWith Biden, British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak and now French President Emmanuel Macron facing elections in the coming months, the pressure was on the G7 to do what it can while the status quo lasts. what.\n\nRussian assets frozen to support Ukraine\n\nThe American proposal involves using the profits from the approx. 260 billion dollars in frozen assets of the Russian central bank, most of them are held in the European Union, to help Ukraine, and the provision of a $50 billion loan from the US government to kyiv, using windfall profits from the immobilized funds as collateral.\n\nA French official, speaking to reporters Wednesday, said a political decision had been made by leaders, but that technical and legal details The mechanism for exploiting these assets remains to be developed. The issue is complicated because if Russian assets are ever thawed, for example if the war ends, the windfall profits can no longer be used to repay the loan, requiring a burden-sharing agreement with other countries.\n\nOn the eve of the summit, Washington also sent strong signals of support to Ukraine, with expanded sanctions against Russia to target Chinese companies that help its war machine.\n\nEurope's new political spectrum\n\nItalian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni enters the meeting fortified at home and abroad after her far-right party performed even stronger in the weekend's European Parliament elections than in the 2022 elections which made her the first female Italian Prime Minister. Known for its revolving-door governments, Italy now finds itself in the unusual position of being the most stable power in the EU.\n\nThe leaders of the other two EU members, Germany and France, are not faring as well, shaken by the strong showings of far-right parties in the vote. Macron called early elections and German Chancellor Olaf Scholz saw the far-right Alternative for Germany defeat its social democrats.\n\nAs a result, Meloni will likely be able to steer the three-day meeting toward its main priority points while strengthening its role on the world stage, analysts say. In a signal sign of his far-right muscles: Meloni's office denied media reports that Italy was trying to water down language on abortion access in the final communiqu\u00e9.\n\nAlthough the recent results are unlikely to radically change the direction of the next G7 summit, this election victory gives Prime Minister Meloni additional leverage to make it a predominantly Mediterranean summit, said Nick O'Connell, deputy director of the Atlantic Council.\n\nThis includes promoting his migration agenda as Meloni seeks to leverage his agenda for a non-exploitative relationship with Africa to boost development while curbing illegal migration to Europe.\n\nItaly, which has been at ground zero in the European debate on migration for decades, is promoting its Mat\u00e9i map as a way to create jobs and opportunities in Africa and discourage its young people from making dangerous journeys across the Mediterranean Sea. The plan includes pilot projects in areas such as education, healthcare, water, sanitation, agriculture and energy infrastructure.\n\nThe Pope and artificial intelligence\n\nPope Francis has called for a international treaty to ensure AI is developed and used ethicallyrecognizing the promise it offers but emphasizing the serious and existential threats it poses.\n\nHe will carry this campaign to the industrialized countries of the world while wars rage on several fronts. One of his biggest concerns is the use of AI in the arms sector, which has been a frequent concern of the Jesuit Pope who has called even manufacturers of traditional weapons merchants of death.\n\nBut Francis also worries about what AI means for the poorest and weakest: technology that could determine the trustworthiness of a mortgage applicant, the right of a migrant to receive political asylum or the risk of recidivism of a person previously convicted of a crime.\n\nThe 87-year-old pope said he would also reiterate his calls for peace when holding half a dozen bilateral meetings on the sidelines of the summit.\n\nWhere is it happening ?\n\nThe G7 summit is taking place in a sprawling luxury resort that resembles a theater set, a fake town designed to look like one of Puglia's whitewashed medieval hamlets, but which actually only dates from 2010.\n\nLocated next to a real archaeological park, Borgo Egnazia features narrow streets, villas, restaurants and a square with a clock tower. A favorite of celebrities, it will be closed to outsiders for the duration of the summit.\n\nNo such five-star accommodation awaits the more than 2,000 police and carabinieri deployed to provide security. Authorities sequestered the decommissioned cruise ship sheltering them in the port of Brindisis on Wednesday after the police union complained about unacceptable hygiene conditions on board.\n\nAs throughout the G7, a range of anti-globalization, anti-war and climate activists are organizing protests around the summit venue, but far from where the leaders are meeting. A group is organizing a dinner for the poor on Friday evening calling for peace, people's rights and against the Big 7 who claim to decide the destiny of the world and our planet.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press journalists Angela Charlton and Sylvie Corbet in Paris contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "exbulletin.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ExBulletin"}, "authors": [], "concepts": and Zelensky to sign security agreement between US and Ukraine at summit", "body": "The aim is to send a signal to Russia of American resolve over support for Kyiv, the White House said as Mr Biden headed to Italy.\n\nNational security adviser Jake Sullivan told reporters that the agreement would not commit US troops directly to Ukraine's defence against Russia's invasion - a red line drawn by Mr Biden, who is fearful of being drawn into direct conflict between the nuclear-armed powers.\n\n\"We want to demonstrate that the US supports the people of Ukraine, that we stand with them and that we'll continue to help address their security needs,\" Mr Sullivan said, adding \"this agreement will show our resolve\".\n\nMr Sullivan called the agreement a \"bridge\" to when Ukraine is invited to join the Nato alliance - a long-term priority of Mr Zelensky's that the allies have said will first require an end to the Russia-Ukraine war.\n\nMr Biden heads to the summit of the world's leading democracies with an urgency to get big things done, including turning frozen Russian assets into billions of dollars to help Ukraine as it fights off Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine.\n\nThis year's G7 summit comes three years after Mr Biden declared at his first such gathering that America was back as a global leader following the disruptions to western alliances that occurred when Donald Trump was president.\n\nNow, there is a chance this gathering could be the final G7 for Mr Biden and other G7 leaders, depending on the results of elections this year.\n\nMr Biden and his counterparts from Canada, the UK, France, Germany, Italy and Japan will use the summit to discuss challenges related to the spread of artificial intelligence, migration, the Russian military's resurgence and China's economic might, among other topics.\n\nPope Francis, Mr Zelensky and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan are joining the gathering at the Borgo Egnazia resort in the Puglia region of southern Italy.\n\nThe summit, which opens on Thursday, will play out after far-right parties across the continent secured gains of surprising scale in just-concluded European Union elections.\n\nThose victories, coupled with upcoming elections in the UK, France and the US, have rattled the global political establishment and added weightiness to this year's summit.\n\n\"You hear this a lot when you talk to US and European officials: If we can't get this done now, whether it's on China, whether it's on the assets, we may not have another chance,\" said Josh Lipsky, senior The White House has said it will announce measures to use frozen Russian assets, as well as new sanctions and export controls as a result of Moscow's invasion of Ukraine.\n\nG7 leaders hope to agree on the use of interest proceeds on the 300 billion euros worth of frozen Russian central bank assets to help Kyiv. The G7 would provide Ukraine with a loan of around 50 billion US dollars (46 billion euros) from the profits from the Russian assets G7 summit worldwide. However, there are many remaining unclear technical issues.\n\nThe ultimate objective must be to fully confiscate all Russian assets and transfer them to Ukraine, ensuring that this process adheres to international law, the committee chairs say.\n\n\"At least \u20ac3 billion a month in outside financial assistance is required just to prevent a collapse of Ukraine's economy. Against numbers like these, confiscating \u20ac3 billion in annual windfall profits on Russia's frozen assets simply is not a sufficient response to the challenge Russia has issued to Ukraine and its friends in the democratic world,\" their letter reads.\n\nThe G7 Summit will take place at a politically turbulent time when increased support for Ukraine is high on the agenda.\n\nOn Thursday, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky will take part in a G7 discussion on Russia's war against his country and will once again ask for more help from Western countries.\n\nThe letter also states that full confiscation's market impact has already been assessed, adding that \"seizure in response to aggression would be too rare an occurrence to have major currency impacts\".\n\n\"The leaders of some of the major NATO countries are still unable to reach a final decision on Ukraine's NATO membership, despite the support of the parliaments of the NATO countries whose representatives on the parliamentary foreign affairs committees have today addressed the leaders of the G7, demanding that all the aggressor's frozen assets be used for Ukraine's reconstruction and defense,\" Pavilionis {"uri": "2024-06-387981057", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "06:57:17", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T06:57:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T06:57:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/2/11/525450/World/War-in-Ukraine/G-eyes-Ukraine-funding-plan-at-Italy-summit.aspx", "title": "G7 eyes Ukraine funding plan at Italy summit - War in Ukraine - World", "body": "US President Joe Biden arrives on Air Force One at Brindisi International Airport, June, 2024, in Brindisi, Italy. AP\n\nUkrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky will join US President Joe Biden and leaders from Italy, Britain, France, Germany, Canada and Japan at the luxury Borgo Egnazia resort in Puglia.\n\nThe G7 leaders are hoping to agree on a $50 billion loan for Kyiv, secured against the future profits from interest on 300 billion euros ($325 billion) of Russian central bank assets frozen after the February 2022 invasion.\n\nThe European Union -- where most of the funds are being held -- agreed earlier this year to use the profits for Ukraine, worth up to three billion euros a year.\n\nBut the idea at the G7 is to use this to provide more, faster help in the form of a massive upfront loan -- although key questions such as who issues the debt and who shares the risk are still being hammered out.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron's office on Wednesday said a deal had been agreed on providing $50 billion for Ukraine before the end of the year, but said that technical details still needed to be finalised.\n\nBritain, meanwhile, said it would announce up to $310 million in new bilateral assistance to Kyiv at the summit, adding leaders would \"explore all lawful avenues by which immobilised Russian assets can be used to support Ukraine\".\n\nThe White House also said it expected to announce at the summit \"new steps to unlock the value\" of the Russian assets.\n\nBut US National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan was on Wednesday more guarded about what this may entail, saying only that the G7 was working towards announcing \"a framework\", including a timeframe.\n\nZelensky is attending as part of a week of diplomatic efforts to rally support as his country's outmanned and outgunned forces struggle against Russia.\n\nIt will culminate in an international conference on Ukraine in Switzerland this weekend.\n\nThe summit comes at a time of extraordinary global turmoil.\n\nAs well as the conflict in Ukraine -- now in its third year -- the Hamas-Israel conflict is raging and economic tensions are rising between China and Western countries.\n\nMany G7 countries are also in political flux. Everyone in Puglia is aware this could be Biden's last G7 summit if he loses to Donald Trump in November US elections.\n\nBritain's Rishi Sunak is tipped to be ousted in July 4 elections, while France's Macron and Germany's Olaf Scholz are both under pressure after gains by the far right in EU elections last weekend.\n\nThe G7 summit opens Thursday morning with a short session on Africa, development and climate change, before turning to the Middle East.\n\nThe leaders have already announced their support for a Gaza truce deal outlined by Biden.\n\nJordan's King Abdullah II is among around a dozen non-G7 guests also attending who are not, however, participating in the working sessions.\n\nThey include Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, UAE president Sheikh Mohamed bin Zayed and India's Narendra Modi.\n\nBrazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva -- whose country holds the rotating G20 presidency this year -- as well as Argentina's Javier Milei and UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres also plan to attend.\n\nAll the guests are invited to a dinner Friday night at the Borgo Egnazia luxury hotel complex, built in the style of a traditional village.\n\nWith security extremely tight, the venue is far away from protesters and journalists, with the media centre located some 60 kilometres away in Bari.\n\nAnother key issue in Puglia, to be discussed Friday, will be concerns about China's so-called \"industrial overcapacity\", particularly in green energy and technology sectors such as solar panels and electric vehicles.\n\nThe US, EU and Japan have all voiced concern that generous subsidies from Beijing are resulting in a flood of cheap goods hitting the global market, threatening Western firms.", "source": {"uri": "english.ahram.org.eg", "dataType": "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9644722", "eventUri": "eng-9644722", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-07-04", "textStart": 2356, "textEnd": {"uri": "2024-06-387897242", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "05:14:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T05:14:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T04:05:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://keyt.com/news/2024/06/12/g7-summit-opens-with-deal-to-use-russian-assets-for-ukraine-as-eus-traditional-powers-recalibrate/", "title": "G7 summit opens with deal to use Russian assets for Ukraine as EU's traditional powers recalibrate", "body": "BARI, Italy (AP) -- A Group of Seven summit is opening Thursday with agreement on a U.S. proposal to back a $50 billion loan to Ukraine using frozen Russian assets as collateral, giving Kyiv a strong show of support even as Europe's political chessboard shifts to the right.\n\nDiplomats confirmed that an agreement had been reached on the deal before the leaders even landed in southern Italy for the three-day summit. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will be on hand and is expected to sign a separate bilateral security agreement with U.S. President Joe Biden.\n\nBeyond the Ukraine war, Pope Francis will become the first pope to address a G7 summit, adding a dash of celebrity and moral authority to the annual gathering that is being held this year in Italy's sun-drenched Puglia region. He'll be speaking Friday about the promises and perils of artificial intelligence, but is expected to also renew his appeal for a peaceful end to wars in Ukraine and Gaza.\n\nThe G7 includes Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom and the United States. Host Italy has invited several African leaders -- Algerian President Abdelmadjid Tebboune, Kenyan President William Ruto and Tunisian President Kais Saied -- to press Italy's Africa initiatives. Other guests include Brazilian President Luiz In\u00e1cio Lula da Silva, Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, fresh off his own election, and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.\n\nWith Biden, British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak and now French President Emmanuel Macron facing elections in the coming months, pressure was on the G7 to get done what it can while the status quo lasts.\n\nFrozen Russian assets to support Ukraine\n\nThe U.S. proposal involves using profits from the roughly $260 billion in frozen Russian central bank assets, most of them held in the European Union, to help Ukraine, and issuing a $50 billion loan from the U.S. government to Kyiv, using windfall profits from the immobilized funds as collateral.\n\nA French official, briefing reporters Wednesday, said a political decision by the leaders had been reached but that technical and legal details of the mechanism to tap into the assets still had to be worked out. The issue is complicated because if the Russian assets one day are unfrozen -- say if the war ends -- then the windfall profits will no longer be able to be used to pay off the loan, requiring a burden-sharing arrangement with other countries.\n\nOn the eve of the summit, Washington also sent strong signals of support for Ukraine, with widened sanctions against Russia to target Chinese companies that are helping its war machine.\n\nEurope's new political chessboard\n\nItalian Premier Giorgia Meloni goes into the meeting fortified at home and abroad after her far-right party had an even stronger showing in weekend European Parliament elections than the 2022 elections that made her Italy's first female premier. Known for its revolving-door governments, Italy is now in the unusual position of being the most stable power in the EU.\n\nThe leaders of the G7's two other EU members, Germany and France, didn't fare nearly as well, rattled after hard-right parties made strong showings in the vote. Macron called a snap election and German Chancellor Olaf Scholz saw the far-right Alternative for Germany beat out his Social Democrats.\n\nAs a result, Meloni is likely to be able to steer the three-day meeting to her key priority items as she further cements her role on the world stage, analysts said. One reported sign of her flexed far-right muscles: Meloni's office denied media reports that Italy was trying to water down language about access to abortion in the final communique.\n\n\"While it's unlikely the recent results will radically shift the focus of the upcoming G7 Summit, this electoral win offers Premier Meloni additional leverage to frame this as an essentially 'Mediterranean Summit,\" said Nick O'Connell, deputy director of the Atlantic Council.\n\nThat includes pushing her migration agenda as Meloni seeks to leverage her program for a non-exploitative relationship with Africa to boost development while curbing illegal migration to Europe.\n\nItaly, which for decades has been ground zero in Europe's migration debate, has been promoting its Mattei Plan as a way to create jobs and opportunity in Africa and discourage its young people from making dangerous trips across the Mediterranean Sea. The plan involves pilot projects in areas such as education, health care, water, sanitation, agriculture and energy infrastructure.\n\nThe pope and artificial intelligence\n\nPope Francis has called for an international treaty to ensure AI is developed and used ethically, acknowledging the promise it offers but emphasizing the grave and existential threats it poses.\n\nHe'll bring that campaign to the world's industrialized countries as wars are raging across multiple fronts. One of his greatest concerns has been on the use of AI in the armaments sector, which has been a frequent focus of the Jesuit pope who has called even traditional weapons makers \"merchants of death.\"\n\nBut Francis is also concerned about what AI means for the poorest and weakest: technology that could determine the reliability of an applicant for a mortgage, the right of a migrant to receive political asylum or the chance of reoffending by someone previously convicted of a crime.\n\nThe 87-year-old pope has said he would also repeat his calls for peace while holding a half-dozen bilateral meetings on the sidelines of the summit.\n\nIt's happening where?\n\nThe G7 summit is taking place in a sprawling luxury resort that's something of a theater set, a faux town made to resemble one of Puglia's medieval white-washed hamlets but that actually only dates from 2010.\n\nLocated next to an actual archaeological park, Borgo Egnazia features narrow streets, villas, restaurants and a town square complete with a clocktower. A favorite of celebrities, it will be sealed off to outsiders for the duration of the summit.\n\nNo such five-star accommodations await the 2,000-plus police and carabinieri forces who have been brought in to provide security. Authorities on Wednesday sequestered the decommissioned cruise ship that had been housing them in Brindisi's port, after the police union complained about unacceptable hygienic conditions on board.\n\nAs with any G7, an assortment of anti-global, anti-war and climate activists are staging protests around the summit venue, but far from where the leaders are meeting. One group is staging a \"dinner for the poor\" on Friday night calling for \"peace, the rights of peoples and against the Big 7 who claim to decide the destiny of the world and our planet.\"\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press journalists Angela Charlton and Sylvie Corbet in Paris contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "keyt.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NewsChannel {"uri": "8173611033", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "05:38:04", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T05:38:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T05:37:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.kyivpost.com/post/34140", "title": "White House Says Will Announce Steps on Frozen Russian Assets at G7", "body": "The White House said Tuesday that steps to aid Ukraine using frozen Russian assets will be announced during this week's G7 summit in Italy, as well as new sanctions and export controls on Moscow.\n\n\"We will announce new steps to unlock the value of the immobilized Russian sovereign assets to benefit Ukraine,\" National Security Council spokesman John Kirby told journalists.\n\n\"I think you're going to see unanimity here at the G7 when it comes to working towards using these frozen assets to help Ukraine with their reconstruction,\" he said.\n\nG7 leaders hope to agree a deal on using the profits from the interest on 300 billion euros ($325 billion) of frozen Russian central bank assets to help Kyiv, with the idea being to use the profits as collateral for a loan of up to $50 billion.\n\nKirby also said that \"an impactful set of new sanctions and export control actions\" will be announced, without providing specifics.\n\nUS President Joe Biden and his Ukrainian counterpart Volodymyr Zelensky will hold a bilateral meeting followed by a joint press conference in Italy on Thursday, Kirby said\n\nG7 members will also discuss China's \"support for the Russian defense industrial base, and we will confront China's non-market policies that are leading to harmful global spillovers,\" he added.", "source": {"uri": "kyivpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KyivPost"}, "authors": [{"uri": "https://static.kyivpost.com/storage/2024/06/12/05e7df0bc1ece0dc23449ae67e4f744c.jpg?w=630&q=90&f=jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9644722", "eventUri": "eng-9644722", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.4980392156862745, "wgt": 161, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-06-387864494", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "04:26:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T04:26:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T00:04:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2024-06-13/g7-summit-opens-with-deal-to-use-russian-assets-for-ukraine-as-eus-traditional-powers-recalibrate", "title": "G7 Summit Opens With Deal to Use Russian Assets for Ukraine as EU's Traditional Powers Recalibrate", "body": "BARI, Italy (AP) -- A Group of Seven summit is opening Thursday with agreement on a U.S. proposal to back a $50 billion loan to Ukraine using frozen Russian assets as collateral, giving Kyiv a strong show of support even as Europe's political chessboard shifts to the right.\n\nDiplomats confirmed that an agreement had been reached on the deal before the leaders even landed in southern Italy for the three-day summit. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will be on hand and is expected to sign a separate bilateral security agreement with U.S. President Joe Biden.\n\nBeyond the Ukraine war, Pope Francis will become the first pope to address a G7 summit, adding a dash of celebrity and moral authority to the annual gathering that is being held this year in Italy's sun-drenched Puglia region. He'll be speaking Friday about the promises and perils of artificial intelligence, but is expected to also renew his appeal for a peaceful end to wars in Ukraine and Gaza.\n\nThe G7 includes Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom and the United States. Host Italy has invited several African leaders -- Algerian President Abdelmadjid Tebboune, Kenyan President William Ruto and Tunisian President Kais Saied -- to press Italy's Africa initiatives. Other guests include Brazilian President Luiz In\u00e1cio Lula da Silva, Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, fresh off his own election, and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.\n\nWith Biden, British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak and now French President Emmanuel Macron facing elections in the coming months, pressure was on the G7 to get done what it can while the status quo lasts.\n\nFrozen Russian assets to support Ukraine\n\nThe U.S. proposal involves using profits from the roughly $260 billion in frozen Russian central bank assets, most of them held in the European Union, to help Ukraine, and issuing a $50 billion loan from the U.S. government to Kyiv, using windfall profits from the immobilized funds as collateral.\n\nA French official, briefing reporters Wednesday, said a political decision by the leaders had been reached but that technical and legal details of the mechanism to tap into the assets still had to be worked out. The issue is complicated because if the Russian assets one day are unfrozen -- say if the war ends -- then the windfall profits will no longer be able to be used to pay off the loan, requiring a burden-sharing arrangement with other countries.\n\nOn the eve of the summit, Washington also sent strong signals of support for Ukraine, with widened sanctions against Russia to target Chinese companies that are helping its war machine.\n\nEurope's new political chessboard\n\nItalian Premier Giorgia Meloni goes into the meeting fortified at home and abroad after her far-right party had an even stronger showing in weekend European Parliament elections than the 2022 elections that made her Italy's first female premier. Known for its revolving-door governments, Italy is now in the unusual position of being the most stable power in the EU.\n\nThe leaders of the G7's two other EU members, Germany and France, didn't fare nearly as well, rattled after hard-right parties made strong showings in the vote. Macron called a snap election and German Chancellor Olaf Scholz saw the far-right Alternative for Germany beat out his Social Democrats.\n\nAs a result, Meloni is likely to be able to steer the three-day meeting to her key priority items as she further cements her role on the world stage, analysts said. One reported sign of her flexed far-right muscles: Meloni's office denied media reports that Italy was trying to water down language about access to abortion in the final communique.\n\n\"While it's unlikely the recent results will radically shift the focus of the upcoming G7 Summit, this electoral win offers Premier Meloni additional leverage to frame this as an essentially 'Mediterranean Summit,\" said Nick O'Connell, deputy director of the Atlantic Council.\n\nThat includes pushing her migration agenda as Meloni seeks to leverage her program for a non-exploitative relationship with Africa to boost development while curbing illegal migration to Europe.\n\nItaly, which for decades has been ground zero in Europe's migration debate, has been promoting its Mattei Plan as a way to create jobs and opportunity in Africa and discourage its young people from making dangerous trips across the Mediterranean Sea. The plan involves pilot projects in areas such as education, health care, water, sanitation, agriculture and energy infrastructure.\n\nThe pope and artificial intelligence\n\nPope Francis has called for an international treaty to ensure AI is developed and used ethically, acknowledging the promise it offers but emphasizing the grave and existential threats it poses.\n\nHe'll bring that campaign to the world's industrialized countries as wars are raging across multiple fronts. One of his greatest concerns has been on the use of AI in the armaments sector, which has been a frequent focus of the Jesuit pope who has called even traditional weapons makers \"merchants of death.\"\n\nBut Francis is also concerned about what AI means for the poorest and weakest: technology that could determine the reliability of an applicant for a mortgage, the right of a migrant to receive political asylum or the chance of reoffending by someone previously convicted of a crime.\n\nThe 87-year-old pope has said he would also repeat his calls for peace while holding a half-dozen bilateral meetings on the sidelines of the summit.\n\nIt's happening where?\n\nThe G7 summit is taking place in a sprawling luxury resort that's something of a theater set, a faux town made to resemble one of Puglia's medieval white-washed hamlets but that actually only dates from 2010.\n\nLocated next to an actual archaeological park, Borgo Egnazia features narrow streets, villas, restaurants and a town square complete with a clocktower. A favorite of celebrities, it will be sealed off to outsiders for the duration of the summit.\n\nNo such five-star accommodations await the 2,000-plus police and carabinieri forces who have been brought in to provide security. Authorities on Wednesday sequestered the decommissioned cruise ship that had been housing them in Brindisi's port, after the police union complained about unacceptable hygienic conditions on board.\n\nAs with any G7, an assortment of anti-global, anti-war and climate activists are staging protests around the summit venue, but far from where the leaders are meeting. One group is staging a \"dinner for the poor\" on Friday night calling for \"peace, the rights of peoples and against the Big 7 who claim to decide the destiny of the world and our planet.\"\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press journalists Angela Charlton and Sylvie Corbet in Paris contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved.
